PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware of the presence in the chamber this morning of television cameras and lights. I advise the Senate that I have approved the filming, with the agreement of the party leaders. The purpose of the filming today is twofold. Sequences to be filmed throughout the day will form part of a video film on the operations of the Parliament. That film will be part of an education kit for schools which is being produced by the Parliament itself and which is to be distributed to all schools in Australia during 1987.

INTERJECT.PARA: In addition, the television networks will film the proceedings during Question Time for the purpose of updating the footage they use in illustrating news items on the Senate. Recognising the discomfort caused by the increased lighting, I asked that the film crews ensure that the lights remain on only for the minimum periods necessary to film the footage that they require. At the same time, I ask that honourable senators bear with the discomfort which they may experience because of the increased lighting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal System in Australia, the State and Federal and criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education system, the independence of the Churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children and the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and the employee relationships and the Australian Society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for at least twelve months and for the political parties to become involved in a public awareness program of the Australian Bill of Rights, so that the Australian people can debate, scrutinize and discuss the issue for themselves, prior to a referendum, as to whether or not they want a Bill of Rights introduced

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:-
1. That the Bill of Rights will have the power to override and negate our Common Law within five years of its enactment.

2. Because the Bill of Rights is based on an International Covenant, this will take the control of our country out of the hands of the people and their democratically elected representatives, giving the power to those outside Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
1. That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights and all cognate Bills.
2. That as our representatives, you protect our Australian Heritage and Christian culture and values, both in the Education System, and through the Media.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

1. To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG, and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of ``X'' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

2. To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
We oppose utterly the proposed Bill of Rights because this Bill will
Restrict our rights to those listed in the Bill
Transfer to government powers not given nor intended to be given by the constitution
Threaten our rights by making them subject to the will of this or any future Government
Turn the Human Rights Commission into a political Star Chamber with unjustifiable power
Abrogate Common Law and common liberty
Set the State above the individual
We the undersigned believe in democracy and freedom and earnestly entreat you to recognise that this Bill will undermine the fundamental basis of these.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject the Bill of Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the proposed Bill of Rights because it adversely affects areas of the liberty and freedom of Australians. It will operate against:
The States and our Federal system of Government
Criminal Justice
The Police
Education
Families
Employer/Employee relations

It will remove the power of the people through Parliament, by giving power to a new more powerful Human Rights Commission which is not elected, but can act as a Star Chamber. We do most earnestly wish to keep our system of Common Law.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oil Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should-
pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill.

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not to be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door without a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we support the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985, which will:
protect individuals against violation of their rights by the impact of laws or by the actions of the governmental institutions;
be effective in implementing Australia's international obligations to properly secure fundamental rights and freedoms and
provide an educative charter.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should support the passage of this Bill at an early date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Drug Usage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life particularly by increased penalties for ``drug pushers'' and distributors. We, however, wish to register our firm opposition to any legal changes which would increase or encourage the distribution or availability of so-called ``soft drugs'' such as marijuana. We believe such drugs to be harmful to the physical and psychological health of the individual and therefore to the interest of the community of which such individual is part. Although there is current controversy concerning the question of such harm it appears to us quite foolish to legalise and encourage the use of such drugs unless or until it be shown that such drugs are in fact harmless. The serious social problems of alcohol should provide sufficient warning to our society.
Any efforts to legalise or decriminalise usage or distribution of such drugs will have the following results:
1. Encourage and inculcate a social acceptability towards such drugs.
2. Increase the volume of usage of such drugs in schools and the community by present users and by ``drug pushers'' through the proposed one ounce legal possession.
3. Extend the usage of such drugs to persons who would previously have abstained because of the legal sanctions.

4. Put pressure upon Parliament to establish and license import, growth, manufacture and/or distribution of such drugs, that is, to regulate another destructive industry contrary to the best interest of the individual and society.
5. There would be the probable temptation to tax such drugs as another source of Federal revenue.

We urge the Government to increase the medical and counselling facilities for the assistance of drug users and to expand existing Drug Referral Centres and Clinics. We have general confidence in the existing law and its sympathetic implementation by the Police and Courts.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will firstly take no measures that could extend the major social problem of drug usage and secondly will oblige those who are promoting marijuana and/or similar drugs to prove without doubt that such drugs are harmless before any legalisation or decriminalisation of use is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in vitro fertilization.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Collard (from 254 citizens) and Harradine (from 236 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December, 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematographic Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Gold Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon the healthy, expanding gold mining industry;
(ii) the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations;

(iii) the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and will therefore cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Fringe Benefits Tax will impose intoler-able administration burdens on small businesses and other tax payers.
Will seriously hinder the work of charitable organisations and threaten their viability.
Will result in severe job losses and cause hardship to many Australian families from their involvement in the motor vehicle industry.
Will have serious economic effects on tourism, mining, housing, manufacturing and rural industries.
Your petitioners request that the Government withdraw this harmful and destructive legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions;
that the Hawke Government's Fringe Benefits Tax is an unwarranted burden on the small business and rural sectors, which will severely affect their long-term viability.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government withdraws the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation without delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Dr Keith Reye
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) That the medical services by Dr Keith Reye to the undersigned and their families were reasonably medically necessary and charges of overservicing are unreasonable.
(2) A doctor's and patient's judgment of need for service be beyond question.

Your petitioners humbly request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should oppose charges brought against Dr Keith Reye by the Minister for Health as services rendered were reasonably medically necessary.
National issues in question such as the universal coverage of Medicare to all Australian citizens when in need of any necessary medical service should be debated.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. in that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation forthwith.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Fringe Benefits Tax will place enormous cost increases on employers throughout Australia,

that in so doing, the Fringe Benefits Tax will raise the cost of employing labour particularly in remote locations and that it will inevitably worsen the already high level of unemployment in Australia and
that much of the cost of the tax will be carried by employees as employers reduce benefits
that the cost of the tax will harm small business particularly adversely as these businesses will be un-able to pass on the cost of the tax and as a result many may be forced to close.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Government to repeal this unfair tax before it damages Australian business and thereby reduces the standard of living of all Australians.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the Fringe Benefits Tax will place a costly and unfair burden on independent schools.

The Fringe Benefits Tax will have the most damaging impact upon schools which provide boarding accommodation for children as they are also required to provide accommodation for staff members to live in and supervise the boarders.

Independent schools have limited resources and this additional impost will ultimately have to be passed onto parents, many of whom are already heavily committed to the financing of their children's education.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Parliament to recognise that the future of Australia depends upon the education given to its children and to exempt schools from the operation of the Fringe Benefits Tax.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) France continues to test nuclear weapons at Mururoa atoll contrary to the wishes of all the people of the South Pacific.
(2) Australia is a signatory to-(1) The treaty on the Non Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and the Antarctic Treaty.
(3) Australia is currently pressing for a comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty in the United Nations.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should
(1) Condemn and demand the cessation of French or any other nations nuclear testing in the South Pacific or the use of such area for long range missile tests (e.g. the U.S.S.R. or U.S.A.)

(2) Declare Australia will join with New Zealand and other South Pacific countries in a treaty to make the South Pacific a Nuclear Free Zone in line with that section of the world recognised Antarctic treaty which expressly forbids-The placing, stockpiling, testing or carriage of Nuclear weapons and the establishment of military bases.

SPEECH.PARA: 9 Exhibition Pde
Mt Pritchard 2170.
24th March 1986
Senator B. R. Archer
Parliament House
Canberra
Dear Senator,
We wish to express to you our alarm at the proposed Human Rights Bill, now before Parliament.

Rather than preserve the legal and human rights of Australians, now in operation, this Bill lays the way right open for tyranny and abuse of these rights. It is a Bill which has received no public debate, insufficient Parliamentary debate, and bears all the hallmarks of being hastily put together.

The far reaching effects of this Bill could be devastating to the time-tested and highly-valued system of justice in this country. It is most worthy of note that the Bill is being received gladly by the leaders of totalitarian governments, but has been rejected by the democratic parliaments of Great Britain and United States of America. This nation should, in fact, must, also reject the Bill.
We urgently request that you vote against this Bill, in its entirety, when it comes before the Senate.
Yours Sincerely,
HELEN BLAKE (Mrs)

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED COMMONWEALTH CONTRACTS TO AUSTRALIAN SUPPLIERS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Minister for Finance prepare and bring in a Bill for an Act for the purpose of ensuring that Australian suppliers are given maximum opportunity to compete for Commonwealth contracts for the supply of goods and services, that authorities entering into contracts on behalf of the Commonwealth give proper consideration to Australian suppliers, and that such contracts are awarded to Australian suppliers unless there are cogent reasons for awarding them to non-Australian suppliers, in accordance with the following outline:
PROPOSED COMMONWEALTH CONTRACTS (AUSTRALIAN SUPPLIERS) BILL 1986
Outline of Provisions

1. Purpose of Bill. The purpose of the Bill is to ensure that Australian suppliers are given maximum opportunity to compete for Commonwealth contracts for the supply of goods and services, that authorities entering into contracts on behalf of the Commonwealth give proper consideration to Australian suppliers, and that such contracts are awarded to Australian suppliers unless there are cogent reasons for awarding them to non-Australian suppliers.

2. Application of Bill. The Bill is to apply to all Commonwealth authorities, that is, Commonwealth Departments of State, Parliamentary Departments, statutory authorities and companies owned or controlled by the Commonwealth.

3. General requirement. The Bill is to impose upon Commonwealth authorities a general requirement to ensure that Australian suppliers are given maximum opportunity to compete for Commonwealth contracts, that proper consideration is given to Australian suppliers, and that contracts are awarded to Australian suppliers unless there are cogent reasons for awarding particular contracts to non-Australian suppliers.
4. Australian suppliers. The Bill is to define an Australian supplier in accordance with the following criteria:
(a) for persons other than companies, the persons are to be residents of Australia; and
(b) for companies-
(i) a prescribed percentage of the shareholders is to consist of Australian companies or residents of Australia, or
(ii) a prescribed percentage of the goods to be supplied is to be manufactured in Australia, and
(iii) a prescribed percentage of the profits of the company have been invested in Australia.

5. List of Australian suppliers. The Department of Finance is to compile and maintain a list of Australian suppliers, and collect information to assist Commonwealth authorities to determine whether persons and companies are Australian suppliers.

6. Tenders and quotations. Where the value of contracts is more than the prescribed amount, tenders are to be invited and the invitations to tender are to be directed to the attention of known Australian suppliers. Where the value of contracts is less than that prescribed amount but more than a lower prescribed amount, quotations are to be sought from known suppliers. Exemptions from these requirements may be granted by the Minister for Finance in cases of urgency or exceptional circumstances, and any exemptions are to be laid before both Houses of the Parliament. In submitting tenders or quotations suppliers are to indicate whether they are Australian suppliers, and penalties are to be provided for any false statement.
7. Award of contracts. The award of contracts and the terms of contracts are to be published, together with a statement indicating whether the suppliers are Australian suppliers.

8. Statement of reasons. Where a contract is awarded to a person other than an Australian supplier, the publication referred to in paragraph 6 is to be accompanied by a statement of reasons for the award of the contract to a non-Australian supplier. This statement is to be laid before each House of the Parliament and forwarded to any Australian suppliers who tendered or quoted for the contract. Those suppliers are to be furnished with additional information relating to the reasons for their failure to gain the contract, and any further information relating thereto which they request.

9. Advance notice of contracts. Commonwealth authorities are to give advance notice of invitations to tender for contracts with a value above a prescribed amount, indicating the technology requirements involved in the contracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also seek leave to have the text of papers Nos 1 and 2 incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The papers read as follows-
Statement on the Care of Aged People

1 In my statement of 14 April concerning the Government's response to the Report from the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes entitled ``Private Nursing Homes in Australia: Their Conduct, Administration and Ownership'' (known as the Giles Report), I tabled a Review prepared by my Department on Nursing Homes and Hostels.

2 While making it clear that the Government endorsed the broad strategy and general directions of change in this Review report, I indicated that the Government would be reserving its position on the specific funding implications in the report, pending consultation with the States, the nursing homes and hostels industry, consumer and other welfare groups and professional and staff bodies. The purpose of this Statement is to:
(i) report on the outcome to date of the consultation process; and
(ii) announce the decisions which the Government has taken on the Review in the Budget process.
Consultation

3 The consultation process has established that there is broadly based support for the strategy and directions proposed in the Review to concentrate future growth in aged care services on alternative forms of residential care and community services rather than on more intensive care in nursing homes.
4 A number of important matters have been raised in the consultation process which have influenced the decisions taken by the Government:
(i) the requirement for flexible planning, which provides for monitoring, evaluation and changes where necessary, including more integration with community services;
(ii) a publicised and better resourced hostel sector so that hostels can care for increasingly depen- dent aged people;
(iii) the extension of residential care services beyond hostels to other forms of accommodation such as group housing arrangements;
(iv) the need to expand community services to assist those elderly people most at risk or premature and inappropriate institutionalisation; and
(v) the importance of carefully developing the pro- cess of assessment so that it will gain support from consumers, professionals and service providers.
Future Strategy

5 The aged care policies of Governments over the last twenty years have resulted in a huge and largely uncontrolled growth in expenditure on nursing homes. We can no longer afford to continue the emphasis on intensive and inappropriate levels of care-not only because it will be difficult to sustain rapid growth in nursing homes in the climate of a rapidly ageing population, but more importantly because this system is not resulting in the range of care services which elderly people want and which respect their drive for independence.
6 We have to act now if we are to better meet the needs of the significant number of aged people we will have in this country by the end of this century.

7 The Government's central objective in this Budget is to begin the process of redistributing resources for care of aged people away from nursing homes to alternative forms of residential care and to community care in order to increase the range of aged care services and to achieve improved quality of care arrangements. As evidence of our commitment, this strategy will involve additional expenditure of roughly $24 million in 1986-87, $80 million in 1987-88 and $150 million in 1988-89. These additional costs over the next few years will be offset increasingly by the lower costs of reduced growth in nursing home beds.
8 The main elements of the Government's new strategy include:
(i) increasing recurrent assistance to hostels and increasing the number of hostel places funded through an expanded capital program;
(ii) increasing the resources available for home and community care;
(iii) the development of special programs to cater for the needs of ethnic communities, Aboriginals, dementia sufferers and people with disabilities who are aged;

(iv) the development of co-ordinated assessment processes, including the establishment of new assessment teams, to assist aged people and their families to plan the most appropriate care to meet their particular needs;

(v) the implementation of an information strategy which will ensure that all aged people have access to comprehensive, accurate and timely information on the full range of options and services available to them;
(iv) new growth control arrangements linked to capital funding arrangements and covering both nursing homes and hostels;

(vii) introducing on a phased basis from 1 July 1987 a new standard grant for recurrent nursing home funding arrangements to replace deficit financing for general purpose aged care nursing homes and the separate fee and benefits arrangements for participating nursing homes; and
(viii) in combination with the States, developing a strategy for determining staffing standards in nursing homes, guidance on quality of care and arrangements for tougher inspection processes.
Growth Control

9 As a starting point for planning future provision, the Government has adopted the recommendation made in the Review that growth of residential care services should be planned on the basis of the current national ratio of 100 residential care places per 1000 people aged 70 or over, and that up to 10 per cent of additional beds should be for nursing homes.

10 On the basis of that ratio the Government has decided to plan for the approval of 2750 new places in 1986-87, 4730 in 1987-88 and 5,400 in 1988-89-12,880 additional places overall. A total of up to 1,295 places over the triennium will be for nursing home beds and the balance for hostels (11,585 places). This represents a substantial growth of 30% on the stock of hostel places. These new places will be distributed among the States with the objective of evening out current disparities in the provision of residential care places. I table, and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard, a schedule which shows the distribution of these places across the States.

11 There is an obvious need to overhaul our narrowly based planning methods for residential care. Common criticisms of present arrangements include an inadequate statistical base, the heavy bureaucratic processes involved, the fact that better resourced organisations have been able to obtain access to Government funds ahead of more disadvantaged groups and the limited involvement of consumer, service provider and other organisations in the planning process.

12 With that in mind, I intend to replace the Federal-State Co-ordinating Committees and establish Aged Care Advisory Committees in each State. The objective of the new arrangements will be to ensure that in planning residential care services full account is taken of the availability of community care services; the involvement of consumer bodies and service providers and the continuing and essential contribution of State authorities. I anticipate that the membership of these Committees, their methods of operation and their relationship to HACC advisory structures will need to accommodate the differing circumstances of each State and views of State Governments.
13 Against the backdrop of available demographic information and information on current residential care provision the objective of the Committees will be to provide me with advice on:
(i) those regions or parts or regions which may be inadequately served;
(ii) the needs of particular groups, especially ethnic communities, Aboriginal groups and people with disabilities who are aged;
(iii) the scope for innovation in services, including residentially based respite care services and their integration with community services; and
(iv) the more effective co-ordination of residential and home care services.

14 Subject to my approval of those priorities my Department will begin the process of identifying service providers able to deliver the required services. In some cases this will involve working with organisations which are already well established in the provision of residential care services, but in others there will undoubtedly be a requirement for my Department's resources to be available to assist groups not well placed to develop proposals.
Residential Care Services

15 Key elements of the Review are to provide alternative residential care services to nursing homes in the form of hostels and to strengthen the role of hostels in care of the more frail aged. The consultation process has confirmed the problem of hostels being under-resourced. Moreover, among many consumers hostels have a bad image because they are seen simply as the poor relation of nursing homes and because they are equated with large-scale and impersonal care.

16 There is a need to ensure that hostel operators adopt a management style appropriate to the communal, but more independent, accommodation which they should provide. A name change might help-community homes perhaps. The broader issue, however, is the concern among many consumer organisations that the possibility should be urgently examined of extending residential care service beyond currently assisted hostels to other forms of accommodation.

17 The Government is keen to examine these issues and will be consulting with consumer and voluntary organisations and, in co-operation with the Commonwealth Department of Housing and Construction, with housing authorities on group housing and other matters.

18 In this Budget and in response to concerns expressed by the hostel industry and consumer groups the Government has decided that steps should be taken now to provide a firm commitment to maintain the real level of hostel subsidised over time and to increase assistance for care or more frail aged people. The Government has decided that:
(i) there should be automatic indexation of the hostel care subsidy, respite care subsidy and personal care subsidy with effect from November each year, beginning in November this year; and

(ii) there will be an additional increase of $2.60 a day in the value of the personal care subsidy, making a total of $11 a day from May next year to assist the hostel industry to provide more adequate levels of personal care for dependent elderly people.

19 These measures represent a significantly increased Government commitment to ensuring the effectiveness of the hostel sector in carrying out its role of care for aged people. They will cost $5.6 million in 1986-87 and $24.7 million in 1987-88.
20 The changes build upon the important policy initiatives taken by this Government in 1983 to develop the role of hostels in caring for aged people.
21 The Government recognises that increased numbers of hostel beds will necessitate a significant strengthening of the resources available for capital funding.
22 Additional funds have been allocated to the capital funding program of $13.5 million this year, with planning for an additional $31.7 million and $74.9 million over the following two years to:
(i) lay the basis for the expansion of the hostel sector;
(ii) provide up to 100 per cent capital funding for financially disadvantaged groups, commencing with priority for Aboriginals;
(iii) continue to earmark capital funds for expanded residential accommodation which will actively seek to provide additional access for ethnic communities in 1986/87 and subsequent years; and
(iv) increase the maximum subsidy limits under the Aged and Disabled Persons Homes Act from $16,666 to $20,200 for a single unit and from $19,333 to $23,450 for a double unit.

23 Consistent with the role of providing care it will no longer fund accommodation which does not have as part of its main purpose the provision of care. For this reason, self-contained units will no longer be funded under the Aged and Disabled Persons Homes Act except in respect of those projects which have already been given approval.
Assessment

24 The primary role of assessment teams is to use a range of specialist skills to assist the consumer to clarify his or her needs and to identify the most appropriate options. The teams need to be backed by geriatric, nursing and social work and other skills. If teams fulfil their role effectively, their work should result in aged people receiving more appropriate types of care and assistance more in line with their wishes. We need to remind ourselves continually that older people would prefer to stay at home and do not want to enter institutional care.

25 The Commonwealth will provide $2.0 million, $6.0 million, and $9.0 million over the next three years in addition to the $4.2 million already being spent on assessment. This is a strong start towards the Nursing Home Review's recommendation to support 60 full assessment teams at an annual expenditure of $16 million within three to five years.

26 The Commonwealth and the States have now agreed to work together on a range of assessment issues, including the development of new proposals for assessment. It is the Commonwealth's intention to involve consumers and service providers in the development of such proposals as well as in the policy and management of assessment teams.

27 Discussions are under way with the States on piloting the delegation of admission approvals to nursing homes to assessment teams. I anticipate that the first delegations will be made during 1986-87.
Special Programs

28 The Review proposed an innovative projects program to put the funding of existing approved services in deficit funded homes onto a new basis and to provide special services for the care of those with particular needs, e.g. dementia sufferers.

29 The Government recognises the need for a capacity within residential programs to provide special programs over and above basic care programs. It believes that an innovative approach should be adopted in meeting the care needs of groups who for various reasons cannot be adequately cared for within the usual funding arrangements. With that in mind, the Government has endorsed the concept of a special services program to assist, inter alia:
(i) ethnic communities in gaining access to mainstream nursing homes;
(ii) the further development of programs in the hostel sector for care of dementia sufferers;
(iii) the provision of care in mainstream nursing homes for people with disabilities who are now ageing; and
(iv) to develop programs to assist Aboriginals.
30 Provision has been made in 1986-87 for additional expenditure of $2.0 million and with planning figures of $9.0 million in 1987-88 and $17.5 million in 1988-89 under this new program.

31 My Department will be working with professionals and the community to ensure the development of relevant programs, and with voluntary organisations to draw out a clear picture of current services in deficit funded nursing homes.
Community Services

32 In initiating the Home and Community Care (HACC) program, the Government recognised the importance of developing new community care services and expanding existing ones if the wishes of elderly people themselves to be supported as far as possible in their own homes were to be addressed. The provision of additional resources for HACC was a recognition also of the need for a more appropriate balance between the resources provided for community services and residential care.

33 Under the terms of Commonwealth-State Agreements in establishing HACC the Commonwealth is making available $30 million in additional funds for the program in 1986-87. A growth rate of up to 20 per cent is assured for the programs in 1987-88. The net result will be to lift to a considerably higher plateau the total of resources available for HACC in 1987-88 and beyond.

34 Our consultations have shown that elderly people need the security of knowing that the appropriate services will be available if they are to continue to live at home with confidence. The history of inadequate access to service provision and increasing level of need within the community means that additional resources will be needed in HACC to:
(i) improve access by the whole HACC target population to the services of home help, home nursing, food services and respite care;
(ii) increase the hours of service available to those clients with more intensive care requirements;
(iii) make services more responsive to the needs of special groups, ethnic communities, Aboriginals and isolated people; and
(iv) develop approaches to the delivery of services which ensure through assessment and better co-ordinated services that individuals receive appropriate packages of the services they require.

35 The Commonwealth has, therefore, decided to make available a total of $94 million over a four year period starting 1 July 1987 for expenditure on new and expanded home and community care services. The Government is planning to start projects to the value of $5 million in 1987-88, $8 million in 1988-89, $15 million in 1989-90 and $20 million in 1990-91 which will have a full year cost by 1990-91 of $48 million.

36 The Commonwealth Government will not require State Governments to match these additional amounts of money. However, the availability of additional Commonwealth funds will be subject to a number of conditions, including maintenance of State Government contributions under HACC and, in particular, that individual State Governments agree to index their HACC base by 20% in the four years from 1987-88 to 1990-91. The Commonwealth will also be seeking assurances that State Governments will provide additional unmatched resources for HACC if they in turn embark on policy and program changes that involve, as a consequence, increased pressures on HACC services.

37 I have asked the Office for the Aged and Office of Disability to report to me by the end of September from a consumer perspective on possible future directions and priorities for HACC. This, together with the ongoing policy and program work of my Department and State Governments should lay a better basis for establishing future directions and priorities by Commonwealth and State Governments and HACC Advisory Committees.
Next Steps

38 The decisions announced in this Budget on care of aged people will set the scene for changing the existing balance between providing intensive care through nursing homes and providing appropriate community services and hostel options. The process of change will be gradual and it will be essential that implementation is carefully monitored, evaluated and, where necessary, adjusted.

39 The next step in implementing the Review will be to change the recurrent funding arrangements for nursing homes and to ensure appropriate quality of care and enforcement of standards from 1 July 1987.

40 As regards funding, I welcome the constructive attitude which has been adopted by both the private and voluntary sectors to the Review. Between now and the end of 1986 my Department will be drawing together the financial data which will be necessary to determine the basis for the new funding arrangements to replace existing deficit funded and nursing home benefit arrangements for the care of aged persons. The objective of the new funding arrangements will be to move from the current cost reimbursement arrangements based on assessed costs of individual nursing homes to a benefit system based on a standard fee and benefit structure across Australia.

41 Under the proposed funding arrangements the Commonwealth will stipulate the standard of care which it believes is reasonable to fund. The Commonwealth and States have agreed to set up a working party to report on matters relating to standards and there will be continuing consultation with consumers, professional and staff bodies and some provider organisations on matters relating to standards.

42 Specifically it will be important that the Commonwealth and the States together agree on key matters relating to quality of care objectives and the staffing standards to apply in nursing homes. There is agreement between the Commonwealth and States that they should work together in developing joint and co-ordinated nursing home inspection programs. Urgent work is proceeding on means of making existing sanctions more effective against those proprietors who provide sub-standard care.

43 Subject to the work which is being done on developing better co-ordinated Commonwealth-State inspection programs, it is anticipated that decisions can be taken early in 1987 on the means of most effectively inspecting the provision of appropriate care. This will involve not only Commonwealth-State agreement on a range of matters relating to standards but also on appropriate staff training and placement for this important work.
Conclusion

44 The Government has allocated an additional $23.90 million in this Budget for expenditure in 1986-87 to implement a new system of care for the aged as set out in the Review of Nursing Homes and Hostels and is planning, subject to confirmation in future Budgets, a commitment to spend additional sums in the order of $81 million in 1987-88, and $151.8 million in 1988-89. These are significant additional sums in a time of economic restraint even though they will increasingly be offset by the lower costs of reduced growth in expenditure on nursing homes.

45 The Government is responding appropriately to the concerns of the community for care of its ageing members and the need to plan for the provision of alternative options to traditional nursing home care in the 1990's.

46 The success of this strategy will depend on a continuing partnership between the Commonwealth and State Governments, consumers, service providers, the welfare sector, professional staff bodies and others. So that this can occur I intend that my Department should consult with the widest range of interests possible. Meanwhile, the Office for the Aged and Office of Disability will continue to provide me with advice from a consumer perspective on the implementation of the strategy.

47 We are at the beginning of a long process of ensuring that arrangements made for the care of out elderly people are sensitive to their physical and social needs. This Government has put in place a framework within which it is possible to plan the increased resources which will be needed to care for increasing numbers of aged people. We have committed ourselves now to providing the significant additional resources needed to achieve a better match between the needs and wishes of aged people through action now to expand alternative residential and community care services.

48 The Government has listened to the community in developing its framework. It will continue to do so. The end result will be a very different approach to the way aged care is provided-an approach which provides greater choice to meet the needs of individual aged people throughout the Australian community.

Statement on new Disability Services Legislation

The purpose of this statement is to inform the Senate of the Government's plans for introducing new Disability Services legislation which will replace the present Handicapped Persons Assistance Act 1974, and contain legislative provision for the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Program and the Program of Aids for Disabled People.

Among the first initiatives of this Government were decisions to fund the Australian chapter of Disabled Peoples' International and to establish the Disability Advisory Council of Australia to provide direct advice to the Government from people with disabilities themselves.

These two initiatives in 1983 resulted in increased exposure and discussion of the issues facing people with disabilities. It became clear that there was a need for fundamental change in the way the community provides for the needs of people with disabilities and that a truly comprehensive review of all Commonwealth policies and programs was required.

Accordingly, in late 1983 we set up the Handicapped Programs Review to examine all Commonwealth programs and services directed at assisting people with disabilities. This Review was the first of its kind in Australia, being based both on submissions and on extensive community consultation, especially with people with disabilities. During the course of the Review over 65 towns and cities across Australia were visited and more than 5,000 people were involved in meetings, seminars and personal interviews.

Pending publication of the Review Report, the Prime Minister announced in December 1984 the establishment of the Office of Disability whose responsibilities include providing advice to the Government on the quality and effectiveness of services at a national level. One of its roles is to carry forward initiatives contained in the report of the Handicapped Programs Review entitled ``New Directions'' which I tabled on 30 May 1985.

The Report found broad community support for the Commonwealth's policies of meeting needs through mainstream community programs as far as possible, and of ensuring that the least restrictive alternative principle is followed where specific services are required for people with disabilities. It concluded that substantial improvements were required in the accountability of subsidised organisations for service content and quality, and that major changes were needed in the programs themselves. A restructuring of services, funding and other resources was also required.

The Review believed that these changes could be effected only through new legislation to replace the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, based on the principle that positive consumer outcomes should be the rationale for program development, delivery and review.

The Government at the time endorsed the thrust of the report and I foreshadowed new legislation under the Community Services portfolio to provide for the range of Commonwealth support programs for people with disabilities to replace the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act. The Government will be introducing such new legislation in the Budget Session.

One of the major thrusts of the new legislation will be to establish a clear linkage between a commitment and action by organisations in achieving desirable outcomes for individual people with disabilities and organisations' receipt of financial assistance from the Commonwealth.

For some time, and within the constraints of the present legislation, my Department has been working closely with organisations conducting subsidised services to encourage them to provide programs on the ``least restrictive alternative'' model and more recently to adopt the principles underlying the New Directions report.

The substantive work of re-shaping existing methods of service delivery is, however, still largely ahead of us and, with this in mind, the Government has adopted a two-fold strategy to achieve a complete re-structuring of services for people with disabilities subsidised under current legislation.

The first component in our strategy is a program of demonstration projects to illustrate to service providers and to people with disabilities who are the consumers of those services, the types of services and the principles and operating practices underlying them which the Government wishes to promote in the context of ``New Directions''.

This demonstration program commenced this year and will run for two years, costing some $20 million in total. Examples in two key areas will make it clear how different, even radical, some of these new types of services may be when seen against the traditional service pattern.

In the area of vocational services, where the principal choice for disabled people in the past has generally been limited to sheltered employment, services to be developed include long-term supported employment models such as:
work enclaves in open industry where small groups of disabled workers are given special training, supervision, and adjusted work targets;
work crews where a group of disabled people are an integral part of an independent commercial business; and
individual work-stations where a disabled person works alongside non-disabled workers, but support is provided through extra training and supervision on site.

There will also be competitive employment and placement programs which will train disabled people in work skills and work-related behaviours and locate individual jobs for the program graduates in open employment. Examples of this might be where a cafeteria teaches food service tasks and finds people jobs in regular restaurants. In these instances, any subsidy provided would be for the training and personal support components only, not towards the commercial activity as such.

From these examples, it is clear how we are opening up vocational opportunities which will greatly enhance the dignity and better match the aspirations of people with disabilities, compared with the limiting, isolating, and often stigmatising options traditionally available.

The other key area where I would like to give examples of new types of services is that of supported residential accommodation for people with disabilities. We are all familiar to varying degrees with the traditional residential institutions where dozens, but at times even hundreds, of people with disabilities are accommodated in the one large complex.
More community integrated models of residential support have already begun to be introduced, but the demonstration program will broaden the range of options available by including approaches such as:
co-tenancy arrangements where a non-disabled person offers support to a disabled flat-mate in return for concessional costs of living;

tenant support programs where disabled people occupying a number of flats in a single development are given support from staff living in a separate flat both at set time periods (such as meal preparation) and on-call if necessary;
group homes in ordinary community settings with live-in or on-call staffing appropriate to the needs of a small group of multiply-disabled adults;

model or demonstration de-institutionalising projects which support an existing organisation in the transition from a large institutional facility to a more appropriate range of housing options in the community for its existing residents; and
respite programs.

All told, under the demonstration program, we have so far funded 68 projects, comprising-14 long-term supported employment projects; 13 competitive employment projects; 14 projects exploring options in residential living; and 27 projects providing advocacy and information services and individual personal development planning for people with disabilities. I regard these as significant achievements.

The second component of the Government's strategy for restructuring of the system is the introduction of the new legislation. Our original intention was to introduce the new legislation in this present Autumn session but this will not now be achievable because of pressures on Parliamentary Counsel. As I said earlier, the Bill will be introduced in the Budget session 1986.

However, I am able to indicate now the scope of the new Bill. It will draw together existing programs for people with disabilities within the Community Services portfolio and provide a new coherent framework for these programs to facilitate the pursuit of the Government's objectives for people with disabilities.
The new Bill will contain an explicit statement of its goals and objectives. These may be summarised as:

to achieve for people with disabilities positive outcomes such as long-term increases in independence, participation in paid employment, integration into the community, and the promotion of a positive image;
to provide financial assistance to eligible organisations conducting approved services directed at achieving such outcomes in an integrated fashion;
to enable service performance in achieving the desired outcomes to be taken into account in making funding decisions; and
to encourage innovation in service development and delivery.

There will also be specific objectives relating to the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Program and the Program for Aids for Disabled People both of which will be incorporated into the Bill. I will refer to these programs again later.

First and foremost, the Bill will provide for the funding of a range of services many of which are outside the provisions of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, which will be repealed. Some of these categories will be:
Accommodation Support;
Selected Respite Services;
Supported Employment;
Competitive Employment Training and Placement;
Independent Living Training;
Advocacy and Information;
Recreation;
Individual Assessment and Program Planning; and
Services for Persons with a Print Disability.

The Government recognises that non-government bodies play an essential role in providing services for people with disabilities and will retain the concept of assisting eligible organisations as service providers.
The Bill will include a clear definition of the eligible target group to be assisted by organisations receiving financial support. The proposal is that the target group be comprised of people who:
have an intellectual impairment or a sensory or physical impairment, being a sensory or physical impairment which has become manifest before the person has reached the age of 50 years;
are likely to have that impairment indefinitely; and
as a result of that impairment have a long term incapacity for independent living and have a substantive functional limitation in relation to communication, learning or mobility.
There will be a discretion to include in the target group categories not specifically mentioned in the Bill, if this promotes the purposes of the legislation.

The range of services provided by the Commonwealth and the States in the disability area varies from State to State and the situation is complex. I intend that the new Bill will provide a mechanism whereby inter-governmental and agency co-operation can be enhanced. Local government will continue to qualify for the funding of approved services under the new legislation. The new legislation will also encourage partnership arrangements with State Governments.

One of the biggest problems with the current Act is that there is no recognition of the different funding requirements of different service types. There needs to be flexibility to recognise the widely differing needs of people assisted under the program and the differing needs of individual service types. Rather than a set funding formula, I propose that the Bill provide for funding formulae to be set out in regulations. These funding formulae will change the ad hoc arrangements which exist at present and will reflect the desired outcomes anticipated for individuals.

To assist in developing detailed funding formulae, my Department is sponsoring a consultancy to identify the actual costs of conducting the various types of services, and to make recommendations on the formulae to be adopted. This task will obviously require a great deal of careful analysis and take some time to complete.
When developed and approved by Parliament, these funding formulae will be applied to services which meet the objectives of the new legislation.
In the meantime, in order to provide for funding continuity, transitional funding arrangements will apply to currently funded organisations.

As I mentioned earlier, the new Bill will also provide a new legislative basis for rehabilitation services administered within the community services portfolio thus removing them from Part VIII of the Social Security Act. This will involve transfer of the enabling provisions from that Act to the new Disability Services Act, with some minor modifications. This will facilitate a common philosophical base for the Government's assistance to people with disabilities.

The Department's rehabilitation program is currently over half way through a Three Year Forward Plan which emphasises the development of community based services in preference to those provided in institutional settings, and concentrates on social and vocational rehabilitation for working aged people and on improving access to rehabilitation programs by women, Aboriginals and people with non-English speaking backgrounds.

It is proposed that our rehabilitation services, providing as they do, a direct service to people with disabilities, should work closely with those areas of my portfolio which fund organisations providing services to disabled people. This will ensure the provision of a co-ordinated range of services.

The Bill will also provide for the Commonwealth's Program of Aids for Disabled People, currently based in various provisions of the National Health Act. At this point the Government is proposing no major changes to this program but the opportunity will be taken to improve its operation through minor legislative modifications.

At this stage, I anticipate that the new legislation will become operative as from 1 April 1987. For operational reasons The Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and those sections of the Social Security Act relating to the provision of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Program will not be repealed until 30 June 1987. In addition discussions are taking place with the Department of Health regarding the authority for the operation of the PADP scheme. Regulations will then be introduced under the new Act to provide initially for interim funding for organisations who commit themselves by way of formal contracts to the objectives of the new program. This interim funding will be similar to that currently provided under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act.

Departmental officers will be contacting each organisation through to April 1987 to discuss the objectives of the new legislation as this relates to the specific service types, and to invite organisations to enter into contracts which will be consistent with the new legislation.

There may be a small number of existing services which will not qualify for funding at all under the new legislation. I envisage that carry-on funding at existing levels will be available for these services until such time as other arrangements can be made for them.
A requirement under the new legislation will be that a review of all services, to assess their achievement of the objectives embodied in the legislation, be undertaken at least every five years.

The Department of Community Services will be conducting a series of short intensive workshops to explain in more detail the operational significance of the new legislation and its underlying aims and objectives. The present intention is for these to commence towards the end of 1986.

At the same time as the introduction of the new Disability Services Bill the Government will launch a Statement of Principles and Objectives in relation to people with disabilities to be followed in the administration of the legislation and specifically to be applied to individual services. We will also work towards the implementation of the Principles and Objectives by all those involved in service delivery to people with disabilities. A draft of the Statement of Principles and Objectives is attached.

The Principles recognise that people with disabilities are individuals who have an inherent right to respect for their human worth and dignity, and, irrespective of the origin, nature, type and degree of disability have the same fundamental rights as do other members of society. This applies to the realisation of individual potential; to involvement in decision-making in matters affecting their lives; to the pursuit of grievances and rights; and to services which offer the least restrictive alternative in the achievement of these ends.

The Objectives relate more directly to service delivery and cover aspects such as a focus on consumer benefits, integration of services into the regular service structure where possible, and a community-based focus for specialist services where these are required.

Adoption of the Principles and Objectives will have some very practical consequences for service delivery. They will demand new standards of accountability by service providers to their disabled clients. They will require a new emphasis on the rights of privacy and confidentiality. They will herald a drawing to a close of an era in which regrettably it has been possible for single organisations, in some cases without any accountability, to control the entire life of a person with a disability.

The Handicapped Programs Review contained a large number of recommendations. As a means of pursuing both those covered by the new legislation and other matters, I am writing to my Commonwealth ministerial colleagues seeking their assistance in those areas which are pertinent to their respective portfolio responsibilities. For similar purposes I have also written to State Ministers, especially to open up the wider issues of co-ordination between State and Commonwealth initiatives which will promote a better future for people with disabilities.

The Handicapped Programs Review has demonstrated the crucial importance of consultation with the community about the needs and aspirations of people with disabilities, but most of all with disabled people themselves. Such consultation will continue to be a cornerstone of the Government's policy in this area.

I have outlined in this Statement the intention of the Government in the area of disability services. However, before I introduce the necessary Bill into Parliament, I and my departmental officers will be seeking discussions with relevant groups on the proposals I have outlined. I also expect those discussions to assist in the development of specific guidelines which will apply to the varying service types. I hope to be in a position to table those guidelines when I introduce the new legislation in the Budget Session.
Draft Statement of Principles and Objectives
Principles
1. People with disabilities are individuals who have the inherent right to respect for their human worth and dignity.
2. People with disabilities, whatever the origin, nature, type and degree of disability, have the same fundamental rights as all members of Australian society.
3. Every person with a disability has the same rights as other members of Australian society to realise their individual capacity for physical, social, emotional and intellectual development.
4. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to services which will support their attaining an acceptable quality of life.
5. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to participate in the decisions which affect their lives.
6. People with disabilities have the same right as other members of Australian society to the least restrictive alternative in the services they receive.
7. People with disabilities have the same right of grievance as other members of Australian society in relation to the services which they receive.

In response to these principles, the Commonwealth Government will adopt the following objectives in its provision of services to people with disabilities and promote their adoption by non-government organisations, Local Government and State Governments providing assistance to people with disabilities. (A service is defined as direct assistance predominantly of a non-monetary nature provided through the Government or voluntary organisations. A program is any specific assistance of a direct service or of a monetary nature funded by the Government.)
Objectives
1. That the focus of service delivery to people with disabilities should be the achievement of positive outcomes.

2. That services for people with disabilities should ensure that the conditions of the every-day life of people with disabilities are the same as, or as close as possible to, norms and patterns which are valued in the general community.
3. That services for people with disabilities should be provided as part of local co-ordinated service systems and integrated with generic services wherever possible.
4. That people with disabilities should receive services which are tailored to their individual needs and goals.
5. That programs and services should promote a competent and positive image of people with disabilities.
6. That programs and services should promote the participation of people with disabilities in the life of the local community through maximum physical and social integration.
7. That no single organisation providing services should exercise control over all or most aspects of the life of an individual with disabilities.
8. That services providing assistance to people with disabilities, be they specific or generic, should be accountable to consumers and their representatives, funding bodies and the public at large.

9. That programs and services should provide opportunities for people with disabilities to reach goals and enjoy lifestyles which are valued by the community at large and are appropriate to their chronological age.
10. That disabled people should have access to advocacy support where necessary to ensure adequate participation in decision-making about the services they receive.
11. That services should provide appropriate avenues for people with disabilities to air and resolve grievances about the service they receive.

12. That disabled people should be provided with avenues for participating in the planning and operation of individual services and opportunities for consultation relating to major policy development and program changes.
13. That services for people with disabilities should respect an individual's rights of privacy and confidentiality.
NOTE: Individuals with disabilities should be read to include advocates and families of children with disabilities where appropriate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO BRITISH NUCLEAR TESTS IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave- The report of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia was presented to the Governor-General on 20 November 1985 and was tabled in Parliament on 5 December 1985. No substantive response was made to its recommendations at that stage. In summary, the seven Royal Commission recommendations were as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Extend the benefits of Commonwealth Government employees compensation legislation, including reverse onus of proof, to civilians at the sites, and to Aborigines and other civilians who may have been exposed to black mist;
2. compile a national register of nuclear veterans, Aborigines and others who may have been exposed to black mist or radiation at the tests;
3. clean-up Maralinga and Emu so that they are fit for unrestricted habitation by the traditional Aboriginal owners;
4. establish a Maralinga Commission to oversee the clean-up and co-ordinate future management of the site;
5. signpost areas still not suited for permanent habitation on the Monte Bello Islands and to collect small debris;
6. all clean-up costs for Maralinga, Emu and Monte Bellos to be borne by the United Kingdom Government; and
7. compensate those with traditional interests in the Maralinga lands, in the form of technology and services.

Some of these recommendations raise complex policy issues, some involve delicate intergovernmental negotiations, some cannot be finally addressed without extensive further technical research; all have taken time to consider, and some-for reasons which I will make clear-will not be able to be finally responded to for some time yet. The Government, nonetheless, is conscious of the importance of the matters dealt with in the Royal Commission report-especially for the Aboriginal traditional owners and those claiming to have suffered illness or injury as a consequence of the United Kingdom tests-and remains keen to sustain the momentum that has already developed in the nine months since the report was presented. We have accordingly now determined our responses, to a greater or lesser extent, to recommendations 1, 2, 4 and 7; we are actively engaged in the process of considering recommendations 3 and 5; and we have commenced discussions with the United Kingdom Government-as yet only in their preliminary stages-in relation to recommendation 6.
Recommendation 1: Compensation for Individuals

In accordance with this recommendation, the Government has decided to extend compensation eligibility to Aborigines and non-Commonwealth employees, at the rates and under the rules currently applicable under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. The Department of Social Security will establish an administrative scheme to handle these arrangements. Persons eligible to claim compensation under the scheme will include Aborigines and other civilians, such as graziers, who may have been exposed to the black mist. Construction workers, such as those still present at Maralinga at the time of the first test there, will also be eligible.

The existing onus of proof provisions of the Compensation Act-including the existing `reverse onus' clause in section 30-will apply to Aborigines and non-Commonwealth employees in the same way as to Commonwealth employees who are suffering injuries or disease which may have resulted from the atomic tests. Section 30 provides that where the disease in question is one specified in the regulations as being related to employment of a particular kind, then `unless the contrary is established, the employment . . . shall be deemed to have been a contributing factor to the contraction of the disease'. Item 4 of regulation 12 of the Compensation (Commonwealth Employees) Regulations in turn identifies a `pathological condition caused by . . . radium or another radioactive substance' as being related to `employment involving exposure to or contact with radium or other radioactive substances'.

The net result of these provisions, in the present context, is that if a claimant can establish that he or she has a disease in fact caused by a radioactive substance, and that he or she suffered exposure to a radioactive substance as a result of being employed or otherwise present at or near the atomic test sites, that exposure will be `deemed to have contributed' to that disease-unless the Commonwealth can establish the contrary. It will be appreciated-advice from the Attorney-General's Department confirms this-that this `reverse onus' provision does not extend as far as deeming that any particular pathological condition, for example, cancer, which could possibly have been caused by exposure to a radioactive substance was in fact caused by such exposure. That must be established by the claimant in the ordinary way on the balance of probabilities.

The pathological condition usually cited in compensation claims under regulation 12 item 4 is cancer. But the natural incidence of death from cancer in the Australian population is approximately one in five, and similar statistics apply elsewhere in the world. It is no doubt because of this high natural incidence that the existing Compensation Act provisions do not assume that a person's cancer has been caused by exposure to radioactivity but require this to be established on the balance of probabilities. Although it may not be easy in every case for claimants to establish on the balance of probabilities the necessary causal link between their disease and exposure to radioactivity, it seems highly unlikely, on the basis of the material cited in the Royal Commission report-although the Commission's conclusions were not quantified in this respect-that any injustice will be done.
