The United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation has concluded that the risks of fatal cancer induction from external radiation is of the order of one chance in 100,000 for every millisievert of radiation dose. On this basis, at the very low levels of radiation to which some 15,000 Australians-including Commonwealth employees, non-Commonwealth employees and Aborigines-may have been exposed during the tests, there is a risk of only one or two cancer cases in excess of normal population incidence. While the Government will not be seeking to deny compensation in any case where compensation appears justified, it will nevertheless make full use of the appeals process if compensation is awarded and it believes that Commonwealth liability does not exist.
Recommendation 2: National Register

The Government does not consider that it is either possible or appropriate to create a new national register of the kind envisaged in Royal Commission recommendation 2. However, the objectives of this recommendation can still be met to a very great extent by the existing and proposed arrangements described below. Recommendation 2 envisaged the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation having access to a database of nuclear veterans, Aborigines and other persons who may have been exposed to the black mist or exposed to radiation at the test sites during or after the tests. It would be virtually impossible, however, to produce such a comprehensive database now for Aborigines and pastoral workers. The precise numbers of aborigines, let alone their names, who may have been exposed to the black mist could not now be determined, and the reliability of such a register would be highly questionable.

Two substantial lists of persons involved in the tests and possibly exposed to radiation already exist within my Department. The first list was created as a result of continuing public concerns over the effects of the tests on the health of atomic test personnel, which led to the preparation of an epidemiological study carried out by the Department of Health. As an integral part of the study, my Department conducted an extensive record search in concert with a nationally advertised notice requesting atomic test personnel to complete a health survey form. In all about 15,300 people have been identified through this process. Of these, some 8,000 were included in the epidemiological study. The second list, compiled by the Australian Radiation Laboratory, is based on a United Kingdom `medical-in-confidence' listing of radiation exposures.

Any additional information which might be obtained through a further advertising campaign or record searches is unlikely to add significantly to the existing database. Much of the existing information which would need to be incorporated into any new register is protected by the Epidemiological Studies (Confidentiality) Act from direct disclosure to anyone but the individual concerned. Arrangements can readily be made, building on existing practice, to ensure that compensation claimants and the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation can get access to all relevant material in the Commonwealth's possession. The claimants themselves can pass such information to the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation should they choose to do so. Where the information is not protected by the confidentiality legislation it can be provided direct to the Commissioner and the claimant.

As a result of extensive searches of Commonwealth files made in the course of the Royal Commission's inquiry, my Department now holds a substantial body of information. It can and will provide such information, relevant to a person's presence or activities during the tests, to that person on request. Persons requesting access to such information held by my Department will also be provided with a statement on the health risks of radiation exposure, prepared by the Department of Health, so they will be in a position to make some preliminary evaluation of the likely effect of any exposure in their particular cases.
Recommendation 3: Clean-up of Maralinga and Emu

Following ministerial discussions in London on 22 January this year, two bodies were established to work towards the resolution of the remaining problems of contamination associated with the Maralinga and Emu test sites in South Australia and, to a lesser extent, the Monte Bello Islands off the Western Australian coast. The first is a technical assessment group, or TAG, as it has become known, to advise on field studies and laboratory research and report in detail on options-and costs-for the radioactive and toxic decontamination of the sites. The TAG, whose composition, terms of reference and functions were announced on 19 February, consists of two Australian scientists, Mr D. R. Davy, Chief of the Environment Science Division of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, as convenor, and Dr K. H. Lokan, Director of the Australian Radiation Laboratory. It also comprises a United States plutonium decontamination expert, Mr B. W. Church, Director of Health Physics Division, Nevada Operations Office, Department of Energy, and two British experts nominated by the United Kingdom Government, Dr H. Smith, Head of Biology Department, National Radiological Protection Board, and Mr D. Deverall, formerly Head of the Chemical Technology Division, Atomic Weapons Research Establishment.

The second body is a consultative group, consisting of representatives of the Australian, United Kingdom, South Australian and Western Australian governments, and the association representing the Maralinga traditional owners, Maralinga Tjarutja, formed to discuss and monitor progress on the clean-up. The most serious continuing contamination problem is clearly at Maralinga, where the main concerns are:

(a) the distribution of some 22 kilograms of plutonium, either dispersed in fragments at unacceptable concentrations over a large land area, or buried amid a mass of debris in over 20 burial pits at the Taranaki and TM101 sites; and
(b) the large quantities of uranium, and the toxic chemical beryllium, dispersed over a significant land area at a number of minor trial sites.

The TAG held its first meeting in Canberra in February, which was followed by a visit to the test sites at Maralinga. The second meeting was held in London in May, and was preceded by a visit to the United States Nevada test sites. At its second meeting, the TAG completed an interim report on studies judged as prerequisites to the formulation of options and associated costs to rehabilitate the test sites in Australia. This report, which was presented to me at the end of May, described a range of studies to determine the nature, extent and potential hazards of contamination at Maralinga and Emu, and possible reclamation processes and remedial measures.

The consultative group has met twice in Canberra in April and June. At its first meeting discussions centred on an exchange of views between the representatives on clean-up issues and future management of the test sites. The convenor of the TAG provided an explanation of the TAG interim report at the second meeting in June. Following some discussion of the proposed studies there was a consensus within the group that those studies concerning the nature, extent and potential hazards of contamination should be given priority. In response to the TAG interim report and the consultative group's consideration of it, the Government has now decided that at least six studies should be carried out over the next two years, to enable determination of an optimal clean-up program. These are:
A regional study to determine, by airborne and subsequent detailed ground surveys, the extent of contamination;
an anthropological program to quantify the lifestyle characteristics of a critical group in order to define the risks associated with ingestion and inhalation of radioactive and toxic contaminants;
a program to obtain samples of soil, fauna and flora from lands at Maralinga and Emu which are contaminated with radioactivity to significant levels;
laboratory studies of the bioavailability of plutonium and americium from inhalation and ingestion experiments;
the assessment, using contemporary models, of exposures associated with the inhalation of resuspended dust at Taranaki and other contaminated areas for a variety of realistic scenarios; and
the detection of radionuclides and toxic contamination in animal tissue, plant, air filter and soil samples by chemical or radiochemical analysis.

The cost of these studies has been estimated at $3.4m over two years. As announced on Budget night, $1m has been provided to cover the Australian contribution in 1986-87. I have approached the United Kingdom Government seeking a 50 per cent contribution to the study program in cash or kind and will follow up this matter with the United Kingdom Government during a visit to London in early October. The Government is continuing to work on the refinement of ultimate clean-up options and costs in consultation with the TAG and members of the consultative group. We will be looking at possible further preliminary studies, as and when the need for these has been established. When all necessary information is to hand, an appropriate final clean-up strategy will be formulated.
Recommendation 4: Maralinga Commission

On 23 January, after ministerial talks in London, I announced that neither the Australian Government nor the United Kingdom Government favoured the creation of a formal Maralinga Commission of the kind recommended by the Royal Commission, both governments taking the view that the matters at issue could be properly resolved only by direct intergovernment negotiation. The technical assessment group and the consultative group, described above, carry out certain functions envisaged by the Royal Commission for the Maralinga Commission. The TAG and consultative group arrangements have worked effectively to date. The Government is receiving scientific advice from the former, and is made aware by the latter of the views of those with a direct interest in clean-up issues. In this way the Government itself makes the decision on the appropriate course of action in these matters, but only after being fully informed of and taking into account the views of the various interests involved.
Recommendation 5: Monte Bello Islands

Consideration of any clean-up options for the Monte Bello Islands has been deferred by the TAG until proposed Western Australian Government management plans for the Islands have been finalised. The matter is being pursued through the consultative group. The number of warning signs on the Islands is considered adequate at present and they are being maintained regularly.
Recommendation 6: United Kingdom to bear Clean-Up Costs

The Australian Government's position, as put by me to the United Kingdom Ministers in London in January, is that the statement in the original 1956 memorandum of arrangements relating to the Maralinga site is still an appropriate description of both the legal and moral responsibility of the United Kingdom Government; namely, that:
The United Kingdom Government accepts liability for such corrective measures as may be practicable in the event of radioactive contamination resulting from tests on the site.

The United Kingdom Government's position is that it remains to be convinced-in the light of the clean-up of the site which did take place in 1967 and the release signed by the Australian Government the following year-that it has either a legal or a moral responsibility. Although some preliminary discussions have taken place on these issues, both governments agreed that at this stage the most constructive course would be to put to one side the question of liability for clean-up costs and to focus attention on what are in fact `practicable' solutions-in cost-benefit terms-to the remaining contamination problems. The immediate need has been a full-scale scientific evaluation of the measures needed, and the costs involved, in order to achieve varying possible degrees of access to, and habitation of, the contaminated test sites. This was recognised by the Royal Commission itself when it said, at conclusion 182:

Various options for clean-up were considered but the Royal Commission has not been able to make detailed recommendations because insufficient data were tendered on the levels of risk, options for clean-up and the associated costs.

The United Kingdom Government agreed to participate in the required scientific evaluation-being carried out by the technical assessment group, with its two United Kingdom representatives-on a completely `without prejudice' basis, and the Australian Government willingly accepted this. As indicated above, approaches have been made on a possible contribution by the United Kingdom Government to the research program needed to identify clean-up options, but any such contribution would again be without prejudice to the question of responsibility for payment for the final clean-up.
Recommendation 7: Compensation to Aboriginal Traditional Owners

The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has announced that relocation compensation will be provided to communities with a traditional interest in land within the former Maralinga prohibited area. An amount of $500,000 has been provided in this year's Budget to assist in the provision of roads, a permanent water supply and basic communications, among other facilities. The details of the programs will be worked out with the Maralinga peoples.
Conclusions of Royal Commission

In addition to the seven recommendations that I have discussed, the Royal Commission also drew some 200 `conclusions', which are spelt out throughout the text of the report, and drawn together in volume III. The Government has taken the view that it is not really either possible or appropriate to respond to each of these statements. We have seen their essential role as being to make clear, individually and collectively, the basis upon which the Commission has made its various recommendations, rather than as being propositions to which a government response is required or would be useful. Some comment does, however, seem called for in relation to conclusion 140, which is in the following terms:
Aboriginal people continued to inhabit the Prohibited Zone for six years after the tests. When they were told to leave the Prohibited Zone, some of them perished.

When read in conjunction with paragraphs 9.3.50-52 of the report, an inference clearly emerges that Mr R. A. Macaulay, then the Native Patrol Officer, bore some personal responsibility for the deaths, by starvation or dehydration, of three Aboriginal people ordered to leave the prohibited area.

Mr Macaulay has written to me taking strong exception to this section of the report, not least because he was not given an opportunity to respond to the particular evidence on which it was based, the matter not having been raised during his own earlier evidence to the Commission. He has denied any such responsibility, and has asked that the Government `not accept' the second part of conclusion 140 as it relates to him.

As already indicated, the Government has taken the view that it is not really appropriate or necessary to either accept or reject any of the Royal Commission's conclusions on questions of fact, and a further consideration militating against any specific response here is that the matter in issue may possibly be tested in the course of future litigation. But, in fairness to Mr Macaulay, it should perhaps be said that it does appear from the available documentation bearing upon this issue-which my Department has assembled-that the Commission's report might, with the benefit of further evidence and reflection, have been expressed a good deal more cautiously. It is noteworthy in this respect that the Aboriginal groups' submission, which was clearly much utilised in the drafting of this and other sections of the report, was careful `not . . . to attribute blame' to any of the patrol or peace officers who dealt with the party of Aboriginal people in question, suggesting that `in the end result it was (a) gulf in understanding which contributed to the deaths of the three people'.

The Government is concerned that the outstanding issues raised by the Royal Commission's recommendations are resolved in an expeditious and cost-effective manner. The impetus toward achieving this objective is being maintained despite the present budgetary constraints. The studies into the nature, extent and potential hazard of the contamination at the Maralinga and Emu sites will commence as soon as possible. It is expected at this stage that a final strategy on clean-up can be developed within two years, on the basis of results obtained from the initial six studies and other inquiries which may prove necessary. Meanwhile the process of consultation with the United Kingdom, the State governments of South and Western Australia, as well as Aboriginal interests, will continue both directly and through the consultative group process. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is becoming more and more apparent from each statement made by the Government on the McClelland Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia that the Royal Commission was not only an embarrassment to the Government, particularly in relation to a number of its so-called conclusions, but also a complete waste of taxpayers' money.
—And an abuse of human justice.

—As we have heard one example from the Government, it was an abuse of individual rights. There are probably many more such examples in the conduct of the Royal Commission and in a number of its findings. I have had occasion to refer to the Royal Commission's first conclusion. Senator Gareth Evans in his response referred to conclusion 140 and let the former justice, Mr McClelland, off lightly in relation to that matter. Clearly, the Government has been totally embarrassed by what the Royal Commissioner said about Mr Macaulay, without even giving the man the opportunity to be heard. I hope that those senators opposite who interject will reflect for a moment on what the Government has said about the Royal Commission's disgraceful finding and conduct. I would like to refer, as I have done previously, to another marvellous example of the judicial character of the Royal Commission. Conclusion 1 of the Royal Commission's 200 conclusions starts with the words:

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal Commission received no evidence to disturb the overwhelming impression that the original decision to lend Australia to the United Kingdom for the purpose of the latter's nuclear tests program was taken by Australian Prime Minister Menzies without reference to his Cabinet.

To say that there was `no evidence to disturb the overwhelming impression' is an exhibition of judicial ineptitude. Presumably, that impression resided in the mind of the Royal Commissioner, without any evidence. Because no evidence was produced to disturb that Royal Commissioner's impression which, no doubt, he had gained from the strange workings of his mind and his prejudices, he found that the impression was fact. As a revelation of the Royal Commissioner's thinking process, in itself that would be enough to nullify the whole of the Royal Commission's activities. But here we have the Government identifying not only another totally unjustified finding but also a very serious finding against a public servant carrying out his duty, without even giving that person the opportunity of being heard. However, perhaps those are matters upon which we do not need to dwell. I think they need to be mentioned again and again, because no doubt we will hear from several Australian Labor Party senators and Australian Democrat senators what a terribly important finding this was by Mr Justice McClelland, and how the world should be shaken and the Government should be prompted to act upon every word that he uttered. I have no doubt that their reasoning is based on no better evidence than conclusion No. 1 of the Royal Commissioner, to which I have referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have now spoken for five minutes and you have not introduced anything into the debate yet.
—I propose to spend as long as I am entitled to spend in debating this statement and I do not want to have any of my time wasted by Senator Sanders's inane interjections.
—He does not care about human rights.
—No, of course he does not. The Democrats have only their own prejudices to work off. I bet that they will spend half an hour working off their own prejudices and wasting the time of this Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: In a sense, the Government has now made two responses to this Commission, and they are very important ones indeed. The first response was not made in the Senate. I am not complaining about that. A very important statement was issued by Senator Evans when he was in London in January last year. I notice that he is proposing to have another trip to London. I wonder how many he has had so far this year. No doubt it is very important that he should go back there and negotiate further about these matters. Senator Evans issued an important statement in London following his discussions with the United Kingdom Government. The implication of that statement all about the Royal Commission was that it was a great waste of money, and that the Government was foolish in ever setting it up. He did not admit that, but that has really been the burden of anything the Government has said and done since the report of this Royal Commission was received by it. As I have said, no doubt the Government is thoroughly embarrassed; it ought to be thoroughly embarrassed by the fact that it set up this Commission, wasted all this money and is wasting a great deal of time and effort now in having to respond to the report.

At that stage the Government said that it was going to set up a body, which is now called a technical assessment group, the membership of which has been announced and to which Senator Evans has referred in his statement. As Senator Evans said, this group will conduct major technical operations in a proper, scientific way-which the Royal Commission never did, despite the fact that it cost $4m or more. It would have been the appropriate course for the Government to have taken, instead of giving in, as it is constantly doing, to its left wing loony back bench and other elements in the community of that kind. Instead of making a proper assessment, it set up a royal commission and selected a judge, in the person of Mr Justice McClelland as he then was, who it thought would be agreeable to these pressure groups. That was the appropriate course to take, as I said in my response on behalf of the Opposition in January, and our only regret is that the Government did not see fit to take that course in the first place when it decided to do something about the matter. Whether it is justified is not for debate here, but the Government felt that it had to take some step. It now has in place the technical assessment group. It is meeting and has reported to the Minister. Will the Minister let honourable senators have a copy of the report from that group? The Estimates committee will be hearing evidence from the Department of Resources and Energy, and perhaps the Minister could take it on notice that the Opposition would like to see a copy of that report made available. It is no doubt an interesting and important report and may throw a great deal more light on the whole matter than anything done by the Royal Commission or by this Government to date.

The Fraser Government and the responsible Minister in that Government, Senator Sir John Carrick, who will speak in this debate, had a great deal to do over many years with cleaning up operations in this area and attempting to assess a number of the problems which the technical assessment group is also addressing. I was pleased that Senator Gareth Evans in his statement referred to two important steps that were taken by the Fraser Government. A register of 15,000 people was put together by the Department under Senator Sir John Carrick, followed by a epidemiological study of 8,000 of them. That is a good example of scientific efforts that were made to resolve these problems. We support initiatives the Government is now taking to obtain further scientific knowledge on this topic as a basis for decision-making and for compensation rather than by the methods adopted earlier by this Government, particularly in its foolish decision ever to set up the McClelland Royal Commission at all.

The Government has also rejected, as was announced in January and is confirmed in this statement, a proposal by the Royal Commission to set up what it called a Maralinga commission. Senator Michael Baume, chairman of the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee, is present and may take part in this debate, but there was no more foolish waste of money than to set up a royal commission, one of whose main recommendations was to set up yet another commission, namely, the Maralinga commission, to carry on and do work which should have been undertaken by the Royal Commission. The Government has sensibly rejected that recommendation. One wonders what is left of the Royal Commission's findings that is of any significance when the Government has to set up a technical assessment group to perform the work of the Commission and has rejected, for good reason, one of its major recommendations.

The Government has dealt with the recommendation about compensation for individuals and, again, that is a response with which the Opposition could certainly agree. There is a deficiency in the existing compensation law of the Commonwealth because it has applied only to those Commonwealth employees, particularly servicemen, who were on the site. However, there were other people employed on the site-they were not Commonwealth employees, but they were there and they were exposed to exactly the same dangers as Commonwealth employees-who are not covered. The Government has now decided that they should be covered, as should other people who were in the area, such as Aborigines and graziers. These people should be given the same rights as Commonwealth employees. As Senator Evans has explained in this statement, those rights will have to be exercised in accordance with the existing laws and even though there is a reverse onus of proof, they will be required to provide adequate proof that they were exposed to a radioactive substance and that that exposure has resulted in a disease.

This is an appropriate way of handling this matter. No doubt many people will say that simply because people were in the area they should be compensated for any disease from which they are now suffering. That would be a most foolish approach and would involve the quite unjustified expenditure of public money. The way the Government proposes to deal with this matter is correct and I am pleased that it will police these claims very carefully. Clearly, they must be carefully policed and, indeed, the Government says that it will make use of the full legal process to ensure that compensation is awarded only where it can be proved to be justified. I hope that the Government will stick to its guns on this response because I can well understand that it will be under great pressure from its loony left wing back bench of which I have already spoken. We have seen how the Government has been rolled in the last day or two by those elements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do I look as if I have just been rolled?

—Yes, you are rolling around there giving every sign of it. I assume that there will have to be an amendment to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act to create these rights. Legislation will need to be introduced into this Parliament.
—That will be another opportunity!

—As Senator Coleman says, that will be another opportunity for the back bench to put pressure on the Government and try to roll it. I have no doubt that that will happen. I hope that on this occasion the Government will stick to its guns and not give in to Caucus as it so readily seems to be doing on many issues at present. It has not been standing up for its own convictions.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other matter that I need mention is the negotiations with the United Kingdom. One of the recommendations of the Royal Commission was that the United Kingdom should bear all the costs of the clean-up. The Commonwealth Government has acted on that recommendation in that it has emphasised the 1956 memorandum of arrangements with the United Kingdom in relation to these tests, which stated:
The UK Government accepts liability for such corrective measures as may be practicable in the event of radioactive contamination resulting from tests on the site.

However the United Kingdom Government is not prepared to accept that after clean-ups have been carried out on two separate occasions, during the period of the Menzies Government and subsequently of the Fraser Government, and in view of a release which was signed by the Australian Government in 1967, it now has a legal responsibility in the performance of that memorandum of arrangements. The Commonwealth Government may well have great difficulty in persuading the United Kingdom Government to change its mind on that in view of those circumstances. However the United Kingdom Government, as we have already heard, is participating fully with the technical assessment group and no doubt it will be guided very much by its own and other experts on that group in determining whether there is any continuing moral, if not legal, obligation. I have no doubt that the proper procedures are in place, even though they give Senator Evans a nice excuse to have a trip to London occasionally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to see Sheikh Yamani as well. Am I allowed to do that?

—That is fine. I am not objecting to that, I am saying that that is a proper course to be taken. Only by sensible negotiations, based on scientific knowledge and facts, will we resolve these matters. They will not be resolved by the sort of grandstanding which so many people have indulged in over this matter. I refer not only to the back bench of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats-and no doubt we will see an example of that shortly from Senator Sanders-but also many other people. This matter will not be resolved by a lot of emotive grandstanding; it will be resolved only by proper scientific assessment and rational negotiations between governments. I am pleased that at long last the Federal Government has seen that this is the appropriate approach to these matters, and has not followed the course recommended by its royal commissioner. The only serious criticism which can be made of the Government over this matter is that it ever set up the Royal Commission in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Government response to the recommendations of the McClelland Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia in the 1950s and 1960s. Let me say at the outset that it is very important that there should be the fullest exposure of the facts concerning those tests. Wherever it is possible that radioactivity associated with atomic tests or the use of radioactive materials may impinge upon human health, there should be the fullest exposure of facts.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise because I have had responsibility in this matter. I say this so that what I say now can be judged and any subjective judgments of mine can be taken into account. I was the responsible Minister in the Fraser Government from 1979 to 1983. As such, I took a number of actions in this regard. In the whole of that time I gave instruction to my own department-which is now the Department of Resources and Energy and the responsibility of the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans-and through that department, with full Cabinet authority, to all departments, including the Department of Health-the Minister will know this-to the effect that there must be the fullest exposure of facts; that we must seek out every individual alive and the records of every individual now dead in order to determine what happened at Maralinga, Emu and the Monte Bellos; and that we should offer to every individual whom we locate a full health check and the fullest facilities for examination for compensation before the Commissioner for Employees Compensation. To my knowledge no attempt has been made by any government or any department that is as thorough as this.

The Minister in his statement refers to the fact that some 15,300 names were procured. Let me examine what, in fact, happened. Every record that is now held by the Department of Defence of every person who had been associated with those tests and was on record was obtained. The records that were obtained showed not only the names, the ages and the then addresses of those people, but also their full health records, as known then, the areas that they were in in these testing areas and the dosimeters, the recording which showed the radioactivity to which each person was exposed.

There was a massive two-year search in Australia through all the records that there could possibly be-through the Australian Electoral Office and every other place-to see whether we could locate these people. From memory some 8,200 people were located alive and were actually contactable and there were some 1,200 to 1,300 death certificates. Every person who was alive was written to and given a very comprehensive questionnaire. Each person was told what we were seeking and was asked to give information. These people were invited to come forward, they were invited to have a health test and they were invited to go before the compensation commission. Indeed, they were pursued again and again. If the questionnaire came in and did not look as if it had been fully filled in they were contacted again. The aim was not to leave one person unaccounted for who might give us some kind of useful evidence. That was done. The death certificates were obtained and the primary and secondary causes of death were examined in an epidemiological study by experts to see whether there were any signs of neoplasms, of carcinogenic disease that could have been caused by radiation.

We then proceeded. We advertised in the Press as to what we were doing. We got in touch with all the veterans' organisations, those that were the nuclear veterans' organisations, and we urged them to contact people and to have them come forward. As a result, the report became available and is available to all. Although I would not have hesitated to expose any direct association, I was happy with the consequence which exposed the fact that there was no proof at all of any radioactive influence upon the health, the morbidity or the mortality or the individuals concerned. That report is available for all honourable senators and for the community to observe. But we went further. We encouraged people to have health checks and to go before the compensation commission. In that time we attempted to clean up Maralinga.

I do not want to make a political issue of this matter, since it has been made an issue by the Royal Commission. Because the Royal Commission in itself was disastrous, I must say a number of things. I would have welcomed a thoroughly objective commission which was non-political in its basis. In the three years of the Whitlam Government I would have welcomed any attempt whatsoever by the Government to have undertaken a survey and to have shown the slightest concern at all about individuals who had been at Maralinga, Emu or Monte Bello. I would have welcomed a study of Maralinga by a royal commission. Nothing was done. We attempted to find the facts.

The simple situation is that the Minister ought to have reported the results of these tests after the tremendous appeal to the Australian people to come forward. The fact is that a relative handful of people, approximately 100 or 200, have come before the compensation commission. We will get this in the Estimates committees. When we analyse it, the number of cases that could be shown, with the reverse onus of proof, to have some connection, were small. When I last heard, there were some five cases before common law. They have, no doubt, been delayed as a result of the Royal Commission. No doubt the Minister's speech will be carefully examined today by their lawyers. Indeed, a number of paragraphs relating to neoplasms and their incidence in this community will be of great interest in these cases.

As yet, no case has come before common law which has been fully tested. There are cases before common law. Indeed, there is one case of a man claiming agoraphobia, a fear of open spaces. This was because he had allegedly seen an atom bomb go off. The common law has always been available. It is true to say that it is an expensive way of doing things. Therefore, I welcome the fact that the Commonwealth Compensation Commission has been broadened to allow people, other than those who can have access to it now, to come before it. I welcome that and support it fully. The common law has been available and no case has, as yet, been sustained. A number of cases have been before the courts for five, six and seven years and have not yet been proven. That is the background.

I am delighted that there should be debate and exposure in Australia on this subject. I have urged that a detailed report should come before this Parliament on the Chernobyl situation. We should be urging the International Atomic Energy Agency to become not just the inspector of atomic weapons around the world-it should be aware of their danger-but it should also be an inspector of the safety factors of reactors. Chernobyl has shown us the importance of the fact that there can be no nuclear free zones in the world, that radiation runs across all boundaries and that there can be no limited wars. Those who advocate nuclear free zones without advocating a world completely nuclear free are peddling propaganda which they know to be false.

TALK.START.PARA: —Reagan is the one who wants nuclear war.

—Senator Sanders is a classic example of that. Those who talk this emotive stuff should understand that they are doing great damage to the community. On the subject of radioactivity we need to tell the facts as they are, neither by exaggeration nor by diminution. That is the purpose of my rising to speak today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal Commission sought no basic technical evidence. It had nothing substantial before it except the health report that my Government had instituted. It did no tests at all of the ground. Here was a chance for it to do tests of the flora and fauna of the area and it did none. The area itself-I have been all over it-teems with rabbits, hares, dingoes, lizards and snakes, every kind of living fauna that one would find in a desert area. They are all ground foragers and ground eaters, all close to the radioactive particulates that are there and not a test has been done. One wonders how a royal commission could set itself up to decide the dangers in this situation. It did not find this out when it had, for instance, on Monte Bello Island an ecological cycle of sea turtles and all the creatures that feed on turtle eggs. The Government could have done a complete test.

I have raised this matter in the Senate a number of times. I asked the Minister to ask the Royal Commission to do these tests. I asked the Minister repeatedly at the Estimates Committee because I could not believe that a royal commission would set itself up to inveigh in the end against radiation and not be able to say: `I have tested the flora and I have tested the fauna and I have found this or that'. Not one bit. It did not know. It did not even scientifically test the area at all. It simply relied on anecdotal evidence. It then came to making a series of assumptions which it hoped, by the force of repetition of prejudice, would become accepted. This is the sad fact, to which I ask the Minister to pay attention, because I want to support so much of what has been done here and the Minister knows that I have tried to be bipartisan in this. I ask the Minister not to carry on, because there is no factual basis for it, with the statement that the black mist not only existed but also was radioactive in causation and did radioactive damage. I put to the Minister that there is no factual evidence at all, only anecdotal evidence on this. I commend the Minister as to much of the journey on this. I believe we ought to be as bipartisan as possible.

The fact of the matter is that this black mist has never been tested. There is no evidence except anecdotal evidence on this, yet we are here making decisions on these situations. The Royal Commission made no scientific tests and sought none. The Minister knows that there is some anecdotal evidence-if it were proven, I would acknowledge it-that some Aborigines may have suffered. For example, one person-Yami Lester, a fine person who is well known in the Aboriginal community-is now alleged to have suffered blindness from the black mist. But the records preceding that are full of the fact that ophthalmologists and others, including relatives, have said that Yami Lester's blindness was caused by measles. To simply get an anecdotal statement is to do great damage. If indeed harm was done to the Aborigines, let us expose it.

The interesting thing is that the Royal Commission, which now advocates a register, did not seek to forage out all those people or their relatives who were there to get their evidence, yet it has made a finding without any factual evidence at all. I plead with the Minister that the Government should not build upon a prejudice or, at the very least, an unproven statement. There is no scientific proof of the black mist. The Minister will know that AIRAC-the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council, which is the standing body of scientists-has said that there is no such proof. I know that there is controversy on these statements, but no proof of them exists at all. Indeed, there are reports before the Government and the Senate pointing that out. In my judgment it is an outrage for a Royal Commission to use phrases that are emotive and melodramatic when it was set up to find the facts. I plead with the Minister on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just because you do not agree with the facts does not mean you have to become emotive.

—Senator Sanders should not talk to me about facts. The one factual test that has been done is checking every one of the 15,300 people. I am not rising to speak in tones of anecdote or the emotional melodrama that Senator Sanders employs; I am speaking from the force of the greatest examination of individuals that has ever been done in terms of radioactivity. Let the Australian Democrats get up and counter that if they want to. The fact is that we set out to try to get every detail we could and we pleaded with people to come forward. Where has that ever been the case before? If the Minister says that I am not right-that the black mist is not anecdotal-let him bring before us a statement. I invite the Minister to do that because tomorrow I will ask the same question at the Estimates Committee. Let him bring before us a statement of the scientific proof, firstly, that the black mist was caused by atomic explosions; secondly, that it was not just a dust storm; thirdly, that it was radioactive; and, fourthly, that it in fact caused human damage. I would not hide from the fact if it can be proven. If damage was done to Aborigines, let us have the proof. But let us not have people racing around the place making certain statements when they know that there is documentary medical evidence that there were epidemics of both ordinary measles and German measles-rubella-over that period and the deaths of a considerable number of Aborigines were caused by measles. Those people know also that evidence was given before the Royal Commission by an ophthalmologist that Yami Lester had been reported by himself and others in the past as having his blindness caused by measles.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the next situation. Here is a situation in which the Minister has come before this Parliament and picked out seven recommendations. He said at the end, in rather a coy way, that there are 200 others but that they are not really recommendations at all, and therefore the Government supports just these seven. The interesting thing is that the Minister has picked four to deal with and king hit two of them straightaway. This Royal Commission was set up by this Government under pressure from its left wing. The first recommendation that the Minister king hit was in relation to the national register. He said: `After all, there is a first class one at the moment'. He did not add that it was created by the previous Fraser Government, with full medical knowledge. He also king hit the idea that there should be a Maralinga commission. That does not leave much of what has come before us today. Recommendation 1, the third of the four recommendations, simply takes the principle of the health study, the principle of using the Commonwealth employees compensation commission, and extends it to those who are outside it. I could not commend a recommendation more; it is a very sensible recommendation and it ought to be done.

Another interesting thing ought to be revealed. I invite the Minister to produce the figures tomorrow at the Estimates Committee so that we will understand what might be the anticipated impact of this. One should understand what was the impact of questioning the 15,000 survivors who were eligible to come before the Royal Commission, how many people are there otherwise, and what kind of an impact are we likely to find? There is no earthly reason to believe that there is any greater danger of mortality or morbidity in the people who were outside the Commonwealth compensation sphere than those who were inside it. I can only hope, for the sake of themselves and their families, that that is so.

As to compensation, if there is a basis for compensation, let us go ahead; so I do not argue on that at all. What I say, as Senator Durack said before me, is that we made agreements over the years with the British in terms of the clean-up of Maralinga. It was competent for the Whitlam Government in its three years of office from 1973 to 1975, if it had felt it necessary from its surveys of Maralinga following the agreement a few years before, to reopen the situation and to say to the British Government: `Let us have another think on this'. It is fundamental to our understanding to appreciate that the Whitlam Government did not even raise a whimper on this situation; it did nothing at all. It knew of the agreement and it had full responsibility for all these sites, but it did nothing at all to challenge the situation. In fact, it approved of that. I can only say now that the common sense of this situation should be not to look to the McClelland Royal Commission in its recommendation that we should try to force the United Kingdom Government to pay the costs, but to come to some kind of working understanding which is sensible, bearing in mind that this is no new-found thing. In the past 15 years Labor governments have had the capacity over six or seven years to do these kinds of things. When one looks at this matter, one comes to a particular conclusion.

What a pity it is that, if a royal commission had to be set up-I do not argue against that-it was not set up with specific personnel and specific terms of reference to get facts and not politics. What a pity it is that that Royal Commission was not given the responsibility to get scientific and demographic information and to test flora and fauna. What a pity it is that we have had this huge expenditure on a commission that in the end, by this very report that is before us today, the Government virtually rejects. That is the truth of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.
—Well, let us have the Minister say this. He has had today to write off some 200 recommendations as trivia. That is what he casts off.
—What nonsense; they are findings of fact.
—Let us have a look at the nonsense. The facts are very simple indeed.
—Do not trivialise this debate.
—Let the Minister run away from his statements. I am holding them in front of me. I read:

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the seven recommendations discussed above, the Royal Commission also drew some 200 `conclusions', which are spelt out throughout the text . . .
He then goes on to say:
The Government has taken the view that it is not really either possible or appropriate to respond to each of these statements.
We do not know why. The Minister goes on to say:
We have seen their essential role as being to make clear, individually and collectively, the basis . . .

But he goes very carefully as soon as he comes to Mr Macaulay and picks him, because Mr Macaulay himself gets right to the sheer indictment of that Commission-that that Commission was not intended to be a judicial commission at all; it was to be a commission that would in fact put out political melodrama. No person could suffer more before a quasi-judicial body than the Mr Macaulays of this world. What a terrible criticism it is of the Royal Commission and a former judge that it is now said:
Mr Macaulay has written to me taking strong exception to this section of the report, not least because he was not given an opportunity to respond to the parti- cular evidence on which it was based.

Can anyone really justify a royal commission in which we have this kind of kangaroo court situation? Let me just summarise this matter. There were tests in the 1950s and the 1960s in Australia. It has been imperative that we should find the facts. It is important that we distinguish between fruity melodrama and absolute facts. It is absolutely important that we hide nothing at all. It is vitally important that every person, or the family of every person, who has ever been inside that area has not only health tests made available but also compensation if compensation is possible. It is vital that we know what has been happening in Maralinga, Emu and the Monte Bello Islands in the recent past. It is vital to test the flora and fauna. But the Royal Commission did not do that. This technical group-whose report we are seeking from the Minister and which I hope he will let us have tomorrow-is now to set to work so that we can get information. Why did we have a royal commission if this is so? This is a most extraordinary situation indeed.

The facts of the matter are perfectly clear. Everybody knows that recommendations such as signposting areas on the Monte Bello Islands still not suited for permanent habitation and collecting small debris are not ones for the future; they are for the government of the day to deal with. My Government in the past dealt with the sealing of pits, with fencing, with bulldozing areas and with putting up signposts. Anyone who knows the area will know that fundamentally this is a continuing job and that with particulate plutonium in small amounts caught up in the dunes around the place, with wind drift and with the various flora capturing these particulates, the scene changes continuously. Therefore, that recommendation is a matter for the government of the day to deal with continuously.

As I said at the start, I want to commend the Government for its decisions on extending compensation and on other matters, particularly in the rejection of the fundamental recommendations of the Royal Commission. I want to press with the Government that the Senate should have before it as soon as possible all scientific and factual reports regarding the nature of flora and fauna, the dispersal of radioactive material and the steps that the Government is taking at this moment to check the fencing, the concrete caps of the areas and what is known as the cemetery at the airfield at Maralinga. Let us have this kind of information day by day as it comes out. Above all, let us have in this Parliament, as with Chernobyl and as with the whole argument on nuclear matters, the facts day by day.

For my part, the Opposition here stands firmly against the whole future use of nuclear weapons of any kind. We stand for total nuclear disarmament, for a nuclear free world. We reject the nonsense that the propagandists put out about nuclear free zones. There can be only one nuclear free zone; that is a total world. We know that we cannot have limited wars, because Chernobyl has shown that radioactivity is no respecter of national boundaries. So we are vitally interested, both as a coalition and as people, in human survival and in the total removal from this world of nuclear weapons. In the discussion on this whole matter of Maralinga, Emu and the Monte Bellos we are dealing with the fundamentals of radioactivity. I make a personal plea. Let us have facts, not fiction. Let us have truth and scientific values, not melodrama, and for Lord's sake, never again give in to the Left and put up a royal commission purely for propaganda purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have listened to two very long speeches from the Opposition parties. Senator Durack indulged in the usual party hyperbole. It took him five minutes to get off the mark. He did not have his facts. Senator Sir John Carrick has made a plea for facts. Senator Durack obviously did not have any; he had not done his homework. But from his statements I did learn that he did not like the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia between 1952 and 1963. I think that this was made abundantly clear. He said it was foolish to set it up at all. He furthermore stated that people should not be compensated, simply because they were in the area, for any disease they might have. I disagree with that totally. I think that people who were in that area should be compensated for any disease that they might have because it might be even remotely related to the nuclear testing. The fact remains-and it is a fact-that the British were criminally negligent in those tests. It has been brought out over and over again that they took no account of the consequences of their action. I think that since they were criminally negligent they should be prepared, or should be forced, to pay. They were completely arrogant. Senator Sir John Carrick gave a more cogent speech and presentation. He too protected the British; he protected nuclear bombs.
—I protected neither nuclear bombs nor--

—He protected nuclear bombs; he protected nuclear energy; he protected nuclear reactors. He made the statement that Chernobyl has proven that there can be no nuclear free zones on earth if we have nuclear reactors-and that is an absolutely correct statement. What follows from this is that we must eliminate nuclear reactors, which is what those in the so-called loony Left, which the Opposition loves to allude to, have been saying all along. There can be no permanent peace on this earth if we have nuclear bombs-which the British were testing-and nuclear reactors.

SPEECH.PARA: To his credit, Senator Sir John Carrick, unlike Senator Durack, at least recognised the need for the compensation of victims. He pointed out that he had done quite a bit of study in this area and I commend him for this. But I cannot agree with much of anything else that he said. One thing that he noted, which I think we all should note, is that when one has any association with nuclear ionising radiation, one must continue to monitor this for years and years. He said that it is a continuing job for the government of the day to monitor the results of these nuclear tests. That is so. It is a recognition of the long term damage of anything connected with the nuclear fuel cycle. It is something that we must be made aware of over and again. We are not just thinking of ourselves but of our children, our children's children and of some 250,000 years hence in the case of some material.

I have often been sceptical of royal commissions. They are often set up to give the appearance that something is happening without anything happening. But this Royal Commission was an exception. It brought out a number of things. The most important was that it indicated the full horrors of what can happen after a nuclear war. Certainly what happened was on only a small scale in that it involved bomb tests; they were not full scale bombs or large bombs by today's standards and nor were they exploded in a city or populated area. But this shows what can happen if we unleash the power in the atom in nuclear war.
Specifically, the first recommendation of the Royal Commission is to:

extend the benefits of Commonwealth Government employees compensation legislation, including reverse onus of proof, to civilians at the sites, and to Aborigines and other civilians who may have been exposed to black mist.

I must say that we have to accept this as anecdotal evidence because we cannot measure it. But simply because we cannot measure it does not mean that it did not exist. If we were to follow Senator Sir John Carrick's argument to its ultimate conclusion, we would have to set off a whole series of tests to see whether they produced black mist and caused blindness and death in the people around. That is utter foolishness. It is like Edward Teller saying that we cannot believe that there will be a nuclear winter as we have to prove it first. How does one prove it? Does one destroy the world in proving these things? On the contrary; we have to take the evidence that exists. There is enough evidence of that black mist to accept it. As was recommended by the Royal Commission, and as the Government states at page 3:

The net result of these provisions, in the present context, is that if a claimant can establish that he or she has a disease in fact caused by a radioactive substance, and that he or she suffered exposure to a radioactive substance as a result of being employed or otherwise present at or near the atomic test sites, that exposure will be `deemed to have contributed' to that disease-unless the Commonwealth can establish the contrary.
We have reversed the onus of proof, as it should be reversed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been reversed for the last 10 years. It was reversed during the time of the Fraser Government.

—Fine; that is a wonderful thing. We should extend the reversal of the onus of proof into a number of other areas. Often we find that a citizen who has been affected by some action by a polluter or by a government has to establish that he or she has been affected; the burden of proof is on the person who has been affected. It should be for the other side to prove that it has not caused damage to a citizen.

SPEECH.PARA: Another thing that this Royal Commission and the Government's response to it raises-this is an important issue-is class action. This basically sets up a class of people who can take action. Class actions are a very valuable tool in modern society for getting compensation or redress for people who have been affected by some action not of their making. A mechanism for class actions should be established in Australia. Another issue is that of standing to sue. This does give standing to sue a limited sense. I would like to see in Australia a more broadened standing to sue issue.

On page 5 the Government states that there is data available. It has been collected. It states that the second list, compiled by the Australian Radiation Laboratory, is based on a United Kingdom `medical-in-confidence' listing of radiation exposures. I do not know whether this is considered to be the blue book; nobody is saying that it is not the blue book. If it is the blue book, and if it is to be made available to those people who have been affected by the nuclear testing, that is a good thing. In the past, the blue book, that is, the medical evidence of the dosi-meters that were on the people at the test sites, has not been made available to those individuals who were affected. The Government response states:

Arrangements can readily be made, building on existing practice, to ensure that compensation claimants and the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation can get access to all relevant material in the Commonwealth's possession.
It also states:

As a result of extensive searches of Commonwealth files made during the course of the Royal Commission's inquiry, my Department now holds a substantial body of information. It can and will provide such information, relevant to a person's presence or activities during the tests, to that person on request.
If this is the blue book information, and it is to be made available to veterans and others involved, this is a great step forward.

The whole issue of atomic testing at Mara-linga and in the other areas is an example of hubris, that is, excessive arrogance or pride. We heard much of this during the Nixon regime, during the Watergate affair, when Nixon thought he was above the people and everything and everyone in the world because he was President of the United States of America. We find that our present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, is also exhibiting signs of hubris. Certainly those scientists who put together those atomic tests in the first place were completely arrogant. They completely disregarded anything except their desire to test weapons. In passing, I note that these are the same people who developed the antique reactor at Lucas Heights. Those same people with those same attitudes developed our very ancient reactor at Lucas Heights. That reactor is about 25 years old and as such should be retired along with the attitudes of the people who built it.

I will not delay the Senate. I will not speak for 30 minutes as previous speakers have done. I will close by saying that this Royal Commission has pointed out once again that nuclear power in the form of bombs, and nuclear energy in the form of power plants, simply cannot be tolerated on this earth. As Senator Sir John Carrick has pointed out, there can be no nuclear free zones if we have exploding reactors or exploding bombs. That is an indication that we must eliminate all aspects of the nuclear fuel cycle. In specific terms, in the case of the Monte Bello and other tests, the Government should press ahead and ensure that the Poms live up to their responsibilities towards those who were affected in these tests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is most important to comment on in this debate on the Government's response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia between 1952 and 1963 is what is missing from the statement by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). Things which should be included are completely missing. Firstly, completely lacking from the Minister's statement is any comment of regret that the land and people of Australia suffered from that Bri-tish nuclear testing program. Completely lacking from the statement is any sentiment of sympathy for the people who, 30 years on, are still suffering. Completely lacking from the statement is any expression of sympathy to the families of victims who have died as a result of their involvement at the sites. Also completely lacking is any expression of concern about the ongoing environmental damage caused by those tests. Completely lacking is any political comment about the loss of Australian sovereignty when Menzies, without reference to Cabinet, let alone the Parliament or the Australian people, lent Australia to the British for that very damaging testing program. All of those exclusions, all of those things unsaid, reflect the Government's lack of moral concern about many issues facing Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: How can a Government Minister respond to the McClelland Royal Commission, which did take into account moral considerations without mentioning the sad fact that Aboriginal people and their land suffered greatly from the testing program, without expressing any regret at the injustices wrought upon the Aboriginal people, as well as people working on the land, technicians and members of British and Australian services? It is also a great shame that the Government has not made any statement of intent to ensure that Australia would not in future allow itself to be used in that way. Of course it is in an embarrassing position, because successive Australian governments, including the present one, continue to allow Australian sovereignty to be impaired by a country imposing nuclear dangers on Australia. That historical aspect should not be overlooked.

In the 1950s an Australian government allowed another country to use Australian soil and back-up services to further its nuclear weapons program. Ever since then, Australian governments have invited nuclear involvement in this country by way of American bases on Australian soil which implicate us in United States nuclear war fighting strategies and which severely hamper Australian sovereignty. That involvement is also obvious as a result of the use of Darwin for the landing of B52 bombers armed with nuclear weapons. That involvement in assisting another country's nuclear war fighting strategies is also evidenced by the frequent visits of nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered warships to various Australian ports, which pose enormous environmental dangers to the people who live in those ports. Right now, there are warships visiting Australian ports in both Western Australia and Queensland. The same kinds of nuclear dangers are conti-nually invited. Australian people are continually put at risk, yet our Government involves us willy-nilly in such nuclear arrangements.

The Royal Australian Navy is preparing for its 75th birthday party. I would gladly give my support to the RAN's celebration of that commemoration, except for the fact that the Navy has been silly enough to invite nuclear weapons-capable ships into a number of Australian ports. Many Australians are opposed to that. We object on principle, because we believe that Australia should not be further involved in any nuclear strategies of any nation. Nuclear wea-pons are evil and the threat to use them is evil.

Our objection is a basic moral objection to Australia's continual involvement in the insanity of the nuclear arms race. That involvement began with the British nuclear testing program. It continues, 30 years on, with our grovelling subservience to the United States in the ANZUS alliance which, in its origins, was never intended to be a nuclear alliance.

The Government is to be commended for commissioning the inquiry. If it were left to the Opposition, these important questions would never have been asked. The Opposition says that it is a waste of time and money even to bother with the leftovers of the testing program. Is it deaf to the tragic stories of people who have suffered? Maybe the Opposition has not heard the stories. However, I have received many letters from victims pouring out their sad stories. Financial compensation will never wipe away the suffering that those people have endured, but at least it is recognition that they have suffered. Much more than that, compensation claims should serve to remind Australian governments of any political persuasion, and the Australian community, that we should not invite future claims for nuclear-related damages by continuing to put Australians at risk, as the present Government is doing.

Obviously there was a need to seek facts about the leftovers of the testing program. Looking at the specifics of the Minister's statement, many questions remain. They relate mainly to the delicate question of who pays for the clean-up and who pays for the compensation. I believe that the British Government should take a great deal of the responsibility, despite the release from responsibility signed by the Australian Government in 1968 absolving the British Government after its abysmally inadequate clean-up in 1967. It is clear to many Australians that the British were grossly irresponsible in their use of Australian land and people in their testing program, and of their own servicemen in the process. The fact that such a release from responsibility was signed is not only greatly regrettable but also another indication of successive Australian governments deferring to foreign governments with little regard for Australian sovereignty. I am sure that the Minister will work as hard as possible to make the British Government pay for further clean-up and compensation but if the British Government will not do so, the Australian Government must. The work cannot be left undone.

Amounts so far set aside are inadequate. At page 9 of the Minister's statement, under recommendation 3, which relates to the clean-up of Maralinga and Emu and the funding of the technical assessment group to enable it to make its findings, an amount of $3.4m over two years is cited as being necessary. However, in the recent Budget an amount of $1m has been set aside to cover the Australian contribution in that two-year period. The Government is seeking a 50 per cent contribution from the United Kingdom Government. If that money is not forthcoming-I hope that it will be, although I have many doubts-the Australian Government must undertake that responsibility, despite the economic constraints that bedevil the Government at the moment.

We cannot allow the clean-ups to be deferred any longer. As the Minister's statement said, an enormous amount of work needs to be done, especially in the Maralinga and Emu areas. A distribution of 22 kilograms of plutonium continues to contaminate those areas. The Aboriginal people who want to move back to those areas have waited long enough. They have waited for 30 years for clean-ups to be conducted in their areas. I do not think that any clean-up program will be totally adequate, because it is difficult to make sure that every bit of radioactive contamination is scraped up and disposed of. As we know only too well, no adequate disposal for radioactive contamination is available to humanity.

Recommendation 7 concerns compensation to Aboriginal traditional owners. That subject is glossed over in two paragraphs, with an amount of $500,000 provided in this year's Budget. That is totally inadequate, and a further insult to Aboriginal people who have been the main victims of the testing program.

I agree with the Opposition that it is regrettable that the Government takes the line that, with 200 conclusions-apart from the seven major recommendations of the report-it is not possible or appropriate to respond to each statement. Each statement should be responded to in detail by the Government. They were made with a great deal of valuable searching which needs to be continued now by the technical assessment group.

It is to be hoped that future governments will never allow Australia to be used again in such a way. I believe that any future government that did so would bring down the wrath of the Australian people-that is, if they knew about it in advance. The problem with all things nuclear in this country is that often we do not know in advance what various governments have planned for us. The secrecy of the nuclear industry world wide is regrettable and it causes many problems to future generations.

We must be eternally vigilant to ensure that such a problem does not occur again. More importantly, future Australian governments should reclaim Australian sovereignty. We are still being used in similar ways. Although we are not being used for a testing program, we are being used in more diabolical ways by the United States, a nuclear super-power, by way of its bases, its warships and its B52 bombers landing in Darwin. We are still being used. That is my main point in commenting on the report.

It is high time that Australian governments reclaimed Australian sovereignty and listened to an increasing number of Australians who are very concerned about our involvement in the nuclear arms race, as expressed by way of the alliance treaty with the United States but not as written down on paper. The ANZUS Treaty of 1951 does not commit us to hosting American bases on Australian soil. It does not commit us to allowing B52 bombers to land in Darwin. It does not commit us to hosting the visits of nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered warships. The treaty was not intended to be a nuclear alliance. That is what has sprung up in secret over the years, at the invitation of a successive number of Australian governments. That is a totally reprehensible situation. I believe that Australian governments would do well to listen to the increasing number of Australians who are calling for an independent and nuclear free Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented, Mr President, by Senator Vallentine during her reading of her statement to the Senate. Senator Vallentine was in the Senate when I was speaking earlier today and she either was simply not listening or deliberately misrepresented what I said.
—The statement was probably written before.

—I suppose that it was but I would have thought that, having listened to what I said, Senator Vallentine would have altered it. She said that the Opposition did not care about the situation at Maralinga and that it was happy to leave the position as it stood. That was a totally false statement and one totally at variance with what was said by me and by Senator Sir John Carrick who followed me. We have supported the Government's decisions to set up a technical assessment group to assess the position and obtain scientific facts. We know that Senator Vallentine is not interested in scientific facts. The technical assessment group will assess the facts. Decisions will then be made. We certainly support that approach. On the basis of the information obtained, a further clean-up may well be required and may well be very costly.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not at any stage criticised that approach. On the day in January this year when that course of action was announced by Senator Gareth Evans, I issued a statement on behalf of the Opposition supporting it. I want to nail completely Senator Vallentine's false assertion that we do not care about the position at Maralinga. Senator Sir John Carrick in his speech made perfectly clear the efforts that he had taken in relation to this problem when he was a Minister in the Fraser Government. This emphasises the concern that we felt then, that we now feel and that we will continue to feel for the proper cleaning up of this operation. The statement which Senator Vallentine read to the Senate-I hesitate to call it a speech-was a total misrepresentation of the Opposition's position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak on the Government's response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia. When one hears the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) and reads the report, one can only feel once again the concerns and fears expressed in the Senate on 13 March 1986 when we spoke briefly about the Royal Commission's report and the technical assessment group. Since then, we have come a long way. We now have the Government's response. The Opposition's case has been put forward by the shadow Minister, Senator Durack, and by Senator Sir John Carrick. The Senate should be reminded that Senator Sir John Carrick was a Minister in the Fraser Government at the time of the investigation. I think that everyone must agree that his grasp of the matter should be acknowledged. Senator Sir John Carrick made a fine speech, giving the facts to support his references.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter of great concern. I have some sympathy with Senator Gareth Evans who, in introducing the subject, said:
Some of these recommendations raise complex policy issues, some involve delicate intergovernmental negotiations, some cannot be finally addressed without extensive further technical research.

He went on. Obviously, Senator Gareth Evans is in a difficult position as well. One of the first points which must be noted is that the Federal Government has accepted as fact the existence of the black mist, in spite of a good deal of controversy which persists as to the existence of that phenomenon. The Royal Commission made seven recommendations. Recommendation 2 calls for the compilation of a national registrar of nuclear veterans, Aborigines and other persons who may have been exposed to the black mist or exposed to radiation at the tests. Senator Gareth Evans said:

The Government, nonetheless, is conscious of the importance of the matters dealt with in the Royal Commission report-especially for the Aboriginal traditional owners and those claiming to have suffered illness or injury as a consequence of the United Kingdom tests.

That was a reference to the black mist. Obviously the Government has now accepted that. Evidence on the black mist was gathered from a small number of people. It is worth while noting that the British Government's position is that it has received no hard evidence to convince it of the existence of this phenomenon and, if it did exist, no evidence to link it with the testing carried out at Maralinga. Senator Sanders is always interrupting. Perhaps it would be a good idea if he, too, looked at this rather dubious report which was brought out by the McClelland Royal Commission.

The Government, in its response to the Royal Commission's first recommendation-that compensation legislation be extended to cover those who may have been exposed to the black mist-has accepted that recommendation. That is in spite of the controversy surrounding the very question of the existence of the mist. The evidence given to the Royal Commission came from a very narrow area and I will have a little more to say about that later. One can foresee some difficulty in determining who have been exposed to this phenomenon and what the results of this exposure have been.

I was interested to see that the Federal Government has rejected the Royal Commission's second recommendation that a national register of those exposed to the so-called black mist be compiled. The Government had decided that it would be virtually impossible to produce such a list-that could be because no one has ever been exposed to any such thing-and so there is not a single person who could be placed on such a list. Once again, I ask the Senate to take note of what Senator Sir John Carrick said when he was a Minister in the Fraser Government. His endeavours to bring about a list of the people involved were considerable. Assuming that there are people who have been exposed to the black mist, surely it would be beneficial to commence, even at this late stage, the compilation of data which could produce a clearer picture of what has occurred and its effects.

This is a serious matter. At this stage, the Government has evidently decided to accept the recommendation, which was based on little evidence, despite the fact that there is no concrete evidence that black mist was associated with the Maralinga blast. I ask the Government not to accept out of hand the conclusion that black mist did exist, because, as I have said, a narrow area of evidence was involved. I believe in the necessity for an accurate assessment of the whole matter. I believe that it should be further investigated.
