Perhaps two organisations could be given that responsibility-the technical assessment group and the consultative group. Whatever the Government decides to do, I believe that, before it takes any further steps, it must ensure that there is adequate evidence to support the view that black mist existed.

When one looks at the report of the McClelland Royal Commission, one can see what an amazing report it is. It contains some of the most unusual statements made by Mr Justice McClelland as Chairman of the Royal Commission. One must have doubts about whether black mist exists. Let me give an example of how Mr Justice McClelland's thinking was coloured. On 13 March 1986 during the debate in the Senate on British nuclear tests in Australia, I quoted from a letter written by Senator Sir John Carrick. Senator Sir John Carrick said then:
A stark insight into the subjective mental processes of the commission's chairman is revealed by this statement.
Mr Justice McClelland's statement was:
I used to see her (Mrs Thatcher, the British Prime Minister) on those cold winter nights looking at British television and formed such a loathing for her that it got out of control.

That statement was made by Mr Justice McClelland of the Royal Commission, a judge of Australia, yet he is supposed to have brought a stable, balanced report to the nation. The judge indicated some of his feelings. He said that he had such a loathing for the British Prime Minister that it got out of control. But, of course, she is not the only person who has been attacked by the judge. There are very many more. Senator Gareth Evans should listen to what Mr Macaulay has to say. He, as an individual in Australia, has been libelled and labelled by this Royal Commission without even being given the opportunity to come before it and answer the charges that have been made against him. I commend Senator Gareth Evans for indicating that this aspect of Mr Justice McClelland's report should be handled with caution.

I cannot say that I am surprised by the third and sixth recommendations of the Commission, which are for a clean-up of Maralinga and Emu, the cost to be borne by the British Government. One has only to look at the colour of the report to see that there is, perhaps, a little instability and lack of balance here. I noted in an article in Quadrant dated March 1986 by one of my colleagues in another place, Alexander Downer, and entitled `McClelland Royal Commission' a quotation from a former Federal Labor parliamentarian that a government should never set up a royal commission unless it is certain of the outcome. That is a rather unusual statement for a senior Labor person to make. I invite those honourable senators who are interested in the subject to read that excellent article in Quadrant. I cannot help feeling that the Government, in setting up this Royal Commission, has heeded the advice alluded to in the article.

The Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice McClelland, has demonstrated that he held strong views concerning this matter and had drawn conclusions adverse to the British Government even prior to hearing the evidence. He is on record as referring to the mess which exists in central Australia and describing the tests as `awful mistakes' prior to hearing the evidence as to whether a mess existed at all. As I have said, it is an incredible report. Other choice comments of McClelland include his reference to former Prime Minister Robert Menzies, who was Prime Minister at the time of the tests, as `lickspittle of the British'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all reality. That is factual. It is a commonly held view in the community.

—I would like to see those interjections reported in Hansard. As to the British themselves, the Royal Commissioner made no secret of his antagonism towards them. Recommendations 3 and 6 of the Royal Commission reflects the Commissioner's desire to get his pound of flesh. I suppose that it should not come as too much of a surprise then, to see that the Federal Government is taking advantage of these recommendations. Given that the cost of the clean-up is estimated to be between $100m and $200m, the Minister's comment that the resolution of this recommendation and recommendation 6-that the cost be borne by the British-will involve delicate intergovernmental negotiations is putting it rather lightly.

SPEECH.PARA: It is incredible that the Federal Government, as the Minister has stated today, is not even prepared to state its position with regard to accepting as fact the findings of the Royal Commission yet is clearly prepared to ask the British Government to foot the bill for a clean-up. Our Government is prepared to accept that the black mist occurred, as I have said once again, on the basis of highly controversial evidence and it is paying additional moneys to Aboriginal people-call it compensation or whatever-in some sort of attempt to pay something to somebody, or perhaps to anybody at all.

The McClelland Royal Commission surely has been wasteful of public money. It has not produced any scientific evidence which would justify its recommendations. I think this has been adequately put to the Senate by Senator Sir John Carrick. However, the Government is now stuck with the situation. At least we have a technical assessment group and a consultative group which are groups of expert people. Let us hope that at least they can get the book straight as to what occurred, what the responsibilities are and who was affected. Once again I stress, as has Senator Durack and Senator Sir John Carrick, this key situation of the black mist. I repeat: The evidence was drawn from a very narrow quarter. It has not been substantiated. I believe that Senator Gareth Evans is a fair person. He has indicated, at least in regard to Macaulay's position, that we should deal with this matter with caution. Before anything further is done, let him get his experts at work to investigate this matter thoroughly this time. Did the black mist exist? If the black mist existed, did it have anything to do with the Maralinga blast?
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McIntosh) agreed to:
That the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence for report:

The adequacy of current contingency planning by Federal and State authorities to deal with the accidental release of ionising radiation from visiting nuclear powered or armed vessels in Australian waters and ports.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AMENDMENT (PROHIBITION OF THE EXPORTATION OF URANIUM TO FRANCE) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Sanders) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Customs Act 1901 to give effect to the policy whereby Australia will refuse to allow the supply of Australian uranium to France until France ceases testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific region.
Bill presented by Senator Sanders, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill has one purpose-to enact a clause of the policy of the Australian Labor Party. It prohibits the supply of uranium to France until France stops testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific.

The Bill will be the basis of amendments to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill. These amendments will strengthen the Treaty and give a clear signal that Australia is opposed to French nuclear testing in the Pacific.

Our reasons for taking this action are straightforward. We believe that it is utter hypocrisy to ratify a treaty when the Government has seriously undermined it in its relentless drive for export dollars.

The fact is that the Treaty only bans one nuclear-related activity which is presently taking place in the South Pacific-the testing of nuclear weapons by France at Mururoa. Yet that is the activity that the Government has just given its moral assent to, against the wishes of most Australians and key nations in our region.
A poll commissioned by the ABC's 7.30 Report showed that 58% of Australians oppose the sale of uranium to France, while only 38% support it.

Four South Pacific Forum nations-Papua New Guinea, Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands and Fiji-have condemned the Government's action. Papua New Guinea may reverse its earlier decision to ratify the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. As the largest and most influential non-European nation in the region, this could be the death knell of a treaty which is already almost worthless.

Their concerns are well-founded. In 41 atmospheric tests before 1974, and over 70 underground tests since, France has severely polluted the South Pacific region and beyond. It has consistently blocked attempts to investigate the effects of the tests on the Polynesian people. There is no doubt, however, that the indigenous people have been severely affected. French Polynesian peace activists claim that France has secretly flown islanders to Paris for cancer treatment.

This 19th century colonial attitude is part of the French ambition to influence the balance of power in the Pacific. An end to testing at Mururoa is unthinkable to them, because of the implications for New Caledonia, the base from which they want to project their military might. At the very time that France is trumpeting this ambition by dismantling their small steps towards Kanak independence, we have told them that all is forgiven.

Leaving the ban in place was and is the only sensible option, morally and politically. It was therefore a shock that a Government whose Prime Minister is renowned for seeking consensus should not have taken the path of least resistance.

However, the Government's reasoning becomes clear when its statements are examined. In accusing the anti-nuclear movement of acting with `ulterior motives', the Prime Minister must have been making a Freudian admission of his own hidden agenda.

The scrapping of the ban has been rationalised, most particularly by Mr Hawke, on the grounds that it was having no effect on France's dangerous nuclear testing at Mururoa. In fact, said the Prime Minister, France was laughing all the way to the bank, as it was able to buy cheaper uranium on the spot market.
Yet in the same breath, we were told that the Australian Government is confident that we can capture 25 per cent of the French uranium market from the late 1980s or the early 1990s.
Why would France consider entering into more long-term contracts with Australia if it can get cheaper uranium elsewhere?

The answer is that France does want long term contracts from reliable suppliers. Buying on the spot market gives no guarantee of continuous supply. France must be willing to pay extra to buy our uranium, otherwise the Government's desire for a quarter share of their market is wishful thinking.

When all the Government's rationalisations are brushed aside, it is obvious that its action is designed to serve one purpose-to signal to France that we will, in future, be a reliable source of supply. This decision indicates a major expansion in uranium exports from Australia, including, eventually, the opening of new uranium mines in addition to Roxby Downs.

The only reason this last plank of the ALP's quasi anti-uranium policy has not yet been broken is that there is no point in buying another party fight now. There is no call for new mines given the current uranium over-supply. However, when the decision is made, it will be made solely on economic grounds. If the ALP is in government at that time, there will be no tears shed by these captives of the New Right as they overturn party policies yet again.

The Government's designs on the French market show that the ban must have been working. It must have posed a threat to France's expanding nuclear power program and its burgeoning nuclear weapons arsenal. With a secure supply of Australian uranium for energy production, France is well placed to obtain uranium for bombs from less scrupulous sources in the Third World-such as two of its present suppliers, Niger and Namibia-and from its own reserves.
Uranium from Niger has assisted Pakistan, Libya and Israel in their covert quests for nuclear weapons, while the huge Rossing mine in Namibia fuels South Africa's bomb program.

This highlights the nonsense of our bilateral safeguards agreements. All of our hand wringing and careful accounting is reduced to a farce when France can get ample uranium from Niger and Namibia, with no strings attached.

France, in turn, has shown a complete disregard for world security in its role as a nuclear supplier. It supplied the Dimona 2 reactor to Israel in 1963, which Israel has used to produce plutonium for ten to twenty Hiroshima-sized bombs, according to a 1976 CIA report.

It has helped Pakistan, which is on the verge of building the `Islamic Bomb', to develop a reprocessing facility which could produce weapons-grade plutonium. It supplied reactors and fuel to Iraq, whose nuclear weapons ambitions were only thwarted by Israel's attack on the Osirak reactor in 1981. It has had nuclear links with India, Brazil, Argentina and South Africa, all of which have an actual or desired nuclear weapons capability.

Most importantly, France does not draw a distinction between the civilian and military nuclear fuel cycles. The Superphenix fast breeder reactor, supposedly a civilian plant, has been earmarked by numerous French officials as the only source of plutonium able to fuel France's expanding nuclear weapons program. France refuses to say whether the Superphenix will be used for weapons manufacture. In spite of their appalling nuclear record, we are prepared to bury our heads in the sand and hope for the best.

In proceeding at breakneck speed with its nuclear power program, France is a likely location for the next Chernobyl. And in planning to build 600 nuclear bombs between now and 1995, France is striving to become the third nuclear super-power.

The Hawke Government is willing to help them achieve both milestones, despite the fact that the Pacific will continue to suffer from French nuclear imperialism. The Australian Democrats appeal to those who believe that ethics transcend economics to join with us and pass this Bill, in accordance with the wishes of a large majority of Australians, and the nations of the South Pacific.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ORDER OF BUSINESS AND DAY AND HOUR OF MEETING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
(1) That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing or Sessional Orders and unless otherwise ordered, the Order of the Business for Thursday, 18 September 1986 be as follows:
(1) Petitions
(2) Notices of Motion
(3) Formal Motions-Discovery of Formal Business
(4) Questions
(5) Ministerial Statements, by leave
(6) Presentation of Papers
(7) Adjournment.
(2) That the Senate, unless otherwise ordered, at its rising on Thursday, 18 September 1986, adjourn till Monday, 22 September 1986 at 2 p.m.
Consideration of House of Representatives message resumed from 16 September.
Schedule of the Amendment made by the House of Representatives in place of the Amendment made by the Senate to which the House has disagreed-
Clause 8, page 3, omit the clause, substitute the following clause;

`8. (1) A person shall not publish, or otherwise disclose to any other person, the whole or any part of a class A document that has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission, or counsel assisting the Commission.
Penalty:
(a) where the defendant is a natural person-$5,000 or imprisonment for 6 months, or both; or
(b) where the defendant is a corporation-$100,000.
`(2) Sub-section (1) does not apply in relation to anything done-
(a) in accordance with an authority given under sub-section 7 (4); or
(b) for the purposes of any proceedings for an offence against sub-section (1).
`(3) In this section, ``class A document'' has the same meaning as in section 7.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Committee does not insist upon the amendment disagreed to by the House of Representatives, and agrees to the amendment made by the House of Representatives in place thereof.

The basic issue with which we are now confronted is the amendment pursued by the Government in this place, unsuccessfully, and then moved by way of an amendment in the House of Representatives to the Senate's treatment of the Bill before the Senate rose for the recent adjournment. The effect of the Government's amendment is to place a general prohibition on disclosure of any of the material or information in the possession of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry, not just by anyone associated with the Commission, but by anyone else, and with quite substantial penalties being provided for anyone who so acts to put this material into the public domain. The Opposition, however, with the support of the Australian Democrats, has pursued a different course, wanting-and no doubt it will be moving for it again here today-a much more limited provision which would apply only to prohibit the disclosure of documentary information by members of the Commission, Commission staff and so on.

The Government wishes to pursue its own position on this as stated in the House of Representatives and as in the proposition now before us. Let me say why. The unique terms of reference of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry authorised an unprecedented inquiry into all aspects of the conduct of a particular individual. It was unprecedented. There has never been anything like this in the history of government in this country-the nature of the investigation itself and the width of it, with nothing barred from access by the Commission's inquiry procedures. In the light of the tragic developments of which we are all now so unhappily aware concerning Mr Justice Murphy's health, the allegations that have been collected by and prepared in the Commission will not now ever be tested before the Commission. Indeed, the Commission has not at this stage, so far as its members are concerned, even begun to examine whether those allegations have any foundation at all. All that they have concerned themselves with so far is the collection of material which is sufficiently precise in character to constitute an allegation for the purposes of its enabling legislation. A number of the allegations-perhaps all-are as likely as not to prove, when tested, to be absolute and complete scuttlebutt without any foundation at all.

The other thing that has happened in the Commission of Inquiry so far is that a purely legal ruling has been made by all three members of the Commission on the meaning of `proved misbehaviour', but that does not go in any way to the factual questions here in issue. As has been stated by me in previous debate in this place, and again by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the other place, it would be unconscionable and oppressive to allow any part of untested allegations prepared in the Commission to be circulated. It would be the hounding of a dying man and it would be a grave injustice to his family. We have already seen the kind of thing that is likely to happen with the squalid story, joining so many other squalid stories before us and likely to come in the future, in the National Times on Sunday of 7 September 1986, when the same old familiar gaggle of allegations about alleged unsavoury associations got yet another airing-whether on the basis of information supplied through Commission sources from material that would not otherwise have been available to the paper or whether supplied directly by the persons making the allegations we are not aware of. So it cannot be stated with any degree of certainty whether this particular publication would be the kind of thing that was prohibited or not on the basis of the Government's legislation that is now before us. I make no comment about whether or not it would be caught, because I do not know enough about the paper's sources of information. But one can say that it is exactly the kind of mean-spirited, squalid collection of scuttlebutt which has been the trademark of that publication through the whole course of this unhappy affair. It is not contributing anything to the public weal or to the national or public interest, and I would hope that it is not contributing anything to the circulation of the paper. It is a classic example of the kind of hounding process that it is the intention of this legislation, if our amendment is carried, to remove for the future.

The Government amendment to clause 8 will add a new sub-section (1) which deals precisely with the main problem as I have described it. The amendment is limited to documents that were prepared by the Commission and staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission relating to conduct by Mr Justice Murphy. I stress that the amendment does not apply to any documents prepared by other persons that were received or obtained by the Commission, nor does it apply to any steps that persons who have supplied any information or document to the Commission may wish to take to supply that information or document to other persons. In other words, to repeat, if someone who has made an allegation to the Commission or prepared a document himself which he has tendered to the Commission or produced a document to the Commission wants now to go public in some way to disclose that material to somebody else, he is at liberty to do so. The only thing that is prohibited is the disclosure of information that only exists, as it were, by virtue of the Commission, either as a result of having been prepared by it or that being the only route by which someone has had access to it.

The amendment is to be contrasted with that proposed and foreshadowed by the Opposition, which I shall speak to now to save time later, although it has not yet been formally moved. The Senate Opposition amendment will allow persons other than persons connected with the Commission to publish documents containing material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy, and so it does not operate widely enough to close off those avenues of disclosure which we believe in conscience and fairness ought to be closed. The second problem with the amendment in the terms drafted and circulated is that, insofar as it singles out the members of the Commission themselves, it is uniquely, unprecedently and profoundly offensive to the members of the Commission. That, in short, is our reaction to the Opposition's amendment. Our own amendment will eliminate the singling out of the members of the Commission, their staff and counsel, but the Opposition's amendment perpetrates this. On this question of the offensiveness of the Opposition's amendment, I simply mention further that the Government has had advice from the Secretary of the Commission that all members of the Commission consider the Opposition's amendment `grossly offensive' to persons associated with it. That is a perfectly understandable reaction and it is one that I now communicate to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —That comes from the Commission? Did you seek it?
—I certainly did not seek it; I am advised that is the nature of a communication that we have received.
—From where did the advice come?

—As I said, it came from the Secretary of the Commission. I am not sure whether it was given orally or in writing. I am advised now that it was an oral communication from the Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department.
—It is a funny way for a commission which is a parliamentary body to communicate to the Parliament. It is very funny.
—What do you want to do? Call the members to the Bar of the House? Do you want Mr Justice Blackburn and Mr Andrew Wells to come here?
—If they have already communicated with the Parliament before in a proper way, why can't they--

—The point is that there is no precedent in any Commonwealth legislation for singling out members of royal commissions in relation to this kind of secrecy provision. There are precedents, which I mentioned when we were previously debating this, of which I was aware and on which I thought this clause was based, imposing a secrecy restriction on the staffs of various bodies, but there do not appear to be any precedents at all for, in effect, singling out royal commissioners.
—Is a judge, in law, any more important than a layman?
—I simply record the fact that it is unprecedented and has been regarded by members of the Commission as offensive.
—I ask you: Before you and before the law, has a judge more right to protection than a layman?

—Certainly not to me. I think I have made that clear by my contributions over the years. I make the point that one proceeds on the assumption that judges do not have to be subjected to the kind of statutory discipline that the Opposition imposes upon them by being singled out for attention.
—Why? You singled out their staff.

—They would have been dealt with. I make it clear that the Government's amendment did not exclude members of the Commission from the general obligations; it just did not go down the offensive presentational track of singling them out to the exclusion of other classes of people who might be equally liable to disclose information and in that way equally put at risk the values that we are trying to protect. That is the point. It is a presentational point rather than a substantive point. There is no question of excluding them from liability. That is really as much as needs to be said on this already overly debated matter. As I have said, the Government agrees with the amendment made by the House of Representatives and wishes the Committee to agree to it too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I wish to deal with this red herring that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has introduced into this debate-namely, the alleged views of the commissioners. He admits that they have orally communicated their offence or displeasure at an amendment that has not only been proposed by the Opposition but also passed by this chamber and communicated to the House of Representatives. That displeasure was allegedly communicated orally to a staff member in the Attorney-General's Department. I would have thought that this was a most extraordinary claim to make in this debate, and extraordinary in a number of respects. If such indignation were felt by members of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry one would have thought that some better evidence of it would have been produced than this throwaway line by Senator Evans in the course of his recent remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Another extraordinary aspect of it is that this displeasure has been voiced to the Government, which is in no way responsible for the amendment. It has been fighting it tooth and nail and, if any displeasure were felt, one would have thought it would have been directed at those responsible, namely, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. I can assure the Senate that I have certainly had no displeasure communicated to me, nor, as far as I am aware, has the shadow Attorney-General. I will make some further inquiries about that in case he has had some displeasure directed to him. This is really a quite extraordinary procedure and I must say it only raises doubts in my mind as to how serious was this conversation that has now been retailed, quite improperly, by Senator Evans in this chamber and inserted into this debate.

The third extraordinary feature of this red herring introduced by Senator Evans is that if this displeasure is a fact, the commissioners have communicated their views in a most extraordinary way. Presumably they would have completely overlooked the fact that they were set up by this Parliament. The signal feature of this Commission-as Senator Evans keeps emphasising-is that it is unique; it has been set up by the Parliament to carry out this wide-ranging investigation into whether Mr Justice Murphy may have been engaged in any misbehaviour in constitutional terms. The Commission has already communicated its views in several respects in the proper way, namely, to the Presiding Officers. We have already had two reports from the Commission, one of which was to the Presiding Officers, and the Commission therefore clearly understands how its views should be made known to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about its communication to Spender which you want to table here? Is it improper for the Commission to communicate its views to John Spender? Is that improper? You are about to table a letter; you told me.
—That is a matter of communication.
—Well, the other matter was a matter of communication to us.

—In our letter the Commission was responding to questions that were asked. That is completely different from expressing a view about something that Parliament has done. It is a totally different matter. Here we have Senator Evans introducing another red herring into this debate. For a start I had not even raised this matter. Admittedly I will be doing so, and I will now do so probably with a great deal more fervour than I would otherwise have had. The fact is that, if the Commission wishes to communicate its views about a particular matter to the Parliament, it has already followed the right course on two occasions and I would be very surprised if it were seriously communicating its views on such a matter in the way that Senator Evans has indicated. Whatever the views of the Commission, I do not think they are relevant to this chamber's consideration of the matter. In debates here we do not usually have given to us the views of judges or public servants on what we should or should not do. I do not pay any more attention to these alleged views than I would to the views communicated to me by any other citizen, even if they had been properly and seriously submitted to us. I am sorry that I have had to spend so much of my short time in opening this debate in dealing with this complete red herring introduced quite improperly by Senator Evans.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has rejected in quite inadequate terms the amendment which was made in the Senate to clause 8 of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986, because it has now proposed an alternative clause to its original clause 8. Indeed, this is another example of the hasty and ill drafted nature of this Bill-we have had it before us for some time-to repeal the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. In clause 8 the Government had originally proposed the following:
A person shall not disclose-

(a) any allegation relating to the conduct of the Honourable Lionel Keith Murphy derived from a document received . . . by the Commission, the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission; or
(b) any information or statement disclosing any consideration by the Commission . . . any particular allegation . . .
There will be a penalty on a person of $5,000 or imprisonment and a penalty on a corporation of $100,000. The Government has proposed an alternative clause, which reads as follows:

A person shall not publish, or otherwise disclose to any other person, the whole or any part of a class A document that has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission, or counsel assisting the Commission.

A class A document is a document that contains material relating to the conduct of Mr Justice Murphy. The penalty remains exactly the same as the penalty in the Bill and there is no difference in substance between the Government's proposed amendment to clause 8 and the one that exists in the Bill. It introduces for, I believe, the first time in this country a very severe penalty indeed on any person, particularly on the Press. That is the reason for the $100,000 penalty on a corporation. The legislators had in mind the Press. The Bill includes draconian penalties on anybody publishing material which is by some other statutory provision made confidential. Where we have laws providing for confidentiality and non-disclosure of material-that is done in the Crimes Act itself in relation to public officials, Ministers and others-the obligation is placed on a person not to disclose information of a confidential character. This obligation is imposed on many people who are under agencies, statutory or otherwise. But these provisions-not even the Crimes Act does this-make it an offence, attended by draconian penalties, to publish material which may have come into a person's hands in a perfectly lawful way or certainly not in an unlawful way. Indeed, it would have been open to governments of all complexions for all time to very simply cut off leaks, which governments are always very upset about, by including in the Crimes Act a simple proposal of the kind proposed by the Government.

If the Government is serious about stopping leaks and stopping publication of its material, I would like to see it introduce an amendment to the Crimes Act to put a $100,000 penalty on a paper which publishes a confidential document which it is an offence for a person to disclose. This is a most serious departure by the Government from the freedom of expression and the freedom of the Press in this country. Its alternative amendment is absolutely no different in substance from the one in the Bill and which this Senate rejected and replaced with the amendment I moved before and which I propose to move again. I move:

Leave out all words after ``House of Representatives'' (first occurring), insert: ``, does not agree to the amendment made by the House of Representatives in place thereof, and makes a further amendment to the Bill, as follows:
Clause 8, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:

``8. (1) A person who is, or has at any time been, a member of the Commission, a member of the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission shall not, directly or indirectly, disclose to any other person or make use of any document or information to which the first-mentioned person has had access by reason of being or having been such a member or counsel.
``Penalty: $5,000 or imprisonment for 6 months, or both.
``(2) Sub-section (1) does not apply in relation to-
(a) the performance of any act otherwise authorised by this Act; or
(b) anything done in accordance with an authority given under sub-section 7 (4).''.

This procedure is a rather technical one. I have had to make a technical amendment to our original amendment because the original amendment was drawn up on the basis of a series of amendments to the Bill and it was on the assumption that those amendments may be carried. This amendment was drafted accordingly. However, as our other amendments were not agreed to and different amendments were agreed to in the Senate it has become necessary to make this technical amendment. Let me stress that the substance of this amendment is exactly the same; that is, an obligation is simply placed upon the members and staff of the Commission not to disclose any of the material before it to which they have had access. In other provisions of this Bill there are ways in which that material will be disposed of, but we are not debating it again today. Indeed we are not debating again the whole issue of repealing the Parliamentary Commission, as that has already been disposed of.

This is simply a means which the Opposition believes is a fair way of retaining confidentiality for a certain period by this method. It is based on a number of precedents in other statutes where people are the custodians of confidential material, but it does not take this giant step backwards-the Government's proposal is a giant step backwards-in freedom of expression and freedom of the Press in this country. The Government's amendment will make it a very serious offence to publish any material of that kind which comes into the hands of other people in a quite lawful way. The Opposition certainly sticks to the principle of its amendment and I have moved accordingly. Unfortunately there are a number of other matters that I wished to pursue. I will have to leave them to a later stage in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the issue we are debating needs to be put in some perspective. I am not at all sure how relevant a number of the items that have been raised so far in the debate really are to the issue that is paramount. It does not seem to me to matter terribly much whether or not the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry is upset about the way the particular amendment is worded. After all, the Government also wished to include the Commission in its prohibitions. It is upset about the words. I am not sure how important that is. In fact, I cannot see that it is of any importance in terms of the issues that are involved here.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats objected to the establishment of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry. However, with the support of the Opposition parties the Government chose to go ahead and to have an inquiry. It should never have been held and we are now facing the problem of how we can close it down. When the terminal illness of Mr Justice Murphy was made public we called for the Commission to be closed down immediately. At least the Government saw the sense of closing it down at that stage. Natural justice and the ability of Mr Justice Murphy to defend himself were obviously removed and it would have been an absolutely gross operation for the Commission to continue. I believe that a lot of the public debate since that time has consisted of hounding a dying man and I think it has been one of the more disgraceful episodes of Australia's political life.

For some reason that entirely escapes me a number of spokespersons for the Opposition seem to be unable to grasp the fact that the documents have been divided into a variety of categories. As I said last time, every allegation which has been made to the Commission has, of its very nature, to be in the possession of at least one other person in the community. In fact, the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill to close the Commission down is so worded that these allegations are able to be communicated to any other body that may conceivably have any other interest in them, whether it be the National Crime Authority, the Australian Federal Police or any other body. There is nothing within this Bill to prevent anybody who has made those allegations from remaking those allegations to anybody to whom they feel desirous of so doing and courting any particular legal penalty or running up against any laws of defamation or libel that they wish to run up against. The other document-the document seeking information of a technical kind with regard to the Constitution-has also already been made public, as I believe it should have been. The only documents we are discussing here are the working papers of the Commission; that is, lists that the Commission has made after sorting through the various allegations that have been made, lists of unfounded allegations. That is the type of thing about which we are talking. It does not seem to me that they are the types of things that should be floating around. In fact, we said at the time-we stand by this-that we think the whole lot should be bundled up and burnt. The Government went into an arm waving exercise about witch hunting or something else, and said that it would not do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Book burning.

—Book burning, was it? I do not see that it is any use when we have this unprecedented situation where Mr Justice Murphy is unable to rebut these allegations, when further down the path we would not have a report which may rebut unfounded allegations. In fact, this whole sorry business is the result of the way this thing was set up. I remind the Senate that it was set up by the Government with the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the Government's solution will not achieve the ends that it has sought to achieve. We have already seen that. I do not know whether the Minister reads the National Times on Sunday, but the article has been in there since we had the last debate and it would have been in there regardless of what this Parliament had done in terms of these amendments. We were talking about a penalty of $100,000. In media terms, for a newspaper which is just starting off and is seeking penetration of readership, fairly obviously $100,000 is cheap; it is peanuts. If the newspaper could get into court on that operation, it would probably be quite happy. The facts of the matters are that by giving the attention the Government has chosen to give to those documents, it has enabled the National Times on Sunday to increase its circulation, because it has given credence, support or airing to a certain range of documents which most people in the community would find dead boring if they actually had to read them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the threat of gaoling journalists?
—Senator Baume will have his time to speak later on.
—What about the threat of gaoling the journalist?

—I think the National Times on Sunday would be happy to have one of its journalists threatened with gaol; it would be a marvellous boost to circulation. The point I am making is that the proposals the Government has made in no way protect Mr Justice Murphy. That may be what the Government is intending to do, but its actions do not do that. That is our reason for objecting to them. I am not at all sure about the Opposition's wringing of hands with regard to the freedom of the Press and all the rest. I believe that we have an unprecedented situation. We have a whole series of material which should not be made public, but I do not believe that the way the Government is going about it will achieve that result. I do not happen to believe that it has anything to do with freedom of the Press or otherwise with regard to this. It is a whole lot of material that should not be out in public. The Opposition has agreed that it should not be made public, because it will move an amendment that will prevent it from being made public. So, there is no disagreement here; we all agree that it should not be made public. We are just interested in the method by which we prevent that. It is not a matter of freedom of the Press or otherwise, as the Opposition is quite happy to agree that it should not be made public.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans): What is the current state of the law governing this material? What is the current state of section 10 of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act? Will that still continue in operation upon the passage of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you talking about the main Bill or the repeal Bill?

—I am sorry. It is in the original Bill, which is the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act. It is section 14, sub-section (10), which states that, except in accordance with a direction of the Commission, evidence given before the Commission, contents of documents, information and the fact that any person has given or may be about to give evidence at a hearing shall not be published. Then there is reference to penalties: A fine of $2,000 and imprisonment for a period not exceeding 12 months. In other words, will that continue to have a bearing on the publication of material subsequent to the repeal Bill being passed by the Parliament? If, as I think, it does--
—It does not. It is no help to you at all.
—One would then want to know what that does with regard to those documents.
—I make it clear that no evidence has been given to the Commission nor any document produced to the Commission within the meaning of this section, so that section will have no continued operation.
—In other words, it does not matter whether it continues or not?
—No.

—I thank the Minister. The proposition that we have before us is the one circulated by the Opposition, which has now been tidied up as a result of the opportunity to have a closer look at the second part of it. It seems to us that, unsatisfactory though that is, there is no other means of dealing with the task at hand. This essentially put the onus on the Commission to prevent the material that it has from becoming public. I am curious as to what action the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has taken with regard to the publication last weekend, as to whether or not that in any way was seen to be a breach and, if it was not seen by the Attorney-General to be a breach--
—A breach of what?
—The security in the previous Act. It was not seen to be a breach in any way.
—Which provision of the previous Act?
—I am asking.
—There is no provision it could have offended.

—That is an interesting admission-that the Government was quite happy to pass the previous legislation without one but now it wishes to pass legislation with one. The publication that occurred last weekend presumably would be prevented by the Government in terms of the fact that the Government wishes to prevent the publication of allegations, but it would not be prevented by the Opposition's amendment. Under the Opposition's amendment, if it were passed, those types of publications based on material which came from the Commission could be investigated, because the Opposition's amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a member of the staff . . . shall not, directly or indirectly, disclose to any other person or make use of any document or information to which the first-mentioned person has had access by reason of being or having been such a member or counsel.

In other words, it would seek to cut off at source the information. Quite frankly, beyond that there is very little that one can do. It was plainly obvious with regard to the leaks from the Senate Committee--
Consideration interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret to inform honourable senators that Senator Button is absent from Question Time today. I regret even more to inform honourable senators that any questions to be addressed to him should be addressed to me.

—In the interests of mercy seasoning injustice, I will address my question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer the Minister to an answer given by his predecessor as Minister for Resources and Energy in May 1984 in which Senator Walsh expressed the Government's concern about delays in dealing with applications for exploration and mining on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory. The Minister may recall that Senator Walsh said then that 165 exploration prospects had been held up for almost three years because agreement could not be reached between mining companies and Aboriginal communities. Does this situation still exist? Will the Government proceed with legislation this year to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act in an effort to break the deadlock which has developed in the Territory and, if not, why not?

—There are signs of breaches in the deadlock situation that has prevailed in the Northern Territory, most recently with the signing of the Uranerz agreement between the Northern Land Council and a mining group, demonstrating that it is possible under the existing regime for agreements that are mutually satisfactory to be reached. However, it has to be acknowledged that there are many constraints under the existing Fraser Government land rights legislation in the way of reaching quick agreement for exploration and mining on Aboriginal land, and the Government does have a clearly preferred position as to what amendments to that regime there should be. This preferred position has now been embodied in a draft Bill which is the subject of continuing consultations both with the mining industry and with the Northern Land Council and the Central Land Council, as well as other relevant government interests, including that, of course, of the Northern Territory Government. What will be able to be done by way of meeting a timetable for the introduction of this legislation still remains to be seen. But my understanding from talking to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs just a very short time ago is that it is still his hope and his expectation that legislation will be introduced this session. Whether it can be introduced and passed this session, given the enormously heavy timetable that confronts us, depends a lot on the co-operation we receive in the conduct of parliamentary affairs.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer. I just ask whether the consultations with the land councils and the Northern Territory Government are still proceeding or whether those consultations are complete, and is the only remaining barrier the normal party processes that legislation goes through at the end of such processes?

—It is really a matter for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to answer. Discussions are proceeding within the normal parliamentary party processes at the moment. It may be that those discussions throw up further issues which the Minister believes need further consultation with other groups. A number of such issues have been thrown up in discussion so far. Those processes are continuing. There are further meetings today, and no doubt there will be a lot more yet before we see the legislation. But that is understandable, given the importance and sensitivity of this legislation.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment aware of media reports which claim that the Government has decided to allow mining at Coronation Hill in the projected stage 3 of Kakadu National Park? Will the Minister explain the Government's intentions regarding the future of the Coronation Hill mineral lease and clarify that part of yesterday's joint ministerial statement which refers to provision being made for exclusion from the park of `an appropriate mining lease area, and the project allowed to proceed subject to normal environmental, Aboriginal heritage related clearances'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has agreed to enlarge the boundaries of the park into the existing Gimbat and Goodparla leases. The details of this stage 3 extension, including the mechanisms to ensure the full environmental protection of the South Alligator River system, will be subject to further consideration by Cabinet and Caucus. The Government has also agreed that the development of the Coronation Hill mineral deposit may proceed subject to it satisfying environmental requirements arising from full environmental assessment. Consideration will have to be given to ensure the full protection of the park, Aboriginal and catchment values. The location of Coronation Hill is extremely significant in relation to the catchment and world heritage wetlands. The Government is most conscious of this significance and intends to ensure that the fullest and most sensitive environmental examination takes place. If, at the conclusion of this examination, mining development is to take place, this will occur only on conditions which provide the highest level of environmental protection, not only in the particular area, but for the conservation values of the park as a whole.

ANSWER.PARA: Stage 3 is important for the variety of essentially natural ecosystems which it contains and which complement those in the proclaimed park. It also contains a wealth of Aboriginal rock art--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the embarrassment of the Opposition is very understandable. It also contains a wealth of Aboriginal rock art and provides significant opportunities for tourist development. The integrity of the existing park and particularly the extensive wetlands depends in large measure on the management of stage 3.
—Mr President, I ask that the Minister table the document from which she has so extensively quoted.
—Is the Minister prepared to table the document? The Minister has tabled the document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Can the Minister for Finance confirm Senator Button's statement on the AM program on 8 September that the reason that further cuts in spending in particular areas were not included in this year's Budget was that expenditure reviews were continuing and it was felt that they should be completed before any decision was made by the Government in relation to expenditure in those areas? Have any or all of these reviews since been finalised and, if so, will the Government be announcing decisions on further expenditure cuts in the near future?

—I am not sure, because of the background noise, that I heard all the question; but I got the gist of it, I think. I am not sure what Senator Button meant when he made that statement, but it is already a matter of public record that the Government has before it a paper-I stress that it is no more than a paper-which examines, among other things, programs for which there is both a State and a Commonwealth financial and staffing or administrative obligation. As any diligent government ought to do, this Government from time to time examines those sorts of programs and whether economies can be made on both financial and staffing requirements by some change in the administrative arrangements. It is common knowledge that such a paper exists: I have myself confirmed it. But the consideration of that paper has not yet been completed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Education inform the Senate of what steps the Government is taking to ensure that cuts in the Commonwealth English as a second language budget will not lead to significant reductions in services to migrant children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is taking a number of steps to ensure that unallocated funds available for particular purposes in the Commonwealth Budget may be directed to the ESL area depending on the agreement of the States and the non-government systems. I remind the Senate that there was a cut-a severe cut, I admit-of $27m in the ESL program. At the same time, of course, the Government will continue to commit over $40m for the ESL program next year. So we have by no means vacated the ESL field. In addition to that $40m, $4m was announced by me on Thursday in order to assist in the development of across-the-curriculum ESL resources in the next year. With regard to those States which may not be able to absorb the cuts and continue to provide these services, I have said to them since Budget evening-and I have had discussions with them since-that the $38m which is available nationally as unallocated extra recurrent funding may be directed to the ESL area if that has the highest priority with the States and the non-government systems. In addition to that $38m, we have indicated that the highest priority under the participation and equity program should go to programs assisting children from a non-English speaking background. The amount of money allocated for that is $24m.

ANSWER.PARA: So, honourable senators can see that, although there has been a cut of $27m, an amount in the vicinity of $66m is available to the States and the non-government systems to be directed substantially-not entirely, but substantially-to programs assisting children of a non-English speaking background if the States and the non-government systems accord those programs a high priority. I am very pleased to report to the Senate, because I know that not only Senator Sibraa is interested in this matter, that most of the States and the major non-government system-the Catholic system-have already indicated that they will co-operate with the Commonwealth in the direction of these extra moneys to that area. I hope that the end result, if we can get complete co-operation in this matter between the States and the Commonwealth, will be that the level of services to migrant children will not be reduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the Government agree with the declaration made in Mexico on 7 August by the heads of six governments from five continents that, since the nuclear weapons states have not ended the nuclear arms race, it is up to the non-nuclear countries to become actively involved in all aspects of disarmament? As nuclear arms control is everybody's business because everybody would be affected by nuclear war, I ask the Minister whether the Australian Government will work together with those countries to establish a network of monitoring stations to support a nuclear test ban as the first step towards achieving nuclear disarmament.

—It may be that, given a little more notice, I could give the honourable senator a more comprehensive answer. But, yes, I am aware of the declaration to which she referred. I am certainly aware of the concern that has been expressed about the desirability of establishing an international network of monitoring stations which could effectively verify nuclear weapons test bans of the kind that Australia has been very much in the forefront of promoting in recent years. With that in mind, my Department of Resources and Energy has been co-operating closely with the Department of Foreign Affairs to establish within the Bureau of Mineral Resources a seismological monitoring station linked to data derived from both the United States-run joint facility in Alice Springs and, I think I recall correctly, other monitoring sources or locations around Australia-although I will need to check that. We have been in the process of putting that centre together and developing the capacity to develop independently monitoring techniques in association and consultation with other interested countries around the world. That centre will shortly be opened formally by Mr Hayden and me. At that time, if not before, I will be perfectly happy to make a statement, probably jointly with Mr Hayden, explaining fully what is going on and how it will help to secure the objectives to which Senator Haines referred.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a Press release put out last Sunday by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Ralph Hunt? If so, can the Minister indicate the need for new taxes proposed by the Deputy Leader of the National Party?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fuel price increases to which the Press statement in question refers are a consequence of the import parity pricing policy for crude oil first introduced in 1978 by the coalition government of which Mr Hunt was a member. However, I presume that, since Mr Hunt has put out such a statement, he now repudiates the import parity pricing policy. I do not know whether that view is shared by the temporary Leader of the Opposition or whether it is just another example of the National Party of Australia running off and doing its thing while the Liberal Party of Australia does something else.

ANSWER.PARA: I have noted in particular the last paragraph of the Press statement in question, which refers to the need for the Government to `slash its tax burden on fuel-if necessary, making up some of the revenue forgone through a broadly based consumption tax'. I suppose that is a point of view. But, if the irresponsible policies of the Leader of the Opposition were to be implemented, there would need to be either a very large and very broadly based consumption tax or a huge increase in a variety of other taxes. Although on the Thursday following the Budget the Leader of the Opposition junked all of his expenditure promises-except that of continuing to pay pensions to millionaires-a couple of days later the National Party came up with expenditure proposals for $900m, in addition to the expenditure of about the same order which would be required to service Mr Howard's proposed modifications of Medicare and another $600m or $700m to fund the Opposition's proposition that people should work or receive training in return for the unemployment benefit. So, one way or another we have back into the system $2 billion or so worth of expenditure commitments over and above those contained in this year's Budget. In addition to that, the Opposition has promised around $5 billion in taxation cuts, which would reduce the revenue by $5 billion.

So, when we add up all of those figures, we find that there is about $5 billion worth of forgone revenue from the Opposition's taxation promises, $2 billion worth of increased expenditure-not endorsed in every case by the Leader of the Opposition but put out by the National Party-which makes a total of $7 billion. If one adds to that the existing Budget deficit, one comes up with a Budget deficit figure of $10.5 billion if the irresponsible fiscal policies of the Opposition Leader were to be implemented. In concluding, I note that in absolute terms, although not in real terms, a deficit of $10.5 billion would be even bigger than the $9.6 billion deficit that this Government inherited from Mr Howard the last time he got his hands on the levers of power and his fingers in the till.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in that capacity and in part in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Territories. Does the Government intend to proceed to legislate to break a number of contracts for home sales, entered into with purchasers in Canberra, that contain fixed interest mortgage payments? Is the Government taking steps to inform these home purchasers of that immoral action in breaching contracts and the repayments that will now be demanded even though the legislation has not been introduced into the Parliament? How can the people of Australia trust this Government not to breach similar contracts such as those for defence service home loans and not to increase unilaterally those interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware of the issues raised by Senator Reid. I appreciate that there is some concern in the Australian Capital Territory about the decisions taken by the Government in response to the present difficult economic circumstances. The Minister for Territories advises me that the extremely low interest rates paid by some borrowers cannot be justified and that, in the interests of equity, pre-September 1983 borrowers should have to bear the same economic burden as new borrowers. The Minister advises me that the additional revenue raised-some $800,000 in the remainder of the 1986-87 Budget year and $1.6m in a full year-will be used to provide additional Commissioner for Housing loans, thereby extending to many more persons the opportunity of home ownership in the Australian Capital Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister has also advised me that mortgagees will not be required to commit any more than 25 per cent of their income towards loan repayments. The Government will take into account specifically any genuine hardship cases, and arrangements will be made to balance their repayments with their commitments. Any subsidy given will be recovered over the life of the loan. The Government is responding to the difficulties that have been raised by Senator Reid, and each case will be dealt with sympathetically.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. The Minister failed to address the third part of the question as to whether or not the people of Australia can have any confidence at all that the same thing will not happen to defence service home loans, which also have fixed interest mortgages.

—The Opposition is in the glorious position of being able to criticise every saving the Government seeks to make in such areas. As Senator Reid has taken up that issue specifically-that is, the problems faced by those who have existing commitments-I shall put it to the Minister for a direct response.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CHRISTMAS ISLAND: PHOSPHATE MINING AND TOURISM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. Is the Minister aware of any proposals for tourist developments on Christmas Island? If so, can he outline what those proposals entail? Is it the case that the proposals are linked to the current industrial dispute between the Union of Christmas Island Workers and the management of the Phosphate Mining Company of Christmas Island Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The future of Christmas Island has been on the agenda of both the previous Government and this Government for some years. The Parliament will be aware that phosphate mining on that island will ultimately cease. I recall that in June this year the Government made a decision in principle on the development of a casino-resort complex on Christmas Island. That matter is currently under review by the Government. Final approval will depend on a number of factors, including the upgrading of the airport and the presentation to Government of a sound financial package which would make it an economically and socially desirable alternative to the existing problems on the island.

ANSWER.PARA: In July, the Government decided that the mining operations on Christmas Island should continue, with a subsidy of $4 1/2m to be paid at least until April 1987. The Minister for Terri- tories has advised me that, as a result of that decision, there will be some displacement of the work force. Some 150 persons will be retrenched. The situation will be reviewed in April 1987. Senator Childs, because of his background in the trade union movement, will realise that there is a union response to that proposal. The Minister is currently considering proposals that the Union of Christmas Island Workers has placed before the Government to see whether some reasonable approach can be reached in respect of the current difficulties.

The Minister is sympathetic, but obviously he is acting under some restraint of Government policy. I shall ensure that Senator Childs's question is drawn to his attention to see whether he wants to amplify the matter. I am aware that Senator Lewis has expressed support for the Government's proposals for the island, even though Mr N. A. Brown, an Opposition spokesman on other matters, has taken a somewhat different position.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to the requirement for farm employers to furnish records of farm produce used by employees for the purposes of the fringe benefits tax. In order to establish whether the arbitrary $150 value of produce per annum has been exceeded, does the Minister agree that accurate and detailed records need to be kept of every item supplied, and that that adds a further complex and costly administration burden to the farm business? If an employer claims at the end of the year that the $150 limit has not been exceeded, but has not kept records, and that claim is challenged by the Australian Taxation Office, could the employer end up paying the full fringe benefits tax on the amount of produce assessed by the Tax Office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As with income tax, I would expect that if a person does not satisfy the Commissioner of Taxation that his income tax assessments are correct, the Commissioner will make his own assessment. I expect that the same position would apply to fringe benefits tax if the Commissioner is not satisfied that the declaration is accurate or complete. However, I shall have the matter checked. I am interested that Senator Collard should take up this question. It is worth ruminating for a while on the National Farmers Federation's point of view.
—I take a point of order. Senator Walsh obviously feels a debate coming on.
—Order! Is the point of order coming on? Is there a point of order?

—I think that I shall make it a point of order, Mr President. We have had an answer from the honourable senator. One can see him being tempted into a debate on the question. I thought that I should draw attention to that at an early stage, since he has given us a fair shot across the bows on this occasion. I suggest, Mr President, that you use your presidential power to ensure that he does not debate the question.
—Order! I think that Senator Chaney has forecast a point of order.

—Regarding the effects of fringe benefit taxation on farmers, the fact is that the majority of farmers will not be affected at all. That leads one to the further question: Why is the National Farmers Federation making such a fuss about it? Is the NFF concerned about the welfare of the people it purports to represent, or is it concerned about the welfare of the Elders-IXL Ltd director who happens to be its President, and people in that category? One has double grounds for suspicion when one considers the degree of support from the NFF for the proposition coming from the Federal Opposition that we should have flat tax. If we had a flat taxation system, the reality is that the overwhelming majority of farmers would pay more tax than they pay now.

ANSWER.PARA: So the National Farmers Federation opposes a tax revenue measure which affects a small minority of its members, adversely perhaps, but supports a tax revenue measure which would adversely affect the great majority of its members. Therefore, the credentials of those people in the National Farmers Federation who are orchestrating such a campaign should be called into question. Senator Collard, in the first part of his question, referred to farmers-this applies to everyone else-who think that the bookkeeping provisions of the fringe benefits tax are too onerous deciding not to comply with them. All they have to do is either remove the fringe benefits or cash them out.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Now that the Veterans' Entitlements Act has been operating for some time, can the Minister comment on the approach taken by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the approval of totally and permanently incapacitated pensions under the new Act? Is that approach denying TPI pensions to veterans over 65 years of age? Are the provisions in the new Act retrospective in effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be aware that, in the statement of 14 May last year, certain proposals were made about changing the entitlement areas for those who would otherwise be eligible for the totally and permanently incapacitated pension rate. The proposals were considered by the Parliament. Some changes were made to the provisions by which applicants may be granted a pension relating specifically to their eligibility. In a number of cases the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has been called upon to make some decisions on the legislation passed by the Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: The Tribunal has decided not to grant applications for TPI pensions on principle because the veteran would have ceased work by the time the pension increase was sought. The Tribunal's decision has stressed that although there is no upper limit in terms of age, it made it clear that only in rare cases will a veteran who is beyond the normal retirement age qualify for the grant of a TPI pension. The new TPI provisions are not retrospective, which is a question Senator Giles asked of me. They do not in any way affect existing beneficiaries or those with special pension entitlements. In fact, during the debate in Parliament that point was agreed to by the Opposition. It would be inappropriate for me to comment on any of the cases before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Federal Court, although those issues are being canvassed there in respect of the rights of some of those who have applications pending.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Having formally invited the United States of America and the United Kingdom to send ships to visit Australia as part of the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy, is the Government going to honour its obligations? In view of statements by the maritime unions that their members will strike rather than provide the customary port services and the stupid acts of harassment yesterday by protest groups in Brisbane, how will the Government ensure that ships of the United States Navy and the Royal Navy visiting Brisbane later this week receive the courtesies and assistance that they are entitled to expect as invited guests?
—I have no briefing on that. I shall seek a response from the Minister for Defence.

—Is the Minister for Community Services able to say whether the Government has put aside funds to make good its new policies on the care of the aged program as set out in the Budget statement? Has he been made aware of the serious shortage of hostel beds in New South Wales? Are there any plans to meet that shortage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Richardson for that question as it just happens to coincide with the fact that today I am announcing the expenditure of some $40m on grants for accommodation for the aged in every State, particularly in Senator Richardson's home State of New South Wales, where the amount of money to be expended is about $18m. Senator Richardson will be pleased to know that the grants enable voluntary organisations, church groups, welfare groups but particularly local community groups to provide hostel and nursing home accommodation and to replace nursing home beds in some areas.

ANSWER.PARA: These allocations are an important step in the implementation of the nursing homes and hostels review strategy which we announced in the Budget and which resulted in increased expenditure in the Budget. The Government wants to give people more freedom of choice and more alternatives to nursing homes. For that reason, the grants will involve an emphasis on the provision of hostel beds. We will fund nursing home beds also because there is a need for adequate beds for those who need that form of care. Groups with special needs, such as ethnic groups, will be better catered for. Funding will be spread out over the 1986-87, 1987-88 and 1988-89 financial years because of the long lead times taken in some areas.

I would dearly like to list the individual projects throughout Australia for honourable senators as I know of their great interest in this matter. However, I know that, if I did so, Senator Chaney would feel a point of order coming on, and he would probably succeed in that case. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the list of organisations and the purposes to which those funds are to be put.
NEW GRANTS TO BUILD ACCOMMODATION FOR ELDERLY
Aged people and people with disabilities will benefit from grants totalling $40.4 million for the construction of accommodation.
The Minister for Community Services, Senator Don Grimes released details of the grants today.
The grants will enable voluntary, welfare and church groups and local government to provide 1493 new or replacement hostel places, 335 new or replacement nursing home beds.
The allocation of these funds for hostel and nursing home beds is an important step in implementing recommendations of the Nursing Homes and Hostels Review.

A major recommendation of that review was the need for more emphasis on hostel care and community based services. In the past, too much emphasis had been directed to nursing homes at the expense of these.

``The extra hostel places resulting from these grants will enable more people to take advantage of hostel facilities, and this, in turn, will reduce demand for nursing home beds,'' Senator Grimes said.

``The Government wants to give more freedom of choice and more alternatives to nursing homes. Nevertheless, these grants will ensure that there are adequate nursing home beds for people who do need this form of care.
``These grants will lead to a fairer distribution of facilities. There will be a more even geographic distribution and there will be better provision for needy people.
``As well, the needs of groups with special needs, such as the ethnic communities have been better catered for,'' he said.
Funding will be spread over the 1986-87 to 1988-89 financial years.
