TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that three Labor State governments are attempting to circumvent the global limits set last June by the Loan Council for public sector new money borrowings by resorting to the sale of deferred annuities under the Commonwealth's lump sum superannuation tax law? Would not such schemes lead to a higher effective public sector borrowing requirement and therefore greater pressure on interest rates? Would the interest earned under the investment of moneys be free of Commonwealth income tax under section 27h of the Income Tax Assessment Act? What advice has the Minister received on the status of these ingenious devices which seem to fall outside the Loan Council's global borrowing limits? If this is so, what action does he intend to take?

—The answer to the first part of the question, in which I was asked whether I was aware of all those events, is no. Consequently, the rest of the question is not applicable-to me anyway-but I will refer it to the Treasurer and obtain a response for Senator Messner.

—I refer the Minister for Education to the administration charge payable by some tertiary students in 1987. Has the Minister had any discussions with any institutions on the feasibility of payment of the charges by instalments so that no students are forced to discontinue their studies because they do not have sufficient finance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —How the institutions collect the charge and the time scale within which they do so are questions for the institutions. Obviously, it is easiest, and therefore administratively most efficient, if the institutions collect the $250 at the point of enrolment. If they make any other decisions, there will be further administration. That is not to say that institutions may not make those other decisions. The institutions will, in fact, keep the $250 that they collect and have their grants from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission adjusted accordingly, although they will also net 10 per cent of the charges for their own purposes. The institutions therefore have the scope in that sense to collect the charges in instalments. I presume that some of them will decide to do that. Certainly, the Government would put no obstacle in their way. If the institutions were to do that in an attempt to come to terms with the difficulties that some students may experience, we would be happy to co-operate with them.

ANSWER.PARA: Institutions may decide also-I have asked them to do this-to make loans to students who are having difficulty in getting together $250 at the beginning of the year. The special assistance to students loan fund is now available to every college of advanced education and university. I have asked the institutions to ensure that loans are made in a fairly liberal fashion so that the students may get the loan of the $250 and then repay the $250 to the loan fund during the year in terms that are suitable to the student and to the people administering the loan fund. The loan funds are administered with student representation.

There are two ways in which institutions may assist those students who find difficulty in getting together $250 at the point of enrolment. I believe that the institutions will co-operate in this. There has been no indication that they will not. After all, there is some supplementation to the income available to them from the charge. They are aware that there will be some cases in which students are required to meet the charge but are having difficulty in getting the money together.

Students who are eligible for any form of assistance under the tertiary education assistance scheme will have the $250 immediately given back to them. Students on supporting parent benefit, invalid pensions or carer's pensions will not be liable to the charge. Aboriginal students assisted through Austudy will have the charge restored to them. We are looking only at that group of students who are not eligible for benefits or assistance of any kind. Technically speaking, that should mean the better off students but, because the Government recognises that sometimes people's circumstances differ from what is on paper, we have asked the institutions to be accommodating to needy students in the ways that I have set out. The outcome should be that the imposition of the charge will not be an obstacle to any student who is serious about pursuing his or her studies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. Will the Minister allow an increase in the number of international airline flights, including charter flights, into Australia during the America's Cup competitions so as to avoid disappointment to a large number of yachting enthusiasts who at present may be denied the opportunity of coming to Australia because of the limit on overseas flights into Australia?

—Senator Watson has raised a very interesting question relating to increasing the flights of airlines into Australia during the America's Cup period. He would be aware that a lot of pressure is being exerted on the Government to open the very lucrative Australian market to many foreign airlines-a course which, of course, obviously, is being resisted by Qantas Airways Ltd, in its advice to the Government, and correctly so. I represent the Minister for Aviation in this place. They are not matters upon which I can venture an opinion, although I can state the facts. I will certainly bring the matter to the attention of Mr Peter Morris and see whether he can give an early response to the honourable senator's question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Given that Jane's Fighting Ships and numerous other ship references list the United States battleship Missouri as having on board 32 Tomahawk sea-launched cruise missiles-an offensive weapon which is not only nuclear capable but also widely regarded in the arms control community as dangerously destabilising in terms of proliferation and verification procedure-why is the Government allowing this vessel into the heart of Sydney in the first week of October for the fleet assembly, only two months after presenting a treaty for a nuclear free zone at the South Pacific Forum meeting in Fiji and three months after reaffirming its commitment to deterrence as opposed to nuclear war fighting at the Australian Labor Party conference in Hobart? Furthermore, is it true that the Missouri is not only visiting Sydney but will also be going to Hobart and other ports either before or after the fleet assembly? If so, which ports and on what dates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty does not prohibit the transit of warships through the South Pacific region or visits to Australian ports. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has made this clear on innumerable occasions but most accessibly, perhaps, in his second reading speech introducing the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill on 5 June 1986. The Government welcomes visits by United States Navy ships to Australia as essential to the effectiveness of the ANZUS alliance. To come to the latter part of the question, there is no conflict between the Government's support for deterrence and the visit of the USS Missouri. The Government does not agree that Tomahawk missiles are destabilising or are primarily intended for nuclear war fighting.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two kinds of missiles: There are the nuclear ones and there are the conventionally armed. As to the nuclear-armed Tomahawks, I am advised that two roles for these have been outlined. Both take advantage of the greater dispersal of United States Navy nuclear capability provided by the deployment ultimately of Tomahawk missiles on 190 vessels instead of on, essentially, only 14 aircraft carriers. The first stated role-Senator MacGibbon will love all this stuff-is as an assured survivable reserve. It would be able substantially to survive a Soviet first strike and so ensure that United States forces could not be disarmed by such a strike. The second stated role is to match the long range naval cruise missiles already deployed by the USSR and thus to augment present United States Navy capabilities. As such, it allows the United States to balance the Soviet capacity for theatre nuclear war and nuclear war at sea. It also allows the United States to ensure that any Soviet nuclear strike against the United States Navy could be met with retaliation in kind-retaliation which would not necessarily involve escalation and the use of United States strategic nuclear forces. Finally, this role ensures that the USSR should not envisage any advantage to itself in initiating a nuclear war at sea.

The conventionally armed Tomahawks deter the outbreak of war by providing survivable weapons systems less vulnerable to Soviet pre-emptive attack and by demonstrating to the USSR that the United States has the military capabilities to prevent it from achieving its war aims. The conventional Tomahawks also raise the threshold against the use of nuclear weapons if conflict should occur by increasing United States Navy conventional military capability. So there!

The Minister for Defence has also advised me that the USS Missouri will visit the following ports on the following dates: Sydney from 1 to 6 October, Hobart from 8 to 11 October, and Fremantle from 16 to 18 October. So that should give the honourable senator plenty of time to get her troops organised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and the Special Minister of State, refers to an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's program AM of 12 September with the Willesee journalist, Martin King, who is the man who entered the Footscray ammunition factory with a camera and was not detected for some 90 minutes. I ask the Minister: Are the departments concerned over King's statement? Despite a spate of reported break-ins at that time, King said:

QUESTION.PARA: I could have taken anything that was manufactured in the munitions depot . . . It was really a terrorists supermarket.

Will the Minister also investigate King's allegation that he had spoken to a Tamil employed at Footscray who claimed to be involved in the racket and who has testimonials from the Department of Defence and a false passport which, according to Mr King, had been arranged for him by a member of parliament at a cost of $8,500? Having regard to the vital importance of security at such munitions depots, has the Australian Federal Police investigated this extraordinary event and the allegations of Mr King? If so, will the Minister report the findings of the Federal Police? If not, will he ask the Federal Police to make inquiries and report to the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I am as briefed as I ought to be on this. But I have learnt, amongst other things, from Senator Grimes that the Tamil in fact turned out to be an Aboriginal claiming to be a Tamil. But I had better confirm that with the Minister responsible before formally committing myself to that proposition. As to the general business that Mr Sinclair initiated-I am not sure whether his Tamil was the same one as Senator Jessop's-I do have a briefing from the Minister, which is in the following terms, and it is the sort of thing he has been saying on the media, but that does not seem to have deterred Senator Jessop from asking the question, so let me repeat it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Ammunition Factory, Footscray, is not missing one million rounds of ammunition or anything like that amount. One million rounds of 7.62 ammunition weighs 44 tonnes and would fill two semi-trailers. This amount, even from the Maribyrnong factory, could not be easily stolen nor could its disappearance be covered up. A concern in 1985 that 25,000 rounds of tracer ammunition were unaccounted for has been investigated. A detailed stocktake has shown that over all the discrepancy at AFF is less than about 1,000 rounds. The concern could not be investigated earlier as an employee in the area concerned was under surveillance and has since been charged.

The Army withdrew an order for one million 5.56 calibre ammunition from AFF. However, this was done because the factory cannot yet make this round, not because of missing stocks. Security measures have been upgraded at the munitions factories over the past nine months to detect and deter intruders and theft. The specifics of some of these security measures that have been implemented and the investigations and legal proceedings in hand should not, for obvious reasons, be gone into here; but apparently there has been a lot of activity taking place in this respect. I will follow it up with the Minister and see whether there is anything more he wants to add in response to the honourable senator's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Minister for Communications will be aware of a recent very heavy snowfall in Hobart-I think it was about a month ago-at which time the Hobart telephone network was simply unable to cope with the telephone traffic until late in the afternoon. I have this on very good authority from Mr Noel Lancaster, the Tasmanian Secretary of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union. Does the Minister agree that such congestion and the consequent lapse of communications could cause significant difficulties in times of emergency? Will the Minister indicate to the Senate what is being considered to overcome this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether I can give Senator Tate the answer that he would probably like to hear to the last part of his question, but I am aware of the effect of the snowfall on communications in Hobart that day. I am advised by Mr Duffy that it was the heaviest fall of snow since early this century and, indeed, one of only three times in this century that snow has actually blanketed the city. The telephone network is planned to cope with normal traffic with the peak time taking place during business hours and on working days. But on 25 July it appears that the majority of Hobart people remained at home and many of them continued to conduct their business activities from their home telephones. As a result there was a grossly distorted traffic pattern, originating in areas where the volume of the traffic and its peak are related to normal residential use. Congestion occurred from about 7 a.m. to about 2 p.m. During this time action was taken to reduce mainland access to the Hobart area to prevent congestion spreading to the mainland originating exchanges.

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom is aware of the need both to economically provide network infrastructure and to ensure that congestion is kept to a minimum by suitable traffic management techniques. However, events such as this, which occur very rarely, cannot realistically be catered for. I might add that the difficulty experienced with the network was not related in any way to maintenance practices, but to the extremely heavy and unusual demand placed on the network from areas designed primarily to cater for residential traffic volumes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to a letter he wrote to me dated 26 August in reply to a letter I had written him about the Government's consideration of the listing of Kakadu National Park stage 2 on the World Heritage List. I quote from the letter-there were other matters that were dealt with-as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: Additionally, I consider the issue of whether or not to seek listing should be settled in consultation with the Northern Territory Government.

I have also written to the Attorney-General about these matters. Will the Minister confirm that no such consultation about the nomination of stage 2 did take place with the Northern Territory Government before yesterday's announcement on Kakadu? If that is the case, why did the Government not consult with the Northern Territory Government before taking its decision to nominate stage 2, and why has it reneged on the undertaking given by Senator Evans in the letter to me, which naturally I gave to the Northern Territory Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there has been any consultation with the Northern Territory Government in the last 48 hours leading up to the announcement of our decision yesterday, and I said as much to a Press conference yesterday on which Senator Durack no doubt is basing his question. I am not aware, however, whether there was any consultation by Mr Cohen, whose ministerial responsibility this was, with the Northern Territory Government on the world heritage listing issue. It is hardly a new issue. It has been around as a statement of government intention for a long time, and I have no doubt there has been communication on that as on other issues, but I will ask Mr Cohen whether he has any further information he may care to supply on that basis.
—He has, I am sure.
—In that case it will be a quick answer, but I will ask him anyway.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to a Press release issued today by Mr Ray Braithwaite, shadow Minister for Trade, claiming that the Commonwealth Government's investigation into the intervention of the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries to provide a $145,000 government loan to a National Party official is based on an incorrect understanding of the guidelines for applying natural disaster funds? Has the Minister also seen comments on this matter by the Queensland Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, the National Party official referred to, Mr Behan, and the Queensland National Party Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Turner? If so, can the Minister clarify the matters that have been raised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can clarify the contradictions but I will come to that matter in a moment. Mr Braithwaite is one of a number of Queensland National Party members who have been thrashing around like headless chooks over the last day or so trying to divert attention from the scandal that their actions have created. Judging by the outcome of those efforts so far, they may be well advised to follow the precedent set by another prominent National Party member and blame their fathers. I am aware of the statement that Mr Braithwaite has put out. He accuses Mr Kerin and me of not knowing that the bank refusal was a prerequisite to potential entitlement to a loan. We are of course well aware of that, but in this case there was much more than a bank refusal, which apparently came from the Commonwealth Bank. There was an assessment of non-viability by the Rural Reconstruction Board, supported, it would appear, by the Agricultural Bank of Queensland and the stock agent Elders Pastoral Co.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Braithwaite is one of those who have joined in the diversion by referring to a police investigation into the source of the leaked documents. It reminds one of one of those ancient despots who used to behead the messenger if he brought bad news-blame the messenger and not the message. That apparently is the practice in Queensland. Regarding the other actors in this farce, tragedy, or whatever it is and the contradictions to which Senator Colston referred, in today's Courier-Mail Mr Behan is quoted as having said:
At no stage did I ever agree or have I been told to sell the property. That is a complete furphy.

Whereas on another page of the Courier-Mail Mr Turner, in seeking to explain away why he intervened and overturned the recommendations of the Rural Reconstruction Board and the bank, tried to explain this away by saying that Mr Behan had indicated a commitment to selling a portion of the property which would substantially reduce the debt structure, and therefore completely change the underlying viability assessment. That is the first contradiction. The second contradiction is even more blatant and more important, I suppose, insofar as it involves the Premier himself. The Courier-Mail reported:
Mr Michael Behan said last night that he had never approached the Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, over loan assistance for the family property . . .
In a different newspaper, the Brisbane Daily Sun, it is reported:
Sir Joh admitted Mr Behan had spoken to him about the loan, but refused to give further details.

Moreover, Mr Turner has admitted, according to other Press reports, that this is not the only time he has intervened and overturned recommendations of the responsible administrative body. Indeed, he is quoted as having said that he overturned them `whenever I have thought it necessary'. That alarms the Commonwealth Government even more than the sordid details of this particular allegation-the clear indication that this is certainly not a one-off. It may not even be aberrant, but this could be just a sample of what is standard practice in Queensland.

The fact is that these funds are provided after a threshold has been passed in a ratio of 3:1 by the Commonwealth Government to provide loans under defined or specified guidelines at a highly concessional interest rate of 4 per cent. There has to be a rationing of the amount of money which is allowed or can be provided under such highly concessional interest rates. Hence, the guidelines which are supposed to be met when assessing individual applications are sent out. In other words, this is a very heavily subsidised means by which the taxpayers of Australia, who include the taxpayers of Queensland, assist farmers who are, first, adjudged to have been the victims of national disasters which could not reasonably be foreseen or insured against and, secondly, are assessed as having the capacity in the longer term to repay those borrowings. It is not a National Party slush fund but it has clearly been treated as such. I shall be shortly communicating with the Queensland Government and asking it to supply a comprehensive list of the natural disaster relief arrangements loans which have been made over at least the last 12 months, and possibly over a further period, and to append to or contain in that list a clear identification of the individual cases in which the recommendations of the Rural Reconstruction Board and/or the Agricultural Bank have been overturned by political decisions within the Queensland Cabinet apparently on the premise that this is just another National Party slush fund which Queensland Ministers can use in whichever way they choose. That is certainly not the case. I want to discharge my responsibilities not only to the taxpayers of Australia as Finance Minister in this Government but also to all those other farmers in Queensland and throughout the rest of the country who met the criteria much more adequately than Mr Behan and were refused loans because, of necessity, the funds are rationed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 August Senator Grimes, representing the Minister for Transport in this place in my absence, was asked a question by Senator Townley in relation to daytime running lights and motor vehicle accidents. The Minister for Transport has provided me with some additional information in response to that particular question. He says:

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that studies have been conducted in Sweden and Canada on the possible influence of daytime running lights.

An evaluation conducted over two years in the late 1970s in Sweden suggested that some savings of injury-related road crashes could possibly have been attributed to the introduction of daytime running lights. Also, the Canadian Government recently conducted pilot studies that supported these findings. The outcome is that from 1 September 1988, Canada has legislated for the use of daytime running lights for passenger cars, trucks and buses and full time headlamps are also to be required for motorcycles. There is therefore evidence that the principle of using daytime running lights may reduce road crashes but it is open to question if this benefit would be demonstrated in Australia. Australia is fortunate in having relatively long periods of sunshine compared to the daily average levels in countries such as Sweden and Canada. There is a consensus of opinion in Australia that enhanced conspicuity can assist with the safety of certain types of vehicles, especially motorcycles. It is possible that these benefits may be deleted if the whole traffic stream uniformly used daytime lights.

The Minister therefore advises me that he has asked the Federal Office of Road Safety in the Department of Transport to monitor developments overseas on the use of daytime running lights. The experience in the northern hemisphere will need to be studied carefully to determine whether the safety benefits achieved there can be translated to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today Senator Reid asked me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Territories, a question relating to interest rates in the Australian Capital Territory. I responded, but unfortunately my hearing let me down in respect of her supplementary question which, on reflection, I am sure she will appreciate was not related to the first question that she raised. There is absolutely no relationship between defence service home loan interest rates and the eligibility of persons to qualify for that concession, and what happens in respect of interest rates in the Australian Capital Territory. I can assure Senator Reid that there is no suggestion at all before the Government that there be any change in the interest rates for defence service home loans.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 17 September, from Senator Chaney:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need during the current Parliamentary sittings for a Mini Budget which contains measures necessary to restore confidence in the Australian economy.'
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need during the current Parliamentary sittings for a Mini Budget which contains measures necessary to restore confidence in the Australian economy.

This is the only day of this sitting week that the Senate has available for debate on various matters, because the rest of our days will be taken up with Estimates committees. Today we have had debates on the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia; we have commenced a further debate on the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986 and later we will debate the important issue of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I suspect that for most people in Australia those are relatively obscure topics which certainly lack any central importance to their lives. The men and women of Australia are today concerned about what will happen to their country, what sort of economic future it holds, what job security they have and what sort of economic security they and their children will have. It is the view of the Opposition that the central national interest is in the future state of our economy and in the prospects for Australia's work force. There is very widespread understanding in 1986 that our country is diminishing when it should be growing. Instead of hope for the future, the Government is delivering despair. We have a diminishing country, a leaderless country; a directionless country under a diminishing Prime Minister. It is now quite clear that Mr Hawke is a Prime Minister for good times. Now that we have passed from good times to bad, he has been shown up as a non-leader. Now that we need leadership and direction to give us hope, he is a shrinking figure.

I remind the Senate that the Budget is expressly about trimming Australian living standards. That is not what the Opposition has talked about; that is what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) talked about in the Budget Speech. The Opposition believes that that would be all right if it were part of an active plan for economic recovery and it held out some hope for the future of Australians. In fact, the Budget does not do that. If one looks at the Budget's assessment, the Government's own assessment, of what will happen over the next 12 months one sees continuing high inflation, worsening unemployment, reduced private investment and the prospect of reduced growth. In this context the Government is telling the people of Australia that they are in a diminishing situation, both personally and nationally.

The Opposition's view is that that is not a necessary situation and it is a situation which ought to be addressed by the Government if it is to be regarded as fit to govern this country. We believe that it is incumbent upon the Government to act now so that that situation can be reversed and some hope can be held out. Since the Budget we have had tantalising suggestions from Government Ministers-from Senator Button in particular and also from Senator Walsh-that changes could be made. In Question Time today Senator Walsh told us that the Government has a paper which examines Commonwealth and State programs and their staffing and he says that, as any diligent government would do, the Government has examined whether economies can be made. The Opposition says that the Government should certainly address that and address it in the active way that was promised by Senator Button, although that promise was withdrawn by him when he was challenged in the next 24 hours. We believe that the Government must act, and act during the current parliamentary sittings. In other words, it is not a matter which should be left for 12 months while the country languishes. We believe also that it is not a matter of the Government simply bringing in a Budget which addresses itself to the fiscal situation in Australia. We believe that the Government should at the same time be addressing itself to other vital issues which are the inhibiting factors preventing economic recovery and preventing the people of Australia from having hope for the future.

The Government not only needs to bring in a mini-Budget, but also needs to encompass in that mini-Budget a sensible approach to the labour market, to the vexed question of wage fixing and to the question of labour market practices. It also needs to address itself to the anti-incentive elements of the taxation system which are discouraging investment in business and employment instead of encouraging it, and it needs to address the issue of costly overregulation, which the Government itself has estimated costs business between $40,000m and $80,000m a year. We have said it before and I repeat it now: There is nothing that can be done in a Budget alone that will change investment circumstances in Australia and put us back on the path to recovery and growth. The Government must, in the form of a mini-Budget, take a more responsible fiscal stance and do something about the excessive government expenditure which still impedes our recovery but, at the same time, it must tackle those other vital things which prevent people in business from getting on with the job of creating new employment and wealth for Australia.

As part of this debate I think the Opposition must indicate what it sees as being wrong with the Budget and the sort of issue that needs to be addressed and addressed urgently by the Government. We believe that the taxation settings of the Budget are absolutely wrong. Quite apart from the anti-business taxes, which we have made clear should be repealed, we find that the Government has in this Budget added new taxes of $1.4 billion. I suppose the most evident tax to the taxpayers and the ordinary citizens of this country is the increase in the price of petrol which this Government has imposed upon them by additional excise. But there is $1.4 billion of new taxes and in addition at the moment the public is suffering the loss of the tax reduction which was promised by the Government and which has been delayed by it at a cost of some $650m.

There is something over $2 billion in tax penalties in this Budget and one has to ask the question: Is this a time when the troubles of Australia are going to be reduced by tax increases rather than reversed? I think that if the Government is prepared to listen to the people of Australia on that question it will hear a resounding no. In addition to that, the Budget takes a total in additional taxes of $6.5 billion. Again I mention that because, quite clearly, the people of Australia understand what the Hawke and Keating Government does not understand; that an ever growing tax burden is the worst way to solve our problems of a loss of growth and a growing unemployment problem.

In the 1986-87 Budget we found a fiddling of the figures that has to be reversed by this Government. I have already mentioned the deferral of personal income tax cuts which has been used to help reduce the deficit. I mentioned the putting back of pension indexation, a simple reminder to the pensioners of Australia and the other welfare beneficiaries of Australia that they are beginning to pay the price of this Government's profligacy. That was another $300m in one-off savings. It was a penalty imposed on the pensioners and other people who are dependent upon the Government for support. There is the deferral of the medical fee rise, another $85m crib. This is another sign of the Government's desperation to do something about the deficit. I stress that these are one-off savings like the profits from the Reserve Bank of Australia and they do nothing to ease the problem for the Government in terms of the basic structural deficit, the problem that it faces next year and the judgment, indeed, of the international market.

TALK.START.PARA: —John Howard should know about that. The $10 billion man.

—The Minister is starting to interject. He has been loud in his denial that there would be any serious problem that would in any way compare with past problems of the current account deficit and yet we find that we have a record deficit of $13.7 billion. It is estimated at 5.9 per cent of gross domestic product. It is said that that will be the status quo for this country, that we are going to continue to have a deficit of that sort. In the same way we are going to have inflation at 8.4 per cent when the average for our major trading partners is 1.8 per cent; we have an inadequate commitment to wage discounting; we have an outlook for investment which, in the Government's own prediction, is for decline and that mirrors the decline for the last three quarters; and we have dubious growth forecasts where most international commentators and national commentators have suggested that the Government's growth forecasts are simply not likely to be fulfilled.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the situation that we have been handed by the Government. On its own assessment Australia is in decline. We are in a declining investment situation. We are not going to improve on our unemployment figures, rather the reverse, and we are in a situation where our external figures are going to remain so bad that we will be maintaining, as the Treasurer has said, high interest rates into the future.

Since the Budget has been brought out, what has been the impact? We have had a financial market reaction which has been adverse. I could quote commentators in New York, London and Tokyo, all of whom damn this Budget and say that it will not work. We find that interest rates have soared to a seven-month high; money markets have risen by 2 per cent since the Budget, the prime rate is around 19 per cent and home loans are now coming under great pressure. Interest rates which are, of course, an important barrier to activity and investment are rising and the Treasurer tells us that they will stay at those high levels through next year.

This is what the Government has given us in the Budget so far. Since the Budget we have a balance of payments figure for August of $1.2 billion. That is greeted as something which is livable because it is less than the $1.5 billion for the month before. Unemployment is stuck on the 8.3 per cent figure to which it rose in July and the Westpac Banking Corporation, in conjunction with the Melbourne Institute, say that we face protracted recession. We have consumer confidence registered at its lowest ever level and we again have the Confederation of Australian Industry and Westpac in a survey of Australian business indicating that 70 per cent of manufacturers expect worse ahead.

If we believe that the economy must recover, if we are to ease the position of the people of Australia, what more depressing fact could we get than the announcement by the Confederation of Australian Industry with the Westpac Banking Corporation, after a survey taken in the first two weeks of September this year-after the Budget-that 70 per cent of respondents expect the general business situation to worsen in the next six months. They advise that the same trend was reflected in a further downward revision of capital expenditure plans for the next 12 months. We have a continued decline in investment in buildings and in plant and machinery and this is expected by the highest proportion of respondents since June 1983 despite the fact that finance is only slightly more difficult to obtain.

It is clear from all of these things, including the opinion polls, that the majority of voters say that the Budget will harm them. We have the worst public reaction to the Budget since 1981. There is really no prospect being held out by this Government of this Budget for any hope at all. One wonders at the mentality of the Government, one wonders at the mentality of the Ministers who are prepared to say that it is good enough to simply hold out for Australia for another 12 months this prospect of no improvement. We have a situation where effectively the Government has washed its hands. It has said that we are incapable of producing a change in this doleful situation. It is the view of the Opposition that it is essential that the Government move on this matter and change its policy settings so that we are not left slopping around in the bottom of the boat as a council of despair. We have a situation where there are changes which could be made. The Opposition, among many other people, has been holding out to the Government clear indications of changes which could be made and yet we have the Government resisting.

TALK.START.PARA: —What changes?

—I will come to what changes are going to be made. Let me say that I welcomed what seemed to be a rush of honesty to Senator Button's head as reported in the Age newspaper of 8 September. It is rather sad that in the Senate yesterday Senator Button, as he did on 9 September, chose to recant from his burst of honesty earlier in the day. When honourable senators see the lengthy report of Michelle Grattan on the interview she did with Senator Button they will find the clearest possible statements from him that the Government could do more on the spending side and that it is capable of bringing in changes. Senator Button was quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a mini-Budget `must be a possibility . . . Whether you glorify it with the expression mini-Budget or not, there is room, I believe, for further cuts in certain areas of Government expenditure . . .
On the same morning on the AM program he made comments. He said specifically:
I made that comment in the light of the question about what the Government had to do in the next 6 months or so having regard to the state of the economy and the current account problem.

The simple point is that we had the clearest possible indication from Senator Button made in that interview and confirmed on radio on that same morning that the Government had within its hands the capacity to move. Of course it has been a sorry fact that the Treasurer has since insisted that there will be no change over the financial year. Even though Senator Walsh himself has made a comment where he makes it clear that spending cuts will be possible, it would appear that the Government has locked itself in. Senator Walsh was quoted in the Age of 13 September as saying in Perth:
Perhaps later this financial year; I think it's unlikely in this calendar year.
Senator Walsh conceded the possibility of cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not. That was taken from an inaccurate-indeed, doctored-ABC interview.

—The Minister will speak soon and no doubt he will put his view. If all the Minister can do is say that the Government is locked in to the status quo for the next 12 months and that it is not capable of moving on the budgetary front and those other essential fronts I have mentioned, the country has clearly been sold down the river by this Government and this Minister, because it is clearly possible for something to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point I want to make about this Government's record is to note the downgrading of our credit rating by Moody's Investor Services Inc. and to remind the Senate that not even Jim Cairns was able to reduce the reputation of this Government in quite the way Mr Keating has now managed to do. If one looks at what Moody's has said about the Australian economy, one gets a bearing out of the positive points I wish to make in the balance of this debate on what is required to be done. What Moody's pointed out as part of its report on what is wrong with this country and why we have lost our AAA rating is that industrial and labour market rigidities are further expected to hamper the country's efforts to shift economic resources into areas with high foreign exchange earning capacity. What Moody's is saying, in everyday language, is that the way we run our trade union system and our labour market and the sorts of ridiculous work practices which have received so much publicity over recent times are all factors which are impeding our economic recovery. This Government has to be prepared to tackle these things, but to date it has shown itself to be incapable of tackling them.

The positives which have been asserted by the Opposition have been asserted by the shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and many other spokesmen for the Opposition. We have said that the present Budget should be recast. We say that there is a need for further genuine cuts in Government spending. If Senator Walsh asks where those cuts should be made, I refer him to the statements made by Mr Howard and published by us in our `Policies for Business' document, where we list many of the changes which could be made. I remind the Senate that this is the situation: The Government has been in office for 3 1/2 years and the Minister says that, like any good government, it has been looking at these matters. I challenge him to tell the Senate what cuts the Government is considering and believes could be made. We have said that there can be many changes, such as the abolition of many of the unnecessary Government bodies, the transferring of functions to the States, the restructuring of some of our income maintenance programs and substantial changes to Medicare and health policies. These are areas that we have said, were we in government now, would be subject to examination and action. I ask the Minister to say what areas he, as the Minister for Finance, will tackle to do something about the overspending of his Government and the resultant overtaxing by his Government. We call upon the Government to remove the anti-investment taxes.

It is clear from talking to anyone in the small business sector-the sector which has the capacity to react quickly and create new jobs quickly-about the impact of the capital gains tax, the anti-entertainment tax and the fringe benefits tax that the same message is coming through. On the one hand, we get lectures from this Government and the trade union movement saying that businesses should invest and, on the other hand, the Government imposes a series of taxes which make businessmen feel that further investment in Australia is worthless and make the fund managers of Australia look overseas for their investment, to the detriment of this country. We believe that the final foreign investment restrictions should be removed because they are illogical and nonsensical, given Australia's demands and needs for inflow of funds over the next few years.

We believe it is essential that the Government toughens its wages policy. The present Budget indicates a quite inadequate response to wages policy. We believe that in a mini-Budget the Government should argue for the full effect of any currency changes being taken into account at the next national wage case. We say also that the Government should be arguing that any inflationary impact from the Budget decisions, particularly those affecting petrol prices and health care, should be subject to discounting. I again say to the Minister: Do you not agree that those are proper matters for discounting and that wage rises based on increases in costs are economic nonsense? Yet the Government is not committed to arguing against those before the arbitration authorities.

Finally, the Government has to give leadership in tackling labour market rigidity generally and restrictive work practices in particular. The Government has to get off the fence in this area, has to stop holding hands with its trade union mates and has to genuinely give the lead to both the trade union movement and employers in rooting out these ridiculous practices which render Australia so inefficient. If Senator Walsh had been here last night to hear Senator Button talking about the efforts to move restrictive work practices in the heavy engineering industry and had heard the evidence given about the slowness of the processes which have been undertaken by the Government, he would understand better why there is so little faith in the Government in this vital area. We believe that Australia has great economic prospects and that it can provide higher living standards for its people. We believe that this Government has condemned Australia to diminished living standards, and that should be changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fascinated by the hypothesis put by Senator Chaney just before the end of his speech-the hypothesis of retrospective causation-that is, that prospective taxes have caused the present problems. I have also noted his non-specificity on the particular expenditure changes the Opposition believes should be made, which he tells me were outlined in some tatty business document circulated recently by the Opposition. I am afraid that I did not read that. I do not have it with me and I do not know what is in it, but I know that the shadow Treasurer, Mr Carlton, said at the National Press Club three weeks ago that he was not going to spell out the specifics of what an alternative government would do on the expenditure side because if he were to do that he would be gelding himself-that was his term. I therefore wonder whether this business document, the details of which Senator Chaney chose not to reveal, constitutes a gelding mechanism from Mr Carlton; but the shadow Treasurer has flatly refused to give any details. We know why-because the details will be dictated by the extreme Right, which is on the brink of taking over the Liberal Party of Australia. It is a very serious matter for responsible Australians in general-I am sure this view is shared by a lot of members inside the Liberal Party-that there is a prospect of right wing extremists taking over the Liberal Party. That they are on the brink of doing so is just as frightening as the Australian Labor Party being taken over by Trotskyists. The latter has never been a real possibility in Australia; the former, I regret to say, is. That must be a matter of deep concern not only to non-partisan Australians but also to those members of the Liberal Party in Sydney, for example, who have spent the last decade or so fighting the uglies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is determined to have a mini-Budget. Let me make this perfectly clear: There will be no mini-Budget. Fiscal policy has been set for this financial year in the Budget released last month. There is no need for this Government to have a mini-Budget, because this Government does not produce figures which are rubbery, nor a Budget strategy which has failed to address the fundamental problems. In that context it may be contrasted with what occurred under the previous Government. I have got out today a few Press clippings from 1982 with headlines such as this: `Howard puts record straight on Budget'. That article was dated 10 March 1982 and states:

In a special statement to Parliament yesterday, the Treasurer, Mr Howard, said the Government first became aware of the prospective deficit overrun towards the end of November, and not the end of December as he had previously indicated.

He was caught out. He said it was towards the end of December; in fact, it was the end of November. The Public Service was so angry about being blamed for the Government fiddling the figures-that is, the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, fiddling the figures-that there were angry murmurings that the truth might be revealed. That is alluded to later in this story in the Australian Financial Review, where it is reported:

Mr Howard also addressed himself to the point made by the Financial Review yesterday that some senior bureaucratic advisers were angry at the way in which Mr Fraser had implied that it was they, rather than Cabinet, who were responsible for the blowout.

That is the Budget deficit blow-out, of course. But that was not the real deficit blow-out over which the former Treasurer presided. The real deficit blow-out over which he presided was the next year, in his final 1982-83 Budget. In the Australian of 11 March 1983, for example, it is reported:
The acting Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr John Howard, yesterday denied any dishonesty in his failure to disclose deficit projections in the last week of the election campaign.
Mr Howard said he had discussed with the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, Treasury estimates showing the deficit was higher than the $6 billion he and other government leaders were quoting.

The truth is, of course, that this most rubbery former Treasurer, the India rubber man who was Treasurer at the time, the expert at producing rubbery figures, deliberately concealed from the nation the fact that what was looming at the time he lost government was a deficit not of $6 billion but of almost $10 billion. If a government is going to produce Budgets with rubbery figures, such as those which the present Leader of the Opposition was accustomed to producing, there may be a need to produce mini-Budgets. There is no need to produce mini-Budgets when the figures are not rubbery and when they are honest estimates, honestly presented, as they have been this year and, indeed, in all the years since this Government came into office.

Senator Chaney said, correctly-one of the few things he said correctly-that the aim of this Budget is to trim living standards. That is true; it is. That is because the fact is that the changing terms of trade-that is, the declining prices for the things Australia sells overseas-have wiped $6 billion, $6,000m, off national income. That is an income loss which cannot be accommodated without an appropriate decline in average living standards. Of course there are political difficulties-one would be a fool to deny this-for any government which presides over a decline, in the short term, in average living standards as this Government is fated to do. We accept that responsibility and we have set an appropriate policy for longer term recovery. But there is nothing that can be done in the short term about that catastrophic decline in the prices paid by other countries for the things Australia sells.

It is true, as Senator Chaney said, that we have had a large current account deficit. For those who are not familiar with the jargon, that means the difference between the value of the things, the goods and services, we sell overseas and the things that we buy. That is not new. We have been running for the last six years a current account deficit of between 4 per cent and 6 per cent of gross domestic product. Incidentally, the record, the highest current account deficit, was in 1981-82, not while this Government has been in office. The large current account deficits of that time were strongly associated with the so-called resources boom which never actually happened. But the cost of servicing those foreign debts hangs over the economy still. It is true that there was a substantial, though declining, current account deficit in the first two years of this Government. We were getting on top of it and then we were hit with the collapse in the terms of trade of the order, as the Budget Papers show, of 10 per cent on average for 1985-86 over 1984-85, with a forecast further decline of, on average, 8 per cent for 1986-87 over 1985-86. We had a pre-existing fragile current account due largely to the financial servicing charges of the huge borrowings associated with the resources boom which never happened. That pre-existing fragile current account was hit with a terms of trade collapse the size of which had not been seen since 1930.

Let us look at the origin of those problems. The problem we now face certainly has not been caused by wage outcomes. For the three calendar years from 1983 to 1985, real wages in Australia fell by 3 per cent-and have fallen more since. In the United Kingdom they increased by 11 per cent; in Japan they increased by 5 per cent. In the United Kingdom, unemployment was rising from just above 10 per cent to above 13 per cent. A stridently anti-union government was pursuing anti-union legislation; yet real wages increased by 11 per cent. In Australia, real wages fell in a period of high and sustained economic growth and falling unemployment. There is no precedent in Australian history for that outcome of declining real wages accompanied by falling unemployment and high and sustained economic growth. Real wages needed to fall because of the wages blow-outs of 1981 and 1982 of 13 per cent and 14 per cent respectively. So it is true that neither inflation nor any of our ills are attributable to wage outcomes. The accord has delivered the wage outcomes which the economic situation demanded.

It is true that our inflation rate is higher than those of most of our trading partners and, indeed, that there is operating in many countries a wages-inflation paradox whereby countries in which real wages have increased-this is not true for all countries, but it is true for a great number-have falling rates of inflation. Australia, where real wages have fallen, has accelerating price levels. The common answer to that apparent paradox is the change in commodity prices. Inflation in Australia is not being driven by wage outcomes but by rising import prices directly attributable to the devaluation, which in turn has been caused by the collapse in our terms of trade. On the other hand, the countries which have had significant real wage increases yet declining levels of inflation have been the beneficiaries of those commodity price falls.

The real origin of Australia's present economic problem goes back many decades. It is related partly to the slow downward trend in the relative prices of the things that we export. One can get different figures depending on where one chooses to take the starting point, but over the last three or four decades a reasonable figure for the rate at which the relative prices for the things that Australia exports, minerals and agricultural products, have been falling is about one per cent a year. Secondly, it is related essentially to the internationally uncompetitive nature of Australian manufacturing, attributable to a very significant degree to the economic policies of the 1960s, the architect of which was the Leader of the Country Party, and, further back, to the economic policies, I suppose, of the 1920s. Thirdly, in more recent times, the uncompetitiveness of Australian manufacturing industry was aggravated by a deliberate policy of maintaining an overvalued Australian dollar in the late 1970s and early 1980s as a substitute for a wages policy. Fourthly, it relates to the debt hangover from the resources boom which never happened, to which I referred in more detail earlier. Finally, it relates to a taxation system which encouraged speculation and the dissipation of the nation's scarce investable domestic capital, instead of its investment in activities which would be self-sustaining and which would promote continuing economic growth.

I want to digress here to take one specific example, that of the fringe benefits tax and the motor vehicle industry. It was asserted and mindlessly echoed by the Opposition that the fringe benefits tax application would cause a catastrophic decline in motor vehicle sales. Of course, that was exaggerated. But, to the extent that it was true, it demonstrated that, because of a tax distortion, scarce investment capital was being directed into the purchase of motor vehicles for which there was no functional economic need. In other words, the absence of a fringe benefits tax and the developments in the provision of fringe benefits which had taken place had together set up a mechanism or a formula by which the nation's scarce investable capital was misdirected into a tax haven, that is, the excessive purchase of motor vehicles for which there was no functional economic need. That is a very important symptom of this country's fundamental problems.

Far from the so-called anti-investment taxes of this Government's tax reform package doing damage to the economy and to self-sustaining growth, they are an essential component of a policy package that will ensure that growth. It is worth mentioning the fundamental illogicality of the Opposition's hypothesis of retrospective causation, that prospective taxes have caused the present problems. The only long term answer, other than a large and continuing decline in living standards-unless one believes that the relative price trends for commodities and other goods and services will be reversed, and there is no reason to believe that they will be-is to develop an internationally competitive manufacturing industry. That is what this Government was doing and had done.

The wage outcomes delivered by the accord had wound back the effects of the wages explosions of 1981 and 1982. The consumer price index had fallen from above 11 per cent to around 5 per cent. The level of industrial disputation was the lowest it had been for 17 years. The profit share of product had been restored to the levels of the late 1960s. In key industries, significant structural change had already been achieved. In the steel industry labour productivity had increased by almost 30 per cent. The motor vehicle industry was becoming more competitive, as were the shipbuilding, heavy engineering and even to some extent the chronically sick textile, footwear and clothing industries. All that had happened. In early 1985 the first devaluation of the Australian dollar further and substantially aided international competitiveness. The accord had delivered the wage adjustment that that initial devaluation required. Then, towards the end of last year, it became apparent that we were being hit with not a minor but a catastrophic decline in the terms of trade, the size of which probably had not occurred since 1930, and there was a further devaluation of the Australian dollar which has made the Australian economy massively competitive in an international sense. The accord will deliver the wage adjustment that further decline of the Australian currency requires.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you really believe that.

—As the Leader of the Opposition used to say, the runs are on the board. The accord has delivered so far and it will deliver in the future. I say to Senator Sheil that, if the accord cannot do that, nothing else can.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the supreme ironies of contemporary politics is the fact that the left wing extremists of the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia have exactly the same wages policy as the right wing extremists who pull the strings that move John Howard-that is, they want wage outcomes to be determined in the market-place. That has been tried. The previous Government tried it in 1981 and 1982. What happened? There was a wages explosion because there was a short lived period of high economic growth. Under the accord, three years of sustained high economic growth have delivered a decline in real wages. I suppose it comes down to whether one is more interested in outcomes than in processes. The extremists of the Right who are on the brink of taking over the Liberal Party of Australia are clearly more interested in processes. They are more interested in the methods than in the outcomes. This Government is interested in outcomes. The outcome on the wages front has been delivered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of urgency that we are debating refers to the need for a mini-Budget to restore confidence in the economy. I believe that the actual wording of this matter of urgency indicates the narrowness of political perceptions in this country. What the Opposition really means by the need for a mini-Budget to restore confidence in the economy is that it wants to restore the confidence of the international money markets in the Australian economy. The Government's whole Budget was framed with this in mind. It was framed for the international money markets; it was an attempt to restore confidence in the Australian economy. What we need now is not a mini-Budget. We need a fundamental change in economic direction in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The present Government's strategy is wrong; it is misguided and it will strangle the economy. It will have the effect of pushing an economy already in recession into deep depression. It will have the effect of placing a disastrous burden on working Australians. It will cause heart-rending devastation to families already in poverty. It will cause hunger to families of retrenched persons in single income families and it will create enormous problems for young children.

But, worst of all, this Government has left unscathed the huge profits of money speculators. It has left untouched the rape of Australian industries by overseas companies. By disbanding the Foreign Investment Review Board at the very time when the Australian dollar has been devalued to its lowest level in memory, our Australian owned industries will be left open to takeover at bargain basement prices.

Members of the Government have travelled up and down this country to sell the Budget. The Government has said how brave it is to introduce an austerity Budget at this time; so far it has got away with that. It has got away with it because fundamentally it has brought down a Budget identical in strategy to the Budget for which the Opposition and big business were calling. The only difference between what has been said by the Opposition and what the Government has done in this Budget is that the Opposition believes that there should be more austerity, bigger cuts, further discounting of wages and deregulation of the labour market. That last strategy, which has just been enunciated by Senator Chaney, is open to very severe criticisms. Two days ago on AM no less a specialist in industrial relations than Brian Powell, the Director of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, said that he did not see how the labour markets could be substantially deregulated in Australia without creating enormous industrial turmoil. The Opposition should take note of that comment. If it really believes that deregulation of the labour markets is the salvation of our economic problems, it has a responsibility to show in great detail how it would deregulate the labour markets and get away from centralised wage fixing. The Australian Democrats have at least introduced a Bill that would allow collective agreements to be worked out in association with a centralised wage fixing process. We need a change of direction.

The fundamental problem with the Australian economy is simply that for the last 30 years we have been borrowing money overseas to balance our trade deficit. Borrowing money is not in itself a bad thing. It is not a bad thing to borrow money to invest in wealth creating industries if one is sure that meeting the interest commitments on the amount borrowed is within the bounds of one's ability. Neither of those two criteria is being met at the moment by the Australian Government. Australia is like a reckless family that has borrowed too much and spent unwisely. It is like a reckless family that is faced with the prospect of not being able to meet its interest commitments on the money it has borrowed.

What would a family do in such a situation? I suggest that the first thing that it would do is stop borrowing and work harder in an attempt to find the money to pay the commitments on the money it had already borrowed. Also, it would set about trying to produce, itself, the things that it no longer had the money to buy. The Government has given no such lead in the Budget. In fact, it still encourages big business to borrow overseas to make and invest in paper profits on the takeover trail-that is, to make money out of money. The Government has done nothing to encourage money borrowed overseas into productive investments. We see the criminal waste of borrowed money in things such as tanker loads of orange juice coming in from Brazil to be put on the Australian market at a time when our battling fruit growers in the Murray Valley are letting their oranges drop to the ground because, as was pointed out in a recent survey, if they pick them they will each lose $15,000 this year. They will lose $15,000 this year if they stay in business. If that is not slave labour, I do not know what is; and if that is not an absolutely criminal waste of borrowed money on which all Australia must pay the interest, I do not know what is. It is absolutely infantile to pursue the present course.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no slave labour, just labour.

—Slave labour is getting people to work without paying them a living wage. That is precisely what is happening. In the time available to me, I want to be constructive. I shall list 10 fundamental points of principle that the Democrats, in government, would ensure were implemented. Firstly, we must get our overseas trade account into balance. We must stop borrowing money. Secondly, we must stop overseas companies purchasing our wealth producing industries at rock bottom prices. We must strengthen the FIRB; not disband it, as the Government is doing. Thirdly, we must convert the Department of Trade into a Ministry of International Trade and Industry-type organisation on the Japanese model where there is a mechanism for co-operation between government, industry and the trade union movement. We should rename the Department of Trade the department of international trade and investment.

SPEECH.PARA: Fourthly, we should revamp the Department of the Treasury to cleanse it of the discredited monetarists who are still dominating its policies. Fifthly, we must encourage worker participation if we are to create efficient internationally competitive industries. There is nothing in the Budget about encouraging employee participation-the policy that the Japanese have so successfully used to develop an industrial machine that today is the envy of the world. We have done nothing in that respect. Six months ago I introduced a Bill on employee participation. So far, I have not been able to get the Government's agreement to debate that Bill in the Senate.

Sixthly, we must encourage small business and entrepreneurship in this country. It is through small business that we will develop the innovative industries that will be export competitive. Seventhly, we must apply orderly marketing to primary production in the interests of eliminating the enormous fluctuations in the prices that our farmers receive for their labour. Eighthly, we must create a nuclear-free Pacific. Ninthly, we must share the available work among the entire work force so that there is no unemployment. We cannot continue with such enormous levels of unemployment. Surely the fair thing to do is to have flexible working hours so that the available work can be shared. Tenthly, we must face up to and encourage a multicultural Australia.

Often the Democrats are accused of jumping on bandwagons, of talking principles and not getting down to the nitty gritty. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Democrats' alternative Budget. Our policies have been worked out in great detail. The figures are available and can be studied.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN DEMOCRAT ALTERNATIVE BUDGET (14.8.86)

The Australian Democrat alternative budget has been produced as a practical demonstration of how the Party's policy platform would be implemented. It demonstrates that our present economic problems can be addressed without the austerity measures advocated by the Government, the Opposition and financial markets. Austerity will bring depression, not economic recovery.

Although the Democrat budget proposes a deficit only slightly higher than the figure the Government is aiming for, personal income tax is reduced and spending is increased significantly in important areas.
The Government tax cuts have been maintained and a further $1,000m has been foregone through the introduction of tax indexation.

The family allowance has been increased by 88% and Government cuts in health, welfare, education and payments to the States have been neutralised. Additional funds have been channelled to public housing.
Industry has received aid through technology transfers, employee participation and the abolition of payroll tax.

These measures will be financed through improvements in bureaucratic efficiency, retargeting of welfare expenditure to areas of need and the closing of loopholes exploited by some big companies at great expense to the honest taxpayer.
