Payroll Tax-This tax is a tax on jobs. It will be abolished over three years and the Federal government will reimburse the States, who levy the tax, for the loss of revenue.

Technology Transfer a Worker Participation-These measures are necessary to stimulate efficiency in the manufacturing sector. Their application has been fully explained in Democrat bills currently before the Senate.

Family allowances-The dependant spouse rebate has been scrapped and the resulting funds used to increase family allowance payments by 88%. The family allowance will be taxed in the hands of the recipient parent.

Education-Extra funds have been provided for building and maintenance works in tertiary institutions. These areas have been starved of funds for many years resulting in a reduction of education opportunities and deterioration of buildings and equipment.
States-Extra payments have been made to the States for industrial restructuring and transport upgrading.
Housing-Funds have been directed to ease the chronic shortage of public housing in all States.

Defence-The defence budget has been reduced by $250 million. This reduction has been made possible through increased efficiencies in running the department and the defence forces. Details are set out in a Democrat defence paper.
REVENUES
Personal Income Tax-In addition to the Government's $1,000m promised tax cuts (effective 1.12.86), the Democrats propose the following measures:
$ 121 m + Taxation of family allowances
$1,326 m + Abolition of Dependant Spouse Rebate
$1,000 m - Full tax indexation
$ 552 m - Full imputation of dividends
$ 105 m - Reduction in income tax collections
Full tax indexation will be introduced to prevent inflation eroding living standards.
Full imputation of dividends will be implemented to encourage investments. There will be no compensatory increase in the company tax rate.
Takeover Loopholes-An extra $1,254m will be collected by closing the takeover borrowing loophole.

Transfer Pricing-The practice of tax avoidance through transfer pricing will be greatly reduced through the designation of notional values to exported goods with reference to world prices. This measure will raise $500m.
Capital Export Tax-A tax of 5% would be levied on movements of capital out of Australia to protect the currency and encourage local investment. This tax would raise $550m per year.
Imports Tax-To combat the balance of trade deficit a tax would be placed on selected imports, mainly luxury items, at 6.5%. This would raise $450m.

Economic Growth Figure-Democrat policies and budget initiatives would result in a further increase in GDP of the order of 2% or $3,000m. This would net the Government a further $1,000m in revenues due to increased taxes generated and a decrease in welfare spending.
Growth would be generated by the stimulus to consumption of the increased outlays and the stimulus to productive investment provided by the tax changes and general policy initiatives.
Family Allowance Details-At present family allowances cost the Government $1,505m per year. The Democrats proposal would increase this by 88% ($1,326m), bringing the total cost up to $2,831m.
The average payment to families at present is $686.84 per year. This would increase to $1,291.25.
The family allowance would be means tested and taxed in the hands of the principal child carer. This would raise $121 million per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In our alternative Budget we have carefully worked out the figures. We came up with a deficit only slightly higher than the Government's deficit, so it is a responsible alternative Budget. However, we have done something about the tax rorts and the negative gearing of big business. We have done something about reducing the flow of luxury imports that we do not need and can do without. Such methods can be incorporated in a Budget which is responsible and which does not create a large deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to some of the initiatives that the Opposition has suggested we should embrace. The Opposition has said, among other things, that we should have income splitting. That would cost $2 billion. It has suggested that we should repeal the assets test, at a cost of $140 billion; that we should abolish the fringe benefits tax, at a cost of $320m; and that we should remove the tax on lump sum superannuation, at a cost of $100m. The Opposition's suggestions for greater austerity would cost a lot of money. I do not see how the Opposition can continue to say that it would introduce such policies and at the same time keep the deficit within bounds. I believe that the Opposition has a very real responsibility to cost out its proposals and to put them into a Budget context that allows everyone to see precisely how they would be worked out in detail.

Senator Chaney said that the present Budget trimmed Australians' living standards. The Democrats could not agree more. There will be cuts in health and in education. There will be cuts in the bounties available to industry at a time when we want to create employment and produce in Australia so that we do not have to buy so many imports. Bounties will be cut, with the inevitable result that industries will go bankrupt. The Democrats are not prepared to accept that. When the various Budget Bills come before this chamber and we debate cuts in education and welfare and reductions in bounties for industries, we will oppose those cuts. They are unnecessary. It is the wrong approach. It is fundamentally the wrong direction in which to go. The Democrats have come up with alternative policies that can be funded, and those policies tackle the fundamental problem.

The fundamental problem is that for 30 years we have borrowed money and we can no longer pay the interest payments on that borrowed money. Therefore, we must stop borrowing money. If we put a 6.5 per cent tax on luxury imports only-that is, about one-fifth of our current imports-that one initiative would raise $250m alone.

Responsible commentators have pointed out that if the tax rort on negative gearing on takeovers in this country were eliminated, the Government would gain a further $1.5 billion in company tax. That figure has been substantiated by responsible journalists in this country. Yet nothing has been done about it. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) refuses to look into it. Certain responsible back benchers in the Government and in the Senate have brought the problem of negative gearing in corporate takeovers to the Treasurer's attention and he has refused to act on it. An amount of $1.5 billion is involved. We could do something about encouraging people to put the money that we can still borrow overseas into productive investments. If we use money wisely to create wealth producing industries, we can get ourselves out of our problem. But, if we keep borrowing money to buy consumer products, there is no doubt that the country is headed for bankruptcy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need during the current Parliamentary sittings for a Mini Budget which contains measures necessary to restore confidence in the Australian economy.

Senator Siddons, at the outset of his speech, made out that we were just suggesting that the measures would be instituted to satisfy the international money market. That would be the last thing that I would be worried about. At the moment, the confidence of all the small businesses in this country is at a minimal level. That is where we must get confidence back. For many years, I have been attempting to point out some of the problems mentioned by Senator Siddons. I have done so in speech, question and motion. I have tried to point out the way in which the economy has been heading downhill because of the insatiable appetite of the Australian Labor Party in wanting to spend any part of the taxpayers' money that it can possibly collect along with anything that it can possibly borrow.

It has been mentioned that the world's greatest Treasurer of last year is now the world's greatest borrower. That is not quite true. He is not quite the world's greatest borrower but, if he keeps going at his present rate, he soon will be. Even blind Freddy could understand that, if one keeps spending more than the amount raised in revenue, eventually the total debt catches up with one. Every housewife and businessman around the country knows that. It seems that the only group that does not is the Labor Party.

Why do I not blame Mr Fraser? Everyone else seems to blame him and Mr Howard. I do not do so for good reason. Past Budget figures show that Mr Fraser and Mr Howard were well aware of the danger towards which the country was heading and were making attempts to do something about it. The deficits in the last three years of Mr Fraser's term were reduced from $3,449m in 1978-79 to $2,016m the next year, down to $1,105m the next year and $576m in 1981-82. When Labor won office in February 1983, it let the expenditure cat out of the bag. In 1982-83, the deficit rose to $4,467m. The year after that it reached the horrific level of $7,960m. The year after that it was $6,746m and then it went down to $4,919m. This year the Labor Government has made an attempt-with rubbery figures, I admit-to get the deficit down.

Of course, Labor blames Mr Howard. I do not believe that the electorate believes Labor any more. It has just been doing this for too long. Anyway, the people of the country expect the Government of the country to fix up what is happening. The blame cannot be pinned on anyone else but on the world's greatest borrower. The Labor Party has not been able to make the cuts in government spending that needed to be made in years gone by, so our indebtedness has continued to escalate. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table showing our debt per head compared with that of some other countries. I have shown it to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is seventh on that list, with Canada, Norway, Denmark, Sweden, New Zealand and Finland ahead of us. The Senate might be interested to find that our debt per head of population is greater than that in Argentina, Mexico and Brazil, among many others. Those three countries are the `bad boys' of the economic scene in South America. One of our big worries is that our debt is increasing rapidly-from $2,600 per head in 1984 to $3,200 per head in 1985-yet Mr Keating pretended that that surprised him. He should not have been surprised because, for a long time, many of us were telling him, in one way or another, that we could see the catastrophe that lay ahead for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that in May 1985 I moved a motion that pointed out just how much in debt we were. I mentioned then that we had to recognise that damage was being done to this country and asked the Government to take immediate action to start cutting expenditure. That was about 18 months ago, yet when eventually the penny drops or when Mr Keating cannot get through to his union people in Caucus how serious the situation is, he calls Australia a banana republic. Some of us have known that for a long time. This has not happened quickly. This is a country which, under Labor, has been plunged deeply into debt. Forward projections by informed people show a huge deficit of about $8 billion or $9 billion next financial year, and that is only a base. We cannot afford such a level or to leave the situation running out of control, as apparently it is doing at the moment. Thought should be given to a mini-Budget. Perhaps, as Senator Chaney suggested, we should even alter the Budget that is now before us. It is only a month old. After about two days, the Press were beginning to notice how bad it was. After a month, it is certainly very much out of date.

Of course, as we borrow, our debts increase. The interest which we must pay has been increasing too. We now pay more from the Budget in interest. I think that the amount predicted to be spent this year on interest is $7,514m-more than we spent on education, health or defence. More than 10 per cent of the tax paid now is being used to pay interest on our borrowings. The figures of the Department of Finance show that the estimate for this year was $6,724m in interest, and the Budget figure is $800m ahead of that. That shows how the debt has escalated since the Department of Finance released that information in a book in May 1985. I bet that this year the interest that must be paid will be more like $8,000m rather than the $7,514m predicted.

What does $8,000m mean in terms that we all understand? With about 15 million people in Australia, it means that every man, woman and child will have to contribute about $500 in tax a year, just to pay interest on the money that the Government is squandering. I have two tables that show the way in which our interest bill and defence spending have increased over the past couple of years. They show a dramatic rise in our interest payments from 1976-77 to the present time and the projection for next year. I have shown those tables to the Minister and I seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard.
