TALK.START.PARA: —Were they checked?

—The Minister checked them. The honourable member is welcome to check them. I imagine that it will take him a long time to do so. I said that the Government was squandering money. I am sure that some will ask where it is squandering money. Let me detail a few areas in which the Government has been squandering money. Until recently, we had the total madness of New Zealand people coming to this country and extracting about $65m a year in unemployment benefit. When I first raised the matter in the Senate it was laughed at, but I note that the Government is attempting to rectify the situation, although I do not believe that it has gone far enough. I believe that it should immediately cut off payment to those people from New Zealand who have not worked in this country. On the matter of unemployment, it is time we recognised that we cannot continue to pay those who choose not to work. Anybody who is caught cheating the system should be ineligible for any assistance from the Government for a period of five years from the time that he or she is convicted. That is the kind of thing that applies in the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, in Canada one has to work for 26 weeks before one can get a year of unemployment benefits and then one has to work another 10 weeks before more unemployment benefits become available. One needs to prove who one is in Canada. Everyone's record of employment has a number on it. The unemployment payments made are not at a flat rate but are based on the last 10 weeks of one's earnings. When one is dismissed from a job the dismissal notice has to be signed by two people. So, one's earnings can be checked against tax paid. If no tax has been paid, there in no unemployment benefit. The tax number can be the check. I believe that that kind of system in this country would help a great deal.

Another way in which the Government can attack expenditure is to stop sending pensions overseas. Some people say that more money comes into this country in the form of pensions than we send away, but I do not believe that we can afford that luxury any more. How does the Department of Social Security check, for argument's sake, on the assets of a pensioner who is living overseas? Why should a pensioner living overseas not be subject to the same rules, if we are to have an assets test, which I do not think we should? How is the Department able to check on those people? Personally, I would not send any pension overseas; but if we continue to send pensions overseas, the maximum tax rate should be applied to them, because when they are spent in Australia they are of some benefit to this country but when they are spent overseas they are of no benefit.

Until we reduce government spending, the confidence of the Australian taxpayer will not be restored and the confidence of overseas banking organisations, such as the Moody's group that Senator Chaney spoke about, will not be restored either. Mr Hawke has said that we have a war on our hands. Mr Hawke has declared the war but he is the person who presided over the disastrous economy that has caused the war. As I have said, the news of the future is not good at all. I have a Press statement from Les McCarrey, who is Director of the State policy unit in the Institute of Public Affairs. The statement is headed: `The real horror is yet to come'. That is something the people of this country should recognise. He points out in this statement that the basic deficit from which we will have to start calculating next year will be $8 billion to $9 billion. If we had a mini-Budget now, that is something that could be avoided. We have this war on our hands. No one in the country would assert that it has been caused by anything other than the fact that the Australian Labor Party would not discipline its own expenditure over the last few years.

We live in a time when we are trying to get money into this country, yet when this big spending and big taxing Labor Government gets a chance to get export income from one of the most highly mineralised areas in the world, it gives in to the loony Left in the Party. A Senate committee is looking at the whole Kakadu area, but does the Government wait to hear what that committee has to say? No, it seems to give in to the loony Left and it says: `No mining in that area'-no matter how uninteresting or how useless that area may be. If a few more members of Caucus visited that area, I think they would realise that the damage done by mining would be minimal in some areas but the rewards for the people of this country would be quite large. About $70 billion to $80 billion worth of minerals is in that area-and the Government decides to lock it up without even finding out just what assets are there.

Mr Hawke has been done over by his loony Left, the people who are trying to put Mr Halfpenny ahead of Senator Button, the one who said, effectively-but not quite in these words-that we need a mini-Budget. That is something that the Opposition senators would support. If the Government does not produce one, this country is heading for disaster. My advice to Australians is that if the Government will not bring in an adjustment to this Budget, they should brace themselves-for there is yet worse to come. As I have said, the world's greatest Treasurer will be remembered in this country as the guy who ruined the economy, and he will become the world's greatest borrower.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mini-Budgets are required when Budget strategies do not work and when it is recognised that the Budget is failing. I would like to state at the outset that this is a Budget strategy that is working all the way and it is widely endorsed. We heard Senator Townley say that the Press woke up to this Budget straightaway. I want to take honourable senators through, slowly but surely--
—Very slowly for him.

—Extra slowly for Senator Townley. I want to take honourable senators through exactly what reaction we have had from the Press and industry over the last month since we brought down the Budget. Even Bert Evans from the Metal Trades Industry Association Inc. put out a Press release a day after the Budget which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has administered the right dose of medicine through the Budget.

I want to start quoting from some Fairfax newspapers because, in recent times, the accuracy of the Fairfax Press has been in question. Sometimes that is justified. However, there are odd occasions when it gets it right, and I want to take honourable senators through those occasions. On 4 September the Australian Financial Review had a big headline concerning financial world backing for our Budget in the following terms: `Morgan Stanley backs Budget'. The article went on to say that recent fiscal and monetary trends in Australia were encouraging for off-shore investors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did the dollar go down?

—I will get to the dollar in a minute. As usual, the honourable senator has not been following the debate. I think that Tasmanian senators from the Liberal Party of Australia have definite problems in following current events. I will help the honourable senator out a little later but I want him to be patient. He should take three deep breaths and remain calm. The Canberra Times of 20 August-I want to go through a number of editorials-said in the introduction to its editorial on the Budget: `A sensible Budget'. The Australian, the thinking person's paper, stated: `Good Budget'. The Melbourne Age-what better paper could one get than the Melbourne Age-stated: `The Keating prescription: Strong medicine, but not bitter'.
—Moody's didn't agree.

—I will get to Moody's in a minute. Senator Peter Baume also needs to be patient. Moody's agreed wholeheartedly. I will take the honourable senator through that as well, but I ask him to be patient. The Australian Financial Review referred to `Mr Keating's remarkable Budget'. Let me just quote some of the words of wisdom from the Australian Financial Review. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: He-
I think it is referring to Mr Keating-
has met the most optimistic of market expectations, maintained a high level of welfare spending . . . It is . . . economically responsible and politically honest.

Of course, that is a pretty accurate description of Paul Keating generally. We just heard about Moody's Investor Services Inc. I want to discuss the Moody's report and I want to quote from the National Times on Sunday which is a really reliable paper. The other day it had an article on the Moody's report which contained enough quotations from that report to try to put it into proper perspective. The AAA rating that we had was reduced to AA1, which is the highest level within the double-A ratings. However, Moody's statement is an endorsement of the Hawke Government's Budget strategy. Let me quote what a gentleman called Roger Nye-Moody's man in Australia-said:

Moody's think the Budget was a brave one. In a rating review we take into account the wisdom or lack thereof of the country's economic managers. One of the positive features of the Australian scene is the intelligent guiding of the ship of state.

Senator Baume asked me about Moody's. That is what it had to say. Moody's is the smaller of the two international credit rating agencies. The much larger one, Standard and Poor's, still has us at an AAA rating. We as a Government have directed our economic policy and our national effort for some considerable time at these issues, and the way in which Moody's has acknowledged our efforts makes us grateful and happy. I quote further from Moody's:
Many fundamental factors bode well for Australia's long term credit quality.

Moody's cited the nation's stability, its strong natural resource base, its sound economic management-I want the Opposition to remember those words, its sound economic management-and prospects for improved economic performance in the 1990s. Overall it has confidence in the private sector's ability to rise to meet competitive challenges and confidence in the Government's ability to pass the appropriate legislation to give incentives for those challenges to be met.

Senator Watson today mentioned the dollar, and we must help Tasmanian Liberal senators in this place-God knows they need it. The Australian dollar closed unchanged, the Sydney Morning Herald tells us, from Monday at US62.5c. The trade-weighted index has remained unchanged at 52. The reason for that is that the Budget has been accepted in the financial markets in spite of our terms of trade difficulties. I shall take Senator Watson through the reasons for that and his defective memory will be assisted in the process. The financial markets have underlying confidence in what we have done. That is why there is now a floor on the dollar, why we are not seeing mad movements any more, and why the float has worked.

It was this Government that floated the dollar. Many members of the Opposition during their years in government-the years they now pretend did not happen-were always in support of a float but could not run over Malcolm to get one up. Foremost, at the head of that queue, as usual, was John Howard. He always wanted to float the dollar, but never could because he could never win an argument in Cabinet. It is a little like the way he goes in the shadow Cabinet.

The blow-out in the trade deficit was not caused by the dollar float, an uncompetitive inflation rate or necessarily entirely by the collapse in world commodity prices. It did not happen overnight. Our incapacity to maintain living standards happened because of neglect, built up over decades. Who ruled Australia during that time? It was the Liberal and National parties. It is not a case this time in this matter of urgency of just going through the failures of John Howard, although I shall probably be tempted to fall prey to that shortly. It is a matter of looking at the whole record and going right back through the days of Menzies and Black Jack McEwen and all those who spent years in office ruining our economy. They neglected our manufacturing industry and our service industries, and forgot about the need to expand Australia's industrial base. When the Hawke Government came into office in 1983, facing all those decades of neglect, there was a herculean task to get this country going again, but we did.

We had the choice when we came into government, in looking at the mess we were left with, particularly after the collapse of 1981-82, of doing what the Liberal Party still acknowledges is the best way to go when faced with an economic crisis. What that Party has always done through its history is make the decision to shut Australia down, lengthen the dole queues, stop industry in its tracks, halt the housing industry, and forget about the poor. It has put the burden on the poor in the hope that one day the problem will go away. If one makes that traditional Liberal Party response, it will work in the short term, for a few years, certainly at the expense and misery of millions of Australians. The band-aid will stay over the sore for a little while, but eventually it will get too great, the disease will break out again and the place will be continually closed down. That is why one saw the rises and falls under Fraser and Howard. The truth is that one has to set in place the mechanisms to overcome, on a permanent basis, the need ever to shut this economy down. We must ensure that it can continue to grow, that employment can continue to rise and that the standard of living Australians have come to expect can be maintained.

We are being lectured here today on Budget strategies by a Party led by John Howard, who overshot his expenditure targets for every single one of his Budgets. I ask Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to get up and explain whether that is wrong. On every single occasion he was wide of his estimated deficit targets for each of his five Budgets. Why would he not be? Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle was Minister for Finance. He never did achieve a surplus. Three out of five Howard deficits blew out beyond Budget projections, culminating in the massive blow-out of 1982-83. That was a whopper of a blow-out. In 1982-83 the Budget estimate was $1.6 billion. The actual figure was $4.473 billion, a blow-out of $2.8 billion.

One consistent cause of those deficit blow-outs under John Howard was the underestimation of the cost of unemployment benefits. They were important, because that Government was putting people out of work day after day-thousands in every week in the last year of the Howard Government. That is why the Australian people had the ultimate good sense to throw that Government out and why, when the crunch comes, they will do it again. We could not overnight miraculously produce a rise in the prices that the world pays for our products. We cannot overnight turn round the fact that the rest of the world has marked down commodity prices. It is worth looking at just how much our major commodities have fallen in the last year when one looks at why we have any sort of a problem: 13 per cent for aluminium, 15 per cent for alumina, 10 per cent for wheat, 5 per cent for wool, 5 per cent for beef, 13 per cent for sugar, and 4 per cent for coal. We cannot just tell the world that we do not accept that, but we can adjust our policies. We can continue the Government's approach to industry policy, which is to upgrade our international competitiveness and to try to make up for those shortfalls. That is the only way to overcome those decades of neglect of Australia's industrial base.

When the Liberals first came into government in the early 1950s a huge percentage of Australians were employed in our manufacturing industry. That figure is now down to under 17 per cent. The reason is that fat and lazy Liberal-National Party governments for 30 years were content to ride on the sheep's back. They thought that that would go on forever, but it did not. Thankfully, there is now a Hawke Labor Government in place to try to clean up the mess.

Let us look at what would happen if John Howard ever ruled the roost again. Let us look at the promises. He will abolish the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the tax on lump sum superannuation. That is an annual cost at the moment of $700m. These promises come on top of the whole grab bag of other promises. I refer to the reinstitution of the entertainment expenses allowance, $310m; negative gearing, $50m; flow-on of world oil price reductions, $400m; abolition of fuel excise, $108m, et cetera, et cetera. At the end of the day one must face the fact that up to $7 billion would have to be added to our deficit if we ever let that mob get the reins of control again-and here they are now lecturing us about the size of the deficit.

The facts are that Paul Keating and Bob Hawke were able to drop the Budget deficit to $3.5 billion. No one in this country thought they could do it. It was one hell of a task, but fortunately we had men of courage and principle who were prepared to take it on. I can recall, as I am sure even Senator Watson can with his defective memory for which he is so famed, what happened when John Howard and his colleagues attempted some sorts of expenditure cuts when they had that ridiculous effort during the days of Phillip Lynch. I refer to the big committee that was to cut expenditure and make for small government. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle played a leading role. What did they achieve? Three months of deliberation and a very impressive $250m in cuts. This Government in a couple of years has cut billions off government expenditures. Honourable senators opposite managed $250m the only time they had the guts to try. Unfortunately, they did not have the guts to follow through. That was at a time when Phillip Lynch delivered a Budget that he described as rubbery. When the crunch came it was not just rubbery; the figures were downright crook. That Government had to go into the election with the fistful of dollars promise but it snatched them away after the election because it could not keep it up. When we got into government only 3 1/2 years ago we were again faced with picking up the mess-John Howard's mess of a blow-out that was getting us towards $10 billion. We have got that figure down to $3.5 billion. This is a government that works. Paul Keating is a Treasurer who can get the economy going. All the people I mentioned earlier-the Press, business, the financial markets-have all endorsed our Budget. If it is given a chance to work, it will pull Australia out of the mire and do for all Australians what they need. It will deliver to them intelligent, principled government that will raise their living standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney cogently explained the Opposition's reasons for its motion of urgency today on the need during the current parliamentary sittings for a mini-Budget which contains measures necessary to restore confidence in the Australian economy. Those who have just listened to the speech of Senator Richardson and that of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) earlier would understand our concern that in the very limited parliamentary opportunities that we have to debate the Budget, there seems to be no recognition of the difficulties of the Australian economy or the responsibility of government in regard to them. I would go so far as to say that there has been a complete breakdown in the Government's primary responsibility-that is, the management of the economy and the protection of people's living standards. I was fascinated to hear from Senator Walsh that there will be no mini-Budget, that the fiscal policy is set-I would suggest that it is set in concrete-and that the difficulties that we can see now with the Budget are ahead of us. It seemed passing strange to me that Senator Richardson should say that mini-Budgets are required when Budgets will not work. Obviously this Budget does not work and will not work. For that reason the Opposition has brought forward this matter of urgency today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget is in the Parliament at the moment. It was introduced some three weeks ago. The Government then scampered off for three weeks to sell the Budget. Quite obviously it was a Budget that needed to be sold because those who have had experience in casting Budgets would recognise it as one that is all about perceptions. It is not about real figures, it is about perceptions. There is a bottom line which was the perception that the Government decided was required, but unfortunately that perception has not been realised. The Budget has failed and we now hear from Senator Walsh that there will be no mini-Budget despite all the entreaties that have been made by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and others about looking at expenditure. Indeed, let us consider the answer given by Senator Walsh today about the committees that are sitting looking at expenditure by the Commonwealth Government and the States. Obviously these committees are intended to report at some time, but we have been told there is to be no mini-Budget.

Senator Richardson quoted somewhat selectively from the Fairfax Press when he referred to an article of 3 September. Perhaps a more accurate and more up to date quote could be taken from the Australian Financial Review of 12 September. The editorial concluded:
The other major step which needs to be taken as an expression of leadership is a mini-Budget.

The term `mini-Budget' can mean a lot of things, but it can also be an opportunity for the Government to correct the mistakes that were made in this Budget and to try to retrieve a situation which is concerning not only the business community and the investment people but also Australians generally. They are very concerned about what has happened.

The first things that we should analyse are the figures in the Budget itself, and there is a controversy about those. The person who most represents the taxpayers of Australia, Mr Eric Risstrom, queried these figures at the time of the Budget-not the first day after, but at the time of the Budget. He questioned the figures in the Budget Papers because he said that the Commonwealth Government estimates greater levels of unemployment. We are advised that if the increase were only one per cent the deficit would blow out by around $800m. He said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had sidestepped every question that was put to him on television about the figures. Mr Risstrom also talked about the fact that the Budget is based on an expanding economy and that the $3.5 billion deficit, which has been much heralded in here today, depends on a 2 per cent growth in the economy. Mr Risstrom went on to point out that for that to be achieved there would need to be a massive turnaround, for the last two quarters, of the economic downslide. I think that everyone would like to think that there would be some growth in the economy, but it is rather futile if the Government already knows that the figures in the Budget will not be realised, but still persists week after week in pushing the Budget through the Parliament. It seems to see no need to correct or retrieve a situation which is causing grave concern.

If we look at the months leading up to the Budget, we should perhaps start with the month of May when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) made his `banana republic' statement. He told us that we would suffer the fate of a banana republic. That had very serious consequences because before that he, the Prime Minister and other spokesmen for the Government had been misleading in the statements they had made about the economy being healthy, about remarkable economic growth and about all sorts of indicators that were very helpful to us. Then in the month of June we had an address from the Prime Minister who analysed the problem but offered no solutions. Nor has he taken any steps to deal with the problem that he had outlined in that address to the nation. In August we had the Budget and the Prime Minister's likening of the situation to a crisis akin to war. In that interview, he said that the party was over. I do not know what party he meant. If one looks at this Budget one would wonder what party he was referring to. I think he probably meant the Labor Party's government was over. The Government could see the problem but it was not prepared to face the solutions required.

It is not only the Opposition that is suggesting that the August Budget has failed to meet the problem outlined by the Prime Minister. I do not think that anyone could argue that the Budget has cut spending at all in real terms. Senator Richardson and others can talk about the thousands of millions that they have taken off the Forward Estimates, or whatever, but the bottom line of the expenditure is that in real terms it has not been cut. The deficit of $3.5 billion was achieved not by cutting expenditure, but by imposing new and increased taxes of about $1.4 billion on top of new types of taxes that were introduced in the last financial year and that are estimated to yield another $850m. It was also achieved by the Reserve Bank profit which increased by $615m to $2.6 billion in the 1986-87 year. That Reserve Bank profit figure is not one that can be relied on for future budget years. This Budget shows a timely figure of $3.5 billion for the perception that I mentioned earlier but it is not a figure which relates in any way to the realities of the economy. When one measures this Budget by the economic yardstick that the Prime Minister himself used-that is, of crisis-one would have to say that it was a bad Budget, that it has failed and that the Government has failed in its economic responsibilities.

I would accept that there was a strategy behind the Budget and I acknowledge that the Government has recognised and stated that there is an enormous problem in the balance of payments. It has recognised also that public sector deficits are draining our national savings and it also gave some recognition of the need to discount wages. In recognising those factors, I would have to argue that the Government has been less than responsible in dealing with the problems concerned. The strategy underlying the Budget was obviously to ease the pressure on monetary policy and to achieve a decline in interest rates. This should have been helped by a decline in the growth of real economic activity. That strategy might have been all right and the Government certainly might have believed that that was what it was attempting, but it gave no recognition to the lack of confidence in the business and investing community and the community in general when it put forward this Budget. The effect of the taxing policies of the Government on business over the past year or so and of the taxing policies on Australians in general has diminished the very fragile confidence that did exist and has built nothing for the future. The strategy has gone wrong. That is why Senator Chaney brought forward this matter of urgency today. It seems to me to be an exercise in futility to go week after week through the Budget Estimates in the Parliament with a Budget that is obviously not going to work, a Budget which has been set in concrete and which provides no solutions to the problems at hand.

The Prime Minister promised massive expenditure cuts. Those cuts have not been realised. It is fair to say that business does not accept that the forecasts underlying the Budget figures are accurate. There is great concern as to what will happen and it is not just conjecture to talk about interest rates going up. They are up and they are still rising. Today's headline in the Sydney Morning Herald business page states: `More pressure on home loans'. Let us look at rates of interest, whether they be related to a home loan, personal loan or credit card. Home loans with banks are between 14.8 and 17 per cent; 17 to 19 per cent with credit unions and 14 to 15 per cent with building societies. Personal loans are all around 18 per cent. Interest rates on credit cards with the banks are 18 to 22 per cent; building societies, 18 to 19 per cent and credit unions, 17 to 19 per cent. No one could suggest that the strategy of the Government's Budget to bring down interest rates has shown any performance in that direction and interest rates are still rising. So on that factor the Budget has failed.

If we look at the state of the Australian dollar, the protection of the currency which is the responsibility of a government in office, we see that there is very grave concern. We find a report in today's Australian that the dollar was steady in quiet trading yesterday, but the Reserve Bank apparently is targeting the trade weighted index between 50 and 52. The Budget Papers on that statistic assume 52 as the trade weighted index level. The index stabilised yesterday at 50 and again departs from the Budget figures and the Budget strategy. One wonders what the Government or the Reserve Bank of Australia will be able to do with regard to the movements in our floated dollar.

So I think that what was said by Opposition speakers with regard to next year's Budget is equally of concern. The budgetary prospects for next year are very grave indeed. Let us leave this Budget, no mini-Budget, no recasting and no changes made because of the reception of the Budget to look at the starting point for next year. Senator Townley referred to the figure from the Institute of Public Affairs. Mr McCarrey, a former Western Australian Under-Treasurer, said that we are looking at a starting point of between $8 billion and $9 billion for the next financial year. If we add to that the alarming external debt which now requires the Government and monetary authorities to defend the present rate of the Australian dollar, we can see why there is concern. This means that interest rates will just have to rise to whatever level is necessary and, therefore, demand will go down even further as the recession continues. One could ask: `Why would business invest in new plant?' A figure was given earlier that about 70 per cent of manufacturers expect that there will be worse times ahead for them. Why would they invest? There has been an argument by trade unions and the Labor Party that investment capital is on strike. It is not that; it is just that it is not prudent to invest in present economic circumstances. One needs to ask: `What will the Government do to correct this?' It will have to look at wages, and to its very timorous approach to 2 per cent discounting for the next wage case. The Government's only argument is that that is the amount that the trade unions would wear without militancy.

We have brought forward this matter of urgency because we believe that there is a need for a mini-Budget to correct some of the difficulties that have been outlined by Opposition speakers today, to do the things that were not done in this Budget, the sorts of things that Senator Button has been talking about when he is being interviewed and is being quite frank about the situation. There is certainly a need for a tougher wages policy to deal with these problems.

Statements have been made with regard to the level of our indebtedness and some of the other factors that are very grave problems. There is just one figure I may have time to use; that is, that the cost of servicing the debt in 1985-86 amounted to 36 per cent of export earnings. That means that only 64 per cent of export earnings is available to pay for imports. That is not enough and, therefore, more borrowings are required. So we are in this vicious circle of borrowing to pay the interest on borrowings that we already have. When they relate to foreign indebtedness and the state of the Australian dollar, we can perhaps understand the concern of the Opposition, the investment community, the money market and all Australians about the Australian economy and the lack of effort that is being made by the Government in this particular Budget to correct the very grave consequences that I have outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been given a very tough role to perform in the Senate today.
—You're up to it, Peter.

—I thank the Minister. It is a very tough role to speak last in this debate because Senator Walsh has provided a reflective economical analysis on behalf of the Government as to why there should be no mini-Budget and why there will not be a mini-Budget. He has provided an analysis of the general furphies tossed up for public consumption by the Liberal Party of Australia. Senator Richardson, my other Party colleague who has preceded me in this debate, has reported in some detail on the accolades and applause that the Government has achieved in bringing down a Budget in these terms both from the public and from the media.

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking last I would have thought that there would be something for me to reply to and that the Opposition might give me some arguments to get my teeth into. In a motion that calls for an immediate mini-Budget to enact certain steps the Opposition has not stated clearly what those steps are. If one looks into the context of the speeches that have been given, it is hard to work out exactly what it is Opposition senators are calling upon the Government to do other than to bring down some vague notion of a mini-Budget. So there is nothing really for me to reply to from the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, sit down then and stop wasting our time.

—I intend to make a few points which will be very uncomfortable to the honourable senator and to his Party, but then the honourable senator expects that. I do think a measure of approval should be accorded, however, to Senator Siddons because he at least said on behalf of the Australian Democrats what their alternative view was in a comprehensive form, unlike the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget is just over four weeks old. It is a bit like trying to pick the winner of a Melbourne Cup just as the horses have jumped from the barrier and have over a mile to run. The Liberal Party `ain't that good'. Indeed, its chief and leading economic pundits have got a good track record for picking losers. Let us go immediately to its ace in this regard, the now discredited former Treasurer, the Leader of the Liberal Party in the House of Representatives, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) whose picking of a $6 billion plus deficit in 1983 was revealed in all its glory when we came to the treasury bench as a projected nearly $10m deficit. He got it so wildly wrong that his reliability and the confidence anyone might have in him as a economic manager have been totally discredited. One can only say that, so soon after a Budget has been brought down, the Opposition has brought on this urgency motion merely to give itself a trial run to test out a few arguments, to have a go and to get itself into a bit of form, to see if it can, as the Budget unfolds, debate economic policy with this Government. I am sorry to inform Opposition senators that they will not get a chance because as the Budget unfolds it will not provide the comfort that they seek in order to debate it.

Let me give some examples. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in the closing remarks of her contribution said that we have not cut expenditure sufficiently. She really did not go into saying where she would propose those cuts or what harsh medicine she would recommend that we take. I remind Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and anyone else who might have been gulled by that remark that this Budget for the first time in many years is a Budget which is cast not only with a $3.5 billion deficit, half a billion dollars below what the discredited former Treasurer, now Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Howard forecast the Budget deficit to be, but also it is a Budget with zero growth in outlays. It has been a long time since a Budget has done that.

Before I turn to the body of my remarks perhaps I should congratulate the Liberal Party on at least achieving one thing; that is, that it has stopped the Labor Party talking to itself on other matters and got us back talking about economic policy where we are best and where the electorate and the broader community have given us a vote of confidence. One of the other things that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has referred to is that there needs to be a tougher wages policy. We keep hearing this slogan of a tougher wages policy offering coming from spokespeople of the Liberal Party. They say there should be zero growth in wages and no wage increases at all. What they do not address, never have addressed and when in government if they ever showed any slight sign of trying to address came destructively undone, is and was how to achieve the philosophical concept they promote as being a wages policy-no growth in wages-in a pluralist society such as ours, where we have a trade union movement which represents strongly the interests of its members and employer associations which represent strongly the interests of their members.

The Thatcher experiment in Britain comes to mind. That is a debilitating and destructive economic, industrial and political experiment which has brought undone the very fabric of that society. Perhaps one could cast one's mind back in a sense of deja vu to the Fraser days when Australians were put in confrontation against Australians and one could believe that that type of situation would help resurgence in the economy. The type of tougher wages policy that is being advocated is probably more likely to be along the lines of the Charles Copeman experiment at Peko-Wallsend Ltd in the Robe River, where everyone was sacked and the company tried to disobey the orders of the Industrial Relations Commission, then tried to reduce conditions of employment rather than address the subject of work practices in the context of the arbitration system. Maybe that is what the Opposition is talking about.

When I look at the utterances of the Liberal Party I see, on the one hand, that its supporters talk about wage cuts, but they say, `For God's sake do not impose the fringe benefits tax on us and make the 11 per cent of Australians who will be affected by that tax-the 11 per cent at the wealthier end of the spectrum-pay their due share of tax'. They say: `Cut wages for the majority of wage and salary earners, but do not make the top 11 per cent of wage and salary earners pay the tax that they have been escaping because they have not met their fringe benefits obligations'. On the other hand, they mouth platitudes about cutting expenditure, but when it is suggested that the excessive growth in executive salaries and remuneration packages over the past three years should be trimmed, they come to the defence of the executive wing and defend that privilege. When it is suggested that that growth should be exposed so that people can see how the dissymmetry between executive salaries and retarded ordinary wages and salaries operates, they say: `No, that information should not be produced'.

This is a peculiar urgency motion which calls for a mini-Budget and refers to measures, but it does not cite the content of such a mini-Budget. It talks about the need to restore confidence, but it does not confront the manifestations of confidence in the Australian community for this Budget. I recall, shortly after the Budget was brought down, seeing a poll in the Australian in which 57 per cent of voters gave a tip for this Budget and said that it was a good one. I recall reading that plethora of editorials and commentary approval cited at some length by Senator Richardson earlier in this debate. I note also that the Australian dollar is holding and holding up well, despite what Moody's Investor Services Inc. says about our credit rating.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are interest rates?

—I might say that, with the level of the Australian dollar and the way it is now performing, I would confidently expect that interest rates will start to edge downwards. That would be a normal expectation in view of the performance of the dollar. As I said earlier, the empirical and anecdotal evidence that is coming forward all the time is that while this is a tough Budget, Australians broadly recognise the need for tough action and support it. This Budget was grievously misforecast by Mr Howard when he predicted a deficit of around $4 billion. We came in under him at $3.5 billion. We do not deny and never have denied that we are living in tough economic times. What we deny is that those tough economic times are a direct function of Australian Labor Party policy. They are not. They are a function of an inbuilt structural position in the Australian economy put there over many years by conservative governments of the party that is now criticising this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of trade turnaround that has affected us amounts to a $4.25 billion reduction in the gross national product over the past financial year. That is $4.25 billion off the national income. In fact, it has reduced the 1985-86 current account deficit to 2 per cent below what it would have been otherwise. However, it has not reached the record of the 1981-82 Howard deficit. It is interesting in this debate that one should turn to informed political commentary in the Press. Just this morning in the Sydney Morning Herald, under the by-line of Ross Gittins, is an analysis of the economic situation in Australia, in which he says:

Indeed, and the inappropriate policies and inaction go back at least as far as the Menzies Government. Australia's slide down the international league-table of income per head has been going on for decades-and the greatest fall occurred during the Menzies years.

We shared in the world's post-war prosperity, but compared with other countries, we frittered away the opportunities it presented. To take just one statistic, in the 30 years to 1983 Australia slipped from being the eighth largest exporting country to being the 23rd.
I remind the Senate that in the 30 years to 1983 Labor was in Government for about three of those years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you were leading the trade union movement and wrecking the country.

—The decline in our competitiveness was presided over by a conservative government. That is a fact that cannot be refuted. In answer to the interjection about my involvement in the trade union movement, of course that is true, but it is not yet a criminal act, as it might be under a Liberal government, to be a member of a trade union in this country. Although, if the members of the New Right had their way, that would be so, because they stand for the abolition of the free association of Australians into trade unions to represent their rights, to counterbalance the right of organised business and to work through an arbitration system, which the New Right opposes, as being a way in which to arbitrate between claims from both sides of the political spectrum.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me answer the interjection in some detail. Last night in the Estimates committee some figures were produced by Senator Button. Because the Hansard is not available, I cannot now reproduce them in this chamber. Under the Steel Industry Authority, because of this Government seeking through the prices and incomes accord to get workers and capital working together to refurbish what was a languishing industry, we now get high levels of productivity which have overshot, per capita of output, the target levels agreed in the early stages of the establishment of that Authority. We have plummeting levels of industrial disputation, as through the accord we have caused the forces of production to harness themselves towards the common goal of operating together to produce more, to secure employment and to make that industry competitive. That is one area where we have worked directly, given a chance to follow our philosophy about how this economy should be managed in the micro-industry setting.

I turn to the Pilbara, the setting of Charles Copeman's latest escapades on his form of deregulation of the labour market. I cite two figures which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) mentioned in a recent speech. In the period of calendar years 1983 to 1985, the industrial disputation figures available show that in 1983 109,000 man days were lost in the iron ore industry in that region; in 1985 24,000 man days were lost, with a reduction in 1984 as well. Earlier this year the figures were running at that much reduced level as well, until the Copemans of this world decided to take the law into their own hands. The record is a very sharp decline in industrial disputation and a very rapid escalation in productivity per head. In the pre-accord period of this Government the output was about 7,200 tonnes per worker in that industry, whereas last year it was 11,300 tonnes-a rapid escalation in productivity per head. What we have achieved in the steel industry and the iron ore industry stands in stark contrast to the divisive, confrontationist Fraser years and the Court years in Western Australia in which workers were set against employers on a destructive course to try to destroy the Australian trade union movement. Senator Siddons recognised this in his address. We have to work with the social partners in the community that exist as inputs to production and harness their creativity and support. This Party is, of course, committed to a program of industrial democracy, not necessarily along the lines of Senator Siddons's Bill, but the objective is there. The way we have succeeded in turning around those two floundering industries, building a better reputation as exporters, stands not as rhetoric, but--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Senate is debating the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need during the current Parliamentary sittings for a Mini Budget which contains measures necessary to restore confidence in the Australian economy.

It is unfortunate that the Minister who entered into this debate, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), confirmed that the Government would not have a mini-Budget during this financial year. In the view of the Opposition that is a counsel of despair, and indeed the gloomy predictions of the Government's own Budget were confirmed by Government speakers in this debate. We have just heard a speech from Senator Cook in which he managed to avoid the real issues. The fact is that the Government has condemned Australia to declining investment, and we all know what that means in terms of future wealth and job creation in this country. The Government's own prediction is for declining investment; the Government's own prediction is for higher unemployment; the Government's own prediction is for declining growth; the Government's own prediction is for high interest rates, and they have gone up 2 per cent since this Budget was introduced; the Government's own prediction is for 25 per cent of our gross domestic product to be taken in tax; and the Government's own prediction is that we will continue in this gloomy way without relief under this Budget. So the Government has simply dropped its bundle. It is leaderless, it is directionless and it does not know what to do about the problems of Australia.

It was fascinating to hear Labor speakers quoting the newspapers, and not least the Fairfax Press, in defence of the Budget. We heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) make a disgusting attack on the Press only yesterday, describing it as his natural enemy and opponent. I do not know how people who have been reading the Sydney Morning Herald and the Australian Financial Review could possibly countenance that, but it shows the sort of desperation which has gripped the Government over recent weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not do you any good to suck up to them, Fred.

—I just commend to the Minister who is now interjecting the reading of a few of Ross Gittins's columns over the last few years and I ask him whether he stands by his leader's comments about the Fairfax Press. I challenge him to put his own view forward.
—Gittins is outstanding.

—There we are. We are now told that Mr Gittins is outstanding. It sits oddly with the interjection the Minister gave me just a few minutes ago. The reality is that this Government is leaderless, rudderless and desperate. It is condemning this country to stagnation and the Opposition believes that there is a better alternative. The reality is that if this Government was prepared to follow the advice of some of the Fairfax Press that was quoted by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, namely, the need for a mini-Budget, which was printed in a leading article in the Australian Financial Review just a few days ago, if the Government was prepared to give real national leadership with respect to changes in the labour market, if it was prepared to do something about the anti-investment taxes in this country, and if it was prepared to do something forthright in the area of excessive regulation, we might then see some economic recovery and the men and women of Australia might have something to look forward to other than appallingly high interest rates, greater unemployment and a declining standard of living. That is what is being delivered by this Government under this Budget. It is a national disgrace and a mini-Budget is essential. I believe that the Senate should record its view that this Government has already failed in its Budget and an alternative is required.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has chosen to bring in a ministerial statement not as a statement to be made in the chamber but as a Government paper which he tabled this morning. This means that it has to be dealt with now and that we are limited to five minutes in which to comment on the paper. The paper concerns the care of aged persons in Australia, which is a most important matter. The Minister released this statement during the last sitting period, during Budget week, but it was not discussed in the chamber. It was not available for comment until today.

The care of aged people in Australia affects each one of us because each one of us is just a decade or two away from being a member of that class of person. When we talk about aged Australians, we are not talking about some other group of people; we are talking about problems that affect all Australians; and concerns that will affect each one of us, we hope, if we are able to live to that age. What must concern most Australians is that there is an enormous amount of unmet need in the provision of services for the aged. There are problems with loneliness, isolation, lack of support and lack of services.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to fix it up by paying pensions to millionaires. What humbug, what mealy-mouthed humbug!

—The Minister for Finance, who is busy cutting services for Australians all over the place, dares to interject when I talk about the problems affecting aged Australians-problems which the Minister, if he is very lucky, will learn about at first hand in a few years.

SPEECH.PARA: We compliment the Government on the introduction of the home and community care program. Indeed, we supported this program. It will help. But there have been some real problems and delays in getting under way the home and community care program referred to in this statement. There has been a disinclination by the States, most of them under Labor governments, to do their part in implementing the goals and objectives of the program.

The home and community care program has raised undue expectations in the minds of consumers, of elderly Australians who had hoped, and were led to believe, that this program would give them new options and new directions. Indeed, the Minister for Health in South Australia, Dr Cornwall, a Labor Minister, said earlier this year that the amount available for his State would be less than $1m for a certain part of the program. He stated:
. . . it will be necessary for the State progressively to pick up an increasing amount of the tab.
The Labor Minister, Dr Cornwall, then added:
. . . unfortunately I believe it-
that is, the home and community care program-
may have been oversold significantly in the pre-Federal election climate. I think that expectations may have been unduly raised . . . it will certainly not be the answer to all our problems.

It is a great pity that, when the objective is to allow elderly Australians to live with dignity, autonomy and choice, the Commonwealth and State governments argue about who is responsible for paying and attempt to shift the responsibility from one level of government to another.

There are concerns about the narrow criteria for participation in the program. If we look at the problems facing residential care for aged persons mentioned in this report, we find that we are stuck with existing methods of provision. We need new ways for people to be able to remain within their society and their community as participants. We need to do this when we are looking for programs for the aged to meet our needs later on. Members of the aged community are often asset rich. They often have a substantial asset in their home but are income poor. They need support yet they can offer support. Some of the cross-generational support being put into place shows just how much aged Australians can contribute. I instance the work done by Ruth Wilson in Sydney who has been working in Sydney schools, getting honorary grandmothers to come into many of the day schools in Mount Druitt and relate to the children. That kind of thing should be encouraged. We are concerned by the narrowness of the approach just as we are concerned by reported criticisms from the Minister for Community Services about the church-run nursing homes and their clientele.

We are concerned that in its programs the Government should move to make the quality of life better for aged Australians and that it should do this through programs, including residential care programs. We welcome the positive measures in this report but we have no doubt that much more needs to be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems quite incredible that a statement of this kind is brought into this Parliament as a Government paper and not as a statement to the chamber by the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes). The statement contains so much material that ought to be debated and looked at quite closely. Given that each senator has only five minutes in which to speak on the topic, I will restrict my comments to aspects particularly relevant to the Australian Capital Territory and the plight of frail aged people in the Australian Capital Territory, about which I have spoken frequently in the past. It is with considerable regret that I tell honourable senators that the situation is no better now than it has been over the last couple of years.

SPEECH.PARA: At present there are 240 people in the Australian Capital Territory who are assessed and classified as in need of nursing home care. It takes 12 months to obtain a place. There are 40 frail aged people in public hospital beds because there is nowhere else for them to go. The fact is that 20 per cent of people in Australian Capital Territory nursing homes come from interstate, some from Victoria and some from New South Wales. I also mention that 25 per cent of our hospital beds are taken up by people from interstate. In addition, there are no facilities for beds for convalescent people. There are no facilities for respite care. That is one of the things most needed in terms of supplementing the home and community care program and the various facilities that will enable people to stay in their homes for as long as they wish and for as long as they are able to do so.

None of us would suggest that people should be driven out of their homes; quite the reverse. We support the concept of keeping people in their homes for as long as possible, but we must not hide behind the rhetoric of those programs and forget that there comes a time when many people are no longer able to cope in that environment and their families are not able to support them. In many instances special nursing care is required for the frail aged which a family at home cannot provide. An elderly person may well be much better off in care, where the care is of the right type and with experienced people, than being left in a family home. Of course, the hostels are part of the solution but they are really only a cheap form of nursing care and are for self-sufficient people who do not require the constant care and supervision required by the frail aged.

When I talk about this sort of care I am not forgetting the fact that aged people may be not only frail; they may have handicaps and conditions which mean that they require that type of care. That certainly is an expensive way of looking after people, but one must accept that nursing home beds are required for those who are bedridden and are not self-sufficient.

I note from the chart in the document produced by the Minister for Community Services that the Australian Capital Territory will have, in total, 200 extra places between now and the end of 1989. It will have no more nursing home beds this year. However, it will have 60 hostel beds and 20 nursing home beds in 1987-88. In 1988-89 it will have no more nursing home beds, but 60 hostel beds. In that three-year period only a further 20 nursing home beds and 180 hostel beds will be provided. Of course, that will be of considerable benefit. However, I was disappointed to find that the understanding of the situation in Canberra is such that only 20 more nursing home beds are to be permitted in three years.

I could spend the rest of the afternoon, Mr Acting Deputy President, telling you the stories that I have heard from constituents who have been faced with the problem of not being able to find any sort of bed for an aged person who quite suddenly needs such accommodation. You would know, as I do, that very often an elderly person comes to need a nursing home bed almost overnight. In Canberra, there is a 12-month wait for a bed. One might be lucky enough to get a bed at Bega or Eden, or in Sydney or the Blue Mountains. How distressing it is for elderly people to be taken away from where their families reside and placed in care so far away from where their families reside and where they have lived. There are places in Canberra which have cottages and hostel beds. They should be allowed nursing home beds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is another ministerial statement which has been brought in as a paper and on which any response will be limited to five minutes. If I said earlier that all of us may, with time, become users of services for the aged, it is especially true that we are only one car crash away from needing services for the disabled. Again we should not talk about us and them; we should understand that the people who have used and developed such services are citizens who want our help as friends and as colleagues. The needs in the community are enormous. Services have been developed by volunteers moving to areas where no services existed, by people learning as they go, and by people dedicating themselves-often dedicating all their lives-to providing services for those with a disability.

The statement that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has brought down, and his Department, does not give adequate public recognition to the work of hundreds and thousands of volunteers across this country over generations. It does not start by measuring and identifying the unmet need in the area of disability and using that as the starting point for examining what services are needed. Indeed, the statement works towards improving the efficiency of existing services. It starts from the point of what exists but it should start by identifying new measures of disability, by identifying and measuring unmet need, and by telling us what we as a society are failing to do. The strategy should be directed towards meeting unmet need rather than just towards the efficiency of existing services.

A couple of matters in the statement are of particular concern. The first involves rehabilitation services. The Government has made some considerable comment about rehabilitation services and how it intends to restructure and, as it says, refocus them. The Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service provides medical, social and vocational services. It is quite clear that the thrust of Government planning is to diminish and lessen the medical element in the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service. It is of concern that that will leave a vacuum because adequate State services do not exist. We receive letters from all over Australia from people who need rehabilitation services and have been in the habit of going to existing Commonwealth rehabilitation services to receive the medical components they require. They are concerned that, as that is withdrawn and a vacuum exists at the State level, they will be left without services. They cannot identify what services they will get. I have received many letters. The so-called refocusing has meant that people have found no services where services were previously available.

The second matter of concern is the new rules that it is postulated will apply to services and to the providers of services. Many agencies that have done a great deal have been told that what they are doing is wrong, or that their direction is wrong, that their style of operation is wrong, and that they can no longer look forward to the kind of funding they have received and therefore the kind of viability for which they have worked for generations. While it is proper to ask them to change, it is not proper that any of them should be expressing to me, as they are doing, any sense of having their very existence threatened. I hope that the Government, in its application of the new rules, will ensure that existing services-even if they are not the most appropriate in terms of the Government's current thinking-will not be put at risk. In that regard, more time for changeover may be needed than the Government seems to be offering.

The needs of people with disabilities are enormous, are continuing and are growing. We should be directing our attentions at the areas of unmet need. I hope that the positive aspects of the Government's program can be put into effect. However, the negative aspects are considerable and have been quite clearly understated by the Government in its paper and plans and in the way in which those plans are being put into effect.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report and Text of Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I seek leave to continue my remarks later. However, I must point out that this is just one of five papers which have ministerial statements attached to them. These are matters that, in a sense, are being pushed through the Senate without adequate time for proper debate.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Again, the text of a ministerial statement by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) has not been brought into the Parliament in the proper way so that it can be debated. I shall refer to only one item out of the many hundreds that are included in the document before us. It appears under the heading `National Capital Development Commission'. I refer particularly to the Cameron Offices in the Belconnen town centre. At page 97 of the report, under the heading `Commonwealth Offices', there is an item for upgrading chillers and providing additional boilers at the Cameron Offices. An amount of just under $300,000 is to be spent this year. Page 101 shows that the estimated cost of modifications to the Cameron Offices is $8m. The estimated expenditure for this financial year is $1m.

I wonder how long it will be before somebody will tell this community and the Parliament what went wrong at the Cameron Offices. They were built in the 1970s at considerable cost. The office complex is quite large. Hundreds of public servants are employed in it. The things that seem to have gone wrong there almost defy description. In many places the offices are unsafe. People should not have to work in the conditions in which they now work. The position is worse when it rains.

After the offices were built there was a court action. Apparently the Canberra Times published some remarks that went to the heart of what was wrong with the Cameron Offices and what might have gone wrong in their construction. It was sued for those remarks and, I understand, lost the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it cost nearly half a million dollars.

—Half a million dollars? It is interesting that, just a few years after, we seem to be faced with the situation where the Cameron Offices are in the news frequently. Whose fault is it that that has happened? What is the true story of what is wrong with the Cameron Offices? Earlier this year, Senator Devlin asked the relevant Minister a question about the Offices. The answer was:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Housing and Construction has advised that the building is now safe and no restrictions need to be placed on its use and occupancy.

That was in April but, by May, there was a lengthy article in the Canberra Times reporting 177 leaks in those Offices. On 7 May, I asked a question about that and the Minister said that considerable work was required. I think that at some stage somewhere it was suggested that it might cost $8m to repair whatever was wrong with the Cameron Offices.

As taxpayers we are entitled to a statement on what happened. There are headlines such as: `Defects in Fire Safety' and on 16 August `Buckets and Mops Again at the Cameron Offices'. I suspect that they probably had the buckets and mops out again yesterday and today. This is a large sum of money to come out of the taxpayers' pockets. I could think of other ways of spending it. I wonder who was responsible for the fact that these problems occurred and the fact that we are required to spend this enormous sum of money repairing buildings that were built only a short time ago.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: OWNERSHIP AND CONTROL OF COMMERCIAL TELEVISION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Future Policy Directions and Text of Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

There are on the list of papers proposed to be presented three sets of reports of which this, `Ownership and Control of Commercial Television-Future Policy Directions', is the first. The report that follows it, which is `Equalisation of Regional Commercial Television-Draft Indicative Plan', and the one that follows that, `Future Directions for Commercial Radio', between them constitute more than 2,000 pages of documentation about the future of broadcasting in Australia. At this stage, we are dealing with only the first of those reports. But the difficulty faced by people attempting to come to an understanding of what is happening in broadcasting in Australia is that, in the past couple of weeks, we have been deluged with more than 2,000 pages of documentation from the Forward Development Unit of the Department of Communications. I put it to the Senate that, in all those 2,000-odd pages, there is a remarkable lack of future direction. All the issues are raised, some of them tediously and ad nauseum. All the alleged options are canvassed, and one is left none the wiser as to what is the preferred economic, social or technological solution to be offered.

Let me therefore confine my remarks in these few minutes to the first of the reports, `Ownership and Control of Commercial Television-Future Policy Directions', and make the point which I have made on numerous previous occasions that the Government has now decided, finally, to bury its alleged policy in favour of localism. Paragraph 27 of the report states:

Some policy objectives are no longer attainable, whatever their merits when first advanced. This applies to promotion of local ownership and to encouraging a diverse shareholding within licensee companies.

Here is the Forward Development Unit's covert admission that the policy of localism and the policy of diversity of media ownership are no longer attainable objectives as far as this Government is concerned-the ultimate statement of the final sellout of broadcasting in Australia into the hands of the media magnates and of the networks. We have heard only in the past 24 hours of the assault by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on those people whom he does not particularly like. On this occasion, it was the Fairfax Press which he described as the natural enemies of his Government. On this occasion, the Government's natural friends are being rewarded and assisted by the deliberate policy pursued by this Government which runs through not only this report but also the following report on the draft indicative plan `Equalisation of Regional Commercial Television' and the report which follows `Future Directions for Commercial Radio'. They are being aided and abetted in their long term desire for complete network domination of media outlets and the whole broadcasting system in Australia. The report makes that admission a number of times.

The section headed `Networking Agreements' commencing on page 206 of the report is written in a fashion that clearly shows that the Forward Development Unit not only is prepared to countenance but also thinks it to be a good thing that regionals should be forced to become slaves of commercial networks, which in effect means slaves of the Melbourne and Sydney media proprietors and which, in time, will mean slaves of those media proprietors who are able to use the satellite communications to bring their programming direct from Los Angeles. That is where the Government's policies will eventually locate the source of most Australian television production-in the United States. Programs will be brought here via satellite in a fairly uncontrolled fashion, will be introduced through the networks and will be forced down the necks of regional television stations and viewers. That is the plan-so-called-that the Government is developing and pursuing. I would expect most of this plan to be introduced by ministerial administrative action because the Minister will not be game to bring the legislation to Parliament where it can be properly debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major problem is that we are acting slightly too late. In the United States of America, the people who hold radio and television licences are restricted by two main factors-first, the total audience reached, which must be no more than 25 per cent of the population, which they use on any one medium and, secondly, the number of stations of different media types that they control. Anyone with newspaper interests in one town is automatically ineligible for a radio or television licence in that area. This is happening even under the deregulated Reagan regime. The Americans are not prepared to allow individuals or companies open-ended opportunities for control of their media. Why should we in Australia? A case is coming up in the Federal Court of Australia which will sound the death knell, or maybe bring a ray of hope. That is the case in which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is trying to have defined the meaning of `control', and the Federal Court will rule whether it is control of the board or control of the shareholding. I believe that if it rules in favour of Mr Murdoch, it will be the death of any type of diversity in the media.

SPEECH.PARA: The second option that we have is to look very much at the whole structure of our media and try to introduce some way in which we can devolve the powers in the main multi-media organisations in the cities-maybe by separating the networks from the transmitting stations. Unfortunately, the Government is going the other way and handing over the regional stations, through its aggregation program and through the way in which it has handled the satellite transmission, to the major networks. At the same time, it is really hitting the national media by trying to get them at one another's throats-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation versus the Special Broadcasting Service. I believe that this is a shame. This report is just a lot of words which unfortunately can do nothing for Australia's commercial television.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Computer Acquisition by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate, I wish to make a brief statement about recent comments made in the media concerning the Public Accounts Committee's inquiry into the job seeker computer acquisition by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I refer honourable senators to my statement made on this matter in the Senate on 13 June 1986 when the Committee's report No. 252 was tabled. The purpose of the Committee's inquiry was to establish whether proper planning and tendering procedures had been followed in the job seeker acquisition. To this end the Committee received evidence from relevant government agencies and also from one unsuccessful tenderer who requested the opportunity to give evidence. The Committee's inquiry concluded that proper procedures had not been followed and that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services must carry responsibility for the improper conduct of the tender. The Committee did not conclude that any computer vendor had contravened proper tendering procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequent to the conclusion of the Committee's inquiry, there have been some developments concerning the job seeker contract that would appear to reflect unfavourably on the successful job seeker contractor, Wang Computer Pty Ltd. Wang has been unable to meet certain of its contractual commitments to the Commonwealth. Contrary to recent assertions in the media attributed to Wang, it has not been denied the opportunity to submit evidence to the Committee on this matter and was at liberty to do so at any time. For reasons best known to Wang, it has chosen not to do so until today, when a written submission was received by the Committee. The Committee will be considering this submission, but its attitude since making its recommendations on this matter to the Parliament is that it is now the responsibility of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Commonwealth's contracting authority to consider and act on those recommendations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
