DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the twelfth report of 1986 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Bill 1986, the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Bill 1986, the Income Tax Assessment (Research and Development) Bill 1986, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation (Safeguards) Bill 1986, and the Superannuation Act 1976. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 12 dated 17 September 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the annual report for 1985-86 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement relating to that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Senate was initially established with the primary purpose of safeguarding the interests of the States in Australia's federal system. However, in the course of its history it has increasingly assumed national responsibility similar to those of the upper Houses in other legislatures. Its most important function has been its work as a House of review with respect to the actions of the Executive and to legislation initiated by the Government. It has established a considerable reputation as a watch-dog and defender of civil liberties from the excesses of unbridled executive power. Not the least part of this reputation is due to the activities of the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee, the annual report of which I have just presented to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This Committee was established by resolution of the Senate on 19 November 1981. Many honourable senators will be aware of the work achieved by that Committee in the course of its history in assisting the Senate in its function as a House of review with respect to legislation by drawing attention to provisions which might otherwise go unnoticed in the passage of Bills through the chamber. Its brief is a watching brief. Its task is to alert the Senate to the possibility of infringements of rights and liberties or the erosion of the legislative power of the Parliament. It expresses no concluded view on whether the clauses on which it comments do in fact constitute such infringements or permit such erosion. That judgment is ultimately left to the Parliament. However, the Committee actively seeks responses to its comments from the Minister, member or senator responsible for introducing the Bill so that those responses may be included in a report to the Senate together with the Committee's original comments. In this fashion, the Committee seeks to promote a fuller and more informed consideration of the clauses upon which it comments at the Committee stage of debate on the Bill in question.

Whilst the paper which I tabled on 11 September last year will remain for some time the primary reference on this Committee's mode of operation and its interpretation of its terms of reference, the Committee believes it to be desirable that, in addition to its weekly reports detailing the results of its examination of particular Bills, it should present to the Senate an annual report identifying trends in matters falling within its terms of reference and highlighting certain areas of particular concern to the Committee.

Besides containing a general overview of the Committee's work during the year, the report deals with four matters which have been of particular concern to the Committee during the past year: Provisions imposing the persuasive onus of proof on defendants in criminal proceedings; provisions abrogating the privilege against self-incrimination; clauses providing for the unrestricted delegation of administrative powers; and the impact of the national uniform companies and securities scheme on the legislative power of the Parliament.

During the year 1985-86 the Committee consolidated its reputation as a useful adjunct to the legislative process. There was a welcome increase in the number of responses to the Committee's comments received from Ministers, and also in the use of the Committee's alert digests and reports in debates in relation to Bills on which it had commented. The Committee received responses with regard to roughly three-quarters of the Bills it commented on, and almost a fifth of the provisions to which it drew attention were amended in accordance with its comments. The existence of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has enhanced the reputation of the Senate as a watchdog and a defender of the civil liberties of all Australians. It has proved a constructive force for the improvement of the quality of the legislation passing through Australia's Federal Parliament. I commend the reading of the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As a member of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills I commend Senator Tate on his outstanding role as Chairman of the Committee which, as he outlined, has had such an important function to perform in this Parliament. I congratulate him and commend the work of the Committee as evidenced in its report to the Senate. I underline the fact that the Committee has traditionally not been overwhelmed by political factors and has served the Senate in an impartial and outstanding way. I draw attention to the fact that, for example, the report is critical of both present and former governments. It says, for example, on page 5 that the responses which the Committee has received from the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) have given it cause for concern on a number of occasions. It reports that it received no response from the former Treasurer and has yet to receive a response from the present Treasurer (Mr Keating), which is most unfortunate. I hope that this report will encourage the bureaucracies in these areas to improve their performance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has drawn to the Senate's attention the Committee's disappointment with the Government's responses so far and to the fact that the Government has not made a proper response to the report of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee on the question of persuasive versus evidential proof. In general it has been a hard hitting, fair and reasonable Committee. The Committee also criticised the Government on the matter of the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment (Clearing Houses) Bill which was made available by the Attorney-General for public comment, but the annual report notes that there was therefore clearly no intention that the Parliament should be involved in this consultative process and, naturally, the Committee was disappointed. However, I endorse the Chairman's remarks that the Government has responded very well indeed, certainly much better than in previous years, and better than previous governments, to the requests made by the report and to remarks made on matters that clearly required amendment. I commend the report to the Senate and congratulate its Chairman, Senator Tate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Examination of Annual Reports

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I present the seventh report on the examination of annual reports, dated September 1986, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

During 1985 and 1986, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has reported on several matters arising from its examination of the annual reports of government departments and authorities referred to it by the President of the Senate. Honourable senators will be aware that under sessional order 7 committees are empowered to `pursue or not pursue inquiries into reports so received'. The report I have tabled today on behalf of the Standing Committee is the seventh report in the series on the examination of annual reports and is entitled `The ABC's Radio Racing Service in Queensland'.

On 5 December 1985, the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, pursuant to sessional order 7, resolved to inquire into the adequacy of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's radio racing service in Queensland. The inquiry was stimulated by representations made to some Committee members and to other honourable senators about the ABC's radio racing services in both metropolitan and regional areas of Queensland. These representations resulted from a decision of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, in September 1985, to cease broadcasting race descriptions on radio in Brisbane. The radio contract of the ABC's long-serving race caller, Mr Larry Pratt, was terminated. In order to maintain a racing service in areas of Queensland outside Brisbane, the ABC arranged, with assistance from the Queensland Totalisator Administration Board, to take Brisbane race descriptions from the commentator for commercial radio station 4BC. These descriptions were then and still are broadcast on the ABC's regional stations.

As the Committee was concerned about the level of services provided in these areas and the general question of decision-making and consultative processes within the ABC, it decided to inquire into these matters in the context of its examination of the ABC's annual reports. The Committee advertised for submissions and 115 were received. Public hearings were subsequently held in Queensland over four days. This report, which is the result of those inquiries and the Committee's examination of the Corporation's annual reports, is divided into two parts. Part one of the report deals with the ABC's annual reports for 1983-84 and 1984-85, the racing industry in Queensland, the ABC's coverage of racing on radio in Queensland and the concerns raised at public hearings about changes to that service. Because representatives of the ABC refused to answer questions relating to its radio racing service in Queensland, the Committee regrets that this section of the report is not as comprehensive as it would have wished. In part two of the report, entitled `The ABC and Parliament', the Committee addresses the serious matter of witnesses from the ABC refusing to answer questions put to them during the inquiry. I will now deal with the major aspects of the first part of the report.

In the Committee's view, the ABC's annual reports for 1983-84 and 1984-85 meet the Government guidelines on annual reports. Both reports give adequate treatment of the Corporation's achievements and concerns, in addition to the basic information suggested by the guidelines. In some respects, the annual report for 1984-85 was superior to that of 1983-84, especially in the amount of information supplied. The Committee encourages the ABC to continue with the type of comprehensive reporting found in the 1984-85 annual report. Neither report makes mention of any ministerial directions or requests which the Minister for Communications may make under sections 80 and 8 (2) of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983. The Committee assumes, therefore, that the Minister did not so direct or request the Corporation in any way. The Committee recommends that, in future, this matter be made explicit in the ABC's annual reports.

Part one of the Committee's report also deals with the ABC's radio racing service in Queensland. The evidence gathered from submissions and from the public hearings indicated that public acceptance of the changes to the ABC's racing service depended to a great extent on the availability of an alternative service from commercial radio. In country areas covered by the ABC's regional service only, there was evidence that, in early 1986, race followers were generally dissatisfied with the quality of the service. There was virtually no radio racing service available on the Sunshine Coast, just north of Brisbane, and in parts of the Gold Coast, to the south of the State's capital.

Although the Committee received sufficient evidence to draw conclusions about the effects of the changes in the ABC's radio racing service, it was unable to reach any definite conclusions about the reasons for the changes and the consultative processes used by the ABC. Nor was the Committee able to investigate fully howefficiently these changes were implemented. There were strong indications, however, that the changes may have been poorly researched, badly managed and incompetently implemented. Unfortunately the Committee was unable to confirm these impressions because the ABC decided not to co-operate with the inquiry.

As I indicated previously, part two of the report addresses important issues concerning the powers and privileges of the Parliament. The Committee's report reviews the events surrounding the failure of summoned witnesses from the ABC to answer questions put to them during the inquiry. The report sets out both the arguments advanced by the ABC in support of the approach it adopted during the hearings and the Committee's response to these arguments. The report also incorporates legal advice on these matters provided by the Attorney-General's Department. In its submission to the inquiry, the ABC informed the Committee that it was willing to answer questions about its views of its relationship with the Parliament and the general processes by which program decisions in radio are made. It was not willing to give evidence on the adequacy of the ABC's radio racing service in Queensland, which it regarded as a programming matter. Accordingly, the Corporation's representatives at the public hearing refused to answer questions which related to the Queensland radio racing service. Executives of ABC radio in Queensland, who were summoned to attend before the Committee, also refused to answer questions about the racing service. The ABC's refusal to answer the Committee's questions was based mainly on the Corporation's perceptions of its integrity and its independence from the political process in programming matters. In the report, the Committee responds to the arguments advanced by the ABC in support of the approach it adopted during the hearing. I shall comment on four of those arguments.

Firstly, the ABC claimed that by requiring operational editorial executives to attend such an inquiry the Committee was establishing a disturbing precedent. The Committee believes that this claim is unjustified and, moreover, is inconsistent with the ABC's past willingness to co-operate in the Committee's inquiry into children's television. During that inquiry, the ABC was invited to give evidence on `its activities in the area of children's programming'. It accepted that invitation and an operational executive from the ABC's children's program department appeared before the Committee on behalf of the ABC and co-operated fully in the inquiry. This co-operation sits oddly with the attitude adopted by the ABC during the present inquiry. The Committee can only conclude that the ABC is selective as to the areas in which it wishes to demonstrate its accountability to Parliament.

Secondly, the ABC claimed that it had already demonstrated its willingness to account for program decisions through the Estimates committees and through answers to parliamentary questions. This claim leads the Committee to conclude that the ABC believes it can nominate those parliamentary forums in which it will be accountable. The Committee rejects this approach as unacceptable to a properly constituted standing committee of the Senate.

Thirdly, the ABC stated that the Committee's decision to investigate the adequacy of the ABC's radio racing service in Queensland was `unusual'. The Corporation, however, did not make it clear why it held this opinion. If the implication is that the Committee's activities should be confined to educational and artistic matters, the Committee rejects the implication. The Committee has had a long-standing interest in issues relating to communications and, in particular, broadcasting. The range of annual reports referred to the Committee and the nature of the reports tabled by the Committee over the past decade bear witness to that association. Indeed, it has been suggested on a number of occasions that the Standing Committee be more accurately named the Senate Standing Committee on Education, Communications and the Arts.

Finally and perhaps most importantly, the Committee rejects the ABC's assertion that the inquiry placed ABC programming under external authority and tended to impair its editorial functions. In support of this proposition the ABC's submissions to the Committee specifically referred to its independence from Government directions guaranteed by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 and to conventions of non-intervention. In the Committee's view the inquiry did not seek to compromise or erode this integrity and independence and it would not have that effect. The Committee respects the programming integrity and independence of the ABC. The Committee believes, however, that it has the right and duty to examine the administration and execution of decisions taken by the ABC. The ABC, as a statutory authority, is created by the Parliament and is fully accountable to the Parliament. The Committee considers that Parliament should not attempt to direct the ABC in relation to the content of programs, nor should it seek to direct the Corporation as to which programs should be carried or when programs might be shown. In the present inquiry, the Committee was not attempting to direct the Corporation, but was seeking information about past events. It wished to know how and why a particular decision was made and to ascertain the effects of this decision on the people of Queensland.

The Committee's views on the ABC's accountability to Parliament are supported by legal advice obtained from the Attorney-General's Department. In relation to the position of the ABC as a statutory authority, the Department stated:

If the argument be that, as a consequence of the independence conferred on the ABC by statute, the ABC is as a matter of law beyond the reach of parliamentary scrutiny, then the argument is . . . misconceived. The provisions on which the ABC relies relate to the relationship between the ABC and the executive government. The powers of the Parliament to inquire into a matter, and to require information for that purpose, do not depend upon that matter being within the control of the executive government. It is abundantly clear that statutory provisions freeing an authority from day to day ministerial direction in no way put that authority beyond the reach of parliamentary scrutiny, particularly in the context of a parliamentary inquiry into the administration and execution of that authority's constituting legislation.

The refusal of witnesses from the ABC to answer questions obstructed the work of the Committee. In effect, the Committee was denied access to information which would have allowed it to prepare a more comprehensive report to the Senate. The witnesses' refusal to answer questions also raised the issue of contempt of the Senate. Nevertheless, the Committee does not suggest that the matter should necessarily be referred to the Privileges Committee at this stage. Rather, the Senate may wish to debate the merits of the ABC's arguments which seek to justify its refusal to co-operate with the Committee. The Committee would welcome such a debate because it would help clarify important issues relating to the accountability of the ABC and other statutory corporations to the Parliament. Such a debate could proceed on the motion which I have moved today. To assist in any debate the Committee reports that it considers that the ABC's approach to this particular inquiry was incorrect and it should answer questions asked by the Committee on behalf of the Senate. The tabling of this report is timely because Estimates Committee C, which will examine the appropriations of the ABC in the next few days, will have the benefit of the Committee's report and its findings on these important issues.

Finally, I stress that in terms of the authority of the Parliament, and in this case the Senate in particular, this is an important report. There are numerous pertinent aspects of the report which I have not mentioned, but they deserve attention by honourable senators. On behalf of the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 250th report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In putting down the statement, I seek leave to incorporate various paragraphs into the Hansard record because it is a lengthy statement and I do not wish to take up too much time of the Senate. I will indicate at what point I would need the incorporations.

SPEECH.PARA: Report 250 details the findings of the Committee's `Review of the Discontinuance of the Efficiency Audit of Australia Post-Administration of Counter Services'. The efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of its counter services began in June 1980 and was discontinued by the then Auditor-General, Mr K. Brigden, in October 1984. It was one of the earliest and longest efficiency audits conducted by the Australian Audit Office. Subsequent to the discontinuance, an informal draft report of the efficiency audit was disclosed to the media without authorisation. This resulted in allegations about the motives of the Auditor-General regarding his decision to discontinue the audit. On 20 June 1985 the Committee announced that it would review the circumstances surrounding the discontinuance of the audit. I seek leave to incorporate the next four paragraphs in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows-

On 30 June 1980, after a feasibility study, the Auditor-General notified the Australian Postal Commission that an efficiency audit into the provision of services to the public through Post Offices would be undertaken. It was anticipated that field work would commence in July 1980 and that a report would be tabled in Parliament in mid 1981. The initial audit team comprised 5 staff.

Australia Post was advised in May 1981 that further field work would be undertaken, that further information was required and that Mr D. Berthelsen would be the Audit Office's project leader from June 1981. The staff on the audit was shortly after reduced to two and then to one person only.

From mid 1981 to late 1983 further field work was undertaken and considerable delays were experienced in the writing of the draft report. Several different drafts were submitted to the Committee which indicated that there had been differing views on report content.

This informal draft report was a precursor to any formal draft to be seen by the Auditor-General. Under the provisions of the Audit Act, the Auditor-General is required to issue a formal draft report to the audited organisation and to take the views of that organisation into account in his final report.

TALK.START.PARA: —In May 1984 an incomplete informal draft report was sent officially to Australia Post. A non-specific response from Australia Post in July 1984 resulted in senior officers of the Efficiency Audit Division becoming increasingly concerned that, while this audit was the only audit outstanding from those commenced by the Efficiency Audit Division, considerable effort would be required to bring it to finality. These concerns were expressed to the Auditor-General in August 1984. The two basic problems brought to the Auditor-General's attention were that the Australia Post Efficiency Audit had been running for some four and a half years; and that for over two years there was only one officer, Mr Berthelsen, conducting the audit and reporting direct to the Division Head.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General discussed in late September 1984 the completion of the report with Mr Berthelsen and was given assurances that the audit report would be finished within four weeks. A month was allowed for completion. At the end of the month, Mr Berthelsen requested a further six weeks to complete the report. In late October 1984 the then Auditor-General, Mr Brigden, decided to discontinue the audit. I seek leave to incorporate the next six paragraphs in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows-
The Committee was presented with a list of some 19 occasions where completion dates for the report had been given by Mr Berthelsen.
On 7 February 1985 the Auditor-General advised Australia Post that further work necessary to carry out the audit on Australia Post would not be undertaken.

In the Committee's view, here the matter should have rested. The Committee concluded that the decision taken by the Auditor-General to discontinue the efficiency audit was justified. However, the debate on whether the audit should have been continued was not put aside.
The issues were raised again by Mr Berthelsen with the new Auditor-General, Mr J Monaghan, on 8 March 1985.

In May 1985 the Auditor-General formally responded to Mr Berthelsen. The Auditor-General noted that the Australia Post Efficiency Audit suffered the consequences of a serious management failure. He found that audit groundwork was not sufficient for the previous Auditor-General to judge that the draft audit conclusions could be sustained against Australia Post's likely rebuttals. The Auditor-General advised Mr Berthelsen that he would not be reviewing Mr Brigden's decision further.

However the debate continued, including claim and counter claim as to the worth of continuing the audit to its final conclusion of reporting in detail to the Parliament. This occurred both within the Audit Office and later before the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —As part of the Committee's review, advice was sought from the Attorney-General's Department, the Committee's Legal Adviser, the Auditor-General, and from Mr K. Brigden, the former Auditor-General as to the basis of the Auditor-General's legal power to discontinue an efficiency audit. These advisings are documented in the Committee's report. On this matter the Committee concluded that the former Auditor-General, Mr K. Brigden, had the discretion to discontinue the efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of counter services under section 48e (1) of the Audit Act 1901; the former Auditor-General, Mr K. Brigden, failed to present a report on the efficiency audit of Australia Post under section 48f (1); the Auditor-General, Mr J. Monaghan, has complied in part with section 48g (1), when he reported the discontinuance of this efficiency audit in the annual report of the Auditor-General 1984-85; and, finally the Auditor-General should comply with section 48f and 48g of the Audit Act 1901 as is relevant to the efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of counter services. I seek leave to incorporate the next six paragraphs in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The paragraphs read as follows-

The Committee also examined the management of the efficiency audit of Australia Post in the Efficiency Audit Division. The first head of that Division, Mr J. Jones, told the Committee that he decided to delegate responsibility to others to manage projects and as Division head develop methodology, select topics and maintain quality control. Mr Jones stated that this `option, had its risks, because when people are allowed to learn by doing they make mistakes'.

Mr Jones accepted the responsibility for, and conceded that, the management of the Australia Post audit was deficient. Mr Jones claimed that he had difficulties working with the former Auditor-General, Mr Brigden.

Mr Brigden was aware that relationships generally were not harmonious between that Division and the rest of the Audit Office. He also said that throughout the Division's existence, problems with the major audits undertaken remained the same. Audit scope was not defined and maintained with precision and audits were not managed firmly or documented properly.

Mr Brigden told the Committee that considerable pressure was brought to bear upon the Division head with a view to having all sixteen of the audits originally undertaken by the Division completed by the end of 1983, but these efforts were by no means successful. Only seven has been completed (since 1978) when the head of the Efficiency Audit Division proceeded on leave early in 1984. In an endeavour to expedite the completion of the audits, major changes were made to long standing administrative and reporting arrangements within the Audit Office.

In May 1985 the Auditor-General, Mr J. Monaghan, decided that all major project audits directed to efficiency and operational effectiveness issues would be formally designated as Efficiency Audits. The aim was to achieve an average turnaround of approximately 9 months from designation to tabling. He expected that, on this basis, some 20 to 30 efficiency audits per year would be conducted. The Audit Office has introduced revised management practices to ensure that management objectives, including improved reporting objectives for efficiency audits are achieved.
There is some evidence that the aims of both Auditors-General (Mr K. Brigden and Mr J. Monaghan) to make efficiency auditing much more timely have been achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Overall the Committee found that the efficiency audit of Australia Post was not well managed, resulting in a lack of concise and timely reporting; there were serious communication problems regarding the efficiency audit of Australia Post within the Efficiency Audit Division, between the Auditor-General, Mr Bridgen, and the Efficiency Audit Division, and between the Efficiency Audit Division and the rest of the Audit Office; and that the scope of the efficiency audit of Australia Post was not well defined and maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee concluded that the management of the efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of counter services was deficient; the ultimate responsibility from 1981 to 1984 for the management of the Efficiency Audit Division and of the efficiency audit of Australia Post was the Auditor-General's; and the management of the efficiency audit of Australia Post was not in keeping with the Australian Audit Office's goals, that is, that the Australian Audit Office should be exemplary as regards accountability for its functions and the efficiency, economy and effectiveness of its operations.

The Australia Post audit was not only the longest, but also the costliest efficiency audit. The Committee anticipates that the Auditor-General will provide the total cost of the efficiency audit of the administration of Australia Post's counter services in his next annual report. The issue of stamp security was also raised before the Committee. Amongst other matters, it was alleged that the Auditor-General may have misled the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) on the issue of postage stamp thefts. The Committee concluded that stamp security within Australia Post was not related to the decision to discontinue the efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of counter services; and further detailed investigation of the security of stamps and other negotiable paper by the Auditor- General is warranted.

Finally, I would like to express the Committee's appreciation to the Auditor-General and his staff, the former Auditor-General and the staff of Australia Post for their co-operation provided throughout the review. The Committee thanks its legal adviser, the Hon. Mr Justice Paul Toose, and members of its Secretariat for the support given during this inquiry. I commend this report to honourable senators and members.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth of Australia Branch Delegation Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Commonwealth of Australia Branch Delegation to the Thirty-First Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference in Saskatchewan in October 1985. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Lindsay of the other place was the leader of the delegation and I was the deputy. I would like initially, and primarily, to pay tribute to the magnificent guidance, surveillance and consideration given to us by our excellent secretary, Mr Ian Cochran. The format of the Conference was excellent. It commenced in Regina, where we spent a couple of days at the preliminary functions; then the party was divided into four separate groups. We then disappeared for three days until we reached Saskatoon, where the main part of the Conference was held. The President of the Association was Herb Swann, Speaker of the House in Saskatchewan. He was a tremendous host and the organisation was brilliant, with 165 delegates present and masses of extras.

SPEECH.PARA: The highlight of the functions for the Australians was the appointment of Dr David Tonkin as the Secretary-General of the CPA-an appointment which was widely applauded, and certainly we all wish him well in his new position, although it is now nearly 12 months since he was appointed. The Australians participated widely in all the sessions. I was pleased to be both panelist and chairman of one session on famine which, if the recommendations were followed, could be a most useful basis for future development. If the recommendations only wind up in a file somewhere with many other similar motions and discussions, the whole basis of the CPA will come under question-both the organisation and the meetings it runs.

I believe that the CPA is a very good and worthwhile body which should be supported, and it should become more objective in its work and the way the conferences are carried out. I regret that in many cases the forum opened up as being somewhere for people to grind their own axes, to say the things that they had been storing up for some time, highlighting the differences between the lesser developed and more developed countries and too often winding up as a debate on apartheid. Very good friendships and useful connections were made. It was most enjoyable and the entertainment, hospitality and friendships were all beyond belief and greatly appreciated.

This year's Conference will be in the United Kingdom, 1987 in Malaysia, 1988 in Australia, 1989 in Barbados and 1990 in New Zealand. The performance that the Saskatchewan Parliament put on for us in terms of entertainment and providing the necessary venues, and all that goes with that, places a particularly difficult job ahead of us. I hope that our planning, presentation and performance in Australia will match the very high standards set in Saskatchewan.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking before lunch, I was making the point that it seems to us that unsatisfactory though the final result will be in terms of the Opposition's amendment, there seems to be no other alternative which will provide the types of protection that the Australian Democrats would want, so I indicate that we will support the amendment moved by the Opposition and will reject the amendment moved by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it for a second time the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill 1986. On the first occasion the Senate sent to the House of Representatives the Bill with an amendment which had been carried by the Senate. The other place has sent it back and now we have before us a Government amendment, and an Opposition amendment for which the Australian Democrats have indicated their support. I remind the Senate that the Bill seeks to bring to an end the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry which was set up by this Parliament. That Commission of three eminent former judges was to inquire into the conduct of a judge of the High Court of Australia. The Bill goes further than that. It not only seeks to bring to an end the Commission of Inquiry but also seeks to put a complete estoppel upon the information before the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the Senate at the moment is an amendment moved by the Government which, in part, states:

A person shall not publish or otherwise disclose to any other person, the whole or any part of a class A document that has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission, or counsel assisting the Commission.

The amendment goes on to say that the penalty would be $5,000 or six months imprisonment for a person or, where the defendant is a corporation-presumably a newspaper or other form of media-the fine is $100,000.

The Minister representing the Attorney- General today put forward several arguments. Senator Gareth Evans's first line of argument was to refer to some articles in a recent publication of the National Times on Sunday. If I construe his argument properly, he sought to suggest that such articles would be stopped-articles which he referred to as scuttlebutt-if this legislation were carried. Essentially, what he did not tell us is that if this Commission had been allowed to proceed, the two journalists could have been and would have been summoned before the Commission and the test of whether or not their evidence was factual would be known. The action of the Minister and his Government is to leave that test forever unmade. Under this legislation the Government is creating a series of situations in which stories can be indicated and cannot be proved. That is a tragic situation. The two journalists concerned, Wendy Bacon and Brian Toohey, have said that what they have stated is correct and that they are journalists with a reputation of integrity. If that is so--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—The Minister scoffs. Let the media scoff if such allegations as were made against their integrity are made against the Minister's integrity. The fact of the matter is that the test was there-not for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to abuse a particular section of the media because he does not like what is being reported, but to test whether or not the facts were there. In fact, the Government has run away from testing the facts. So, let the whole public understand that when the media is under attack by the Government, that is, firstly, because it does not like what the media is saying, and, secondly, because the Government will not put it to the test. The simple thing to have done would have been to have invited those two journalists before the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: A much more astonishing situation has been brought forward by the Minister today. The Minister reported to this Senate that the Secretary of the Commission had indicated to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) that the commissioners found themselves grossly offended by the amendment being put forward by the Opposition. The Minister then proceeded to build his case in support of that.

I find it astonishing that a Minister of the Crown would do that. When he was pressed by interjection he admitted that there was nothing different between what the Opposition was trying to do and what the Government was trying to do, that the Government's amendment and the Opposition's amendment were factually identical in their application to the commissioners. His words were that really the error was one of presentation, that one should not mention commissioners as such, but that one was quite free to mention staff. I find it outrageous that a former Attorney-General and present Minister representing the Attorney-General should set out one kind of rights for those who occupy particular places in the community and another kind of rights for others. He suggests that we must not name judges or ex-judges but that we can name staff and that somehow or other we can put a higher value of integrity and trust upon one citizen than on another. If there is a real offence it lies in what I would call a totally corrupt and ugly presentation.

Let us understand what is happening here. This Parliamentary Commission is a creature of this Parliament, created by this Parliament. We as parliamentarians are sworn to recognise the independence of the judiciary and we ourselves, under our Standing Orders, do not venture upon any such criticism at all. I find it absolutely wrong, if it is true, that the Commission should have sent such a message to this Parliament, first, because in fact it would have been selective. It must have known that the Government's amendment was identical in its application both to the commissioners and to the staff. Secondly, it is the complete freedom and right of this Parliament to bring forward whatever amendments it wishes and not to have such messages sent to us under those circumstances. I must say that it would be an abuse of what I regard as the privileges of such a body so to do. I would ask that the President or the Minister himself find out under what conditions such a message was sent, first of all when it was known that the amendments of both the Government and the Opposition applied identically. Why was it selectively choosing the Opposition when the Government itself was seeking to do by legislation what the Opposition was seeking to do? Let us have that answer.

All this is based upon the Government saying that really we must hide this information, keep it out of sight. The Government then dismisses this matter with a whole series of words about trivia, allegations, assertions and insinuations. Let me bring this debate back to reality. In fact, what happened was that a commission of three was asked to investigate the conduct of a judge. I read from the Government's explanatory memorandum the terms in which it should go about its task:

The Commission will not call Mr Justice Murphy to give evidence unless the Commission is of the opinion that there is evidence of misbehaviour within the meaning of section 72 of the Constitution sufficient to require an answer and the Commission has given to Mr Justice Murphy particulars in writing of that evidence.
It goes on to say:
The Commission is to base its findings on evidence admissible in a court of law.

So the Commission has to look at the evidence, find that, in its view, there is really a case to answer-and the test is that applying to evidence before a court of law-before it goes into anything that could otherwise be described as insinuation. But what did the Commission do, having been adjured to do this? The Commission said-and I read from its own statement:

By Thursday 17 July 1986 counsel assisting the Commission had cause to be delivered to those representing Mr Justice Murphy twelve documents each purporting to set out a specific allegation of conduct by the Judge (Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry Act, S. 5 (2)). Two further such documents have since been delivered.

That meant that 14 allegations made and put into writing stood the test of the explanatory memorandum. In other words, the Commissioners considered that the allegations and the evidence before them were serious enough. So we are dealing with the termination of a commission on that basis and with the disposal of the evidence on that basis. Let nobody from the Government side try to trivialise the facts. The facts are that three commissioners have said that there are 14 serious matters to be investigated and answered. They are to be brought to a finish. But, more importantly than that, the evidence is to be shelved. This amendment of the Government produces an extraordinary situation because, in fact, as I read it, it will do exactly the opposite of what it sets out to do. It says:

A person shall not publish, or otherwise disclose to any other person, the whole or any part of a class A document that has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission, or counsel assisting the Commission.

Presumably any document that has not got to the stage of being prepared by the Commission or the staff, but is in the Commission's hands, can in fact be freed. The lawyers would dine out for months on the meaning of the word `prepared'. Perhaps if a document is to be processed further it is not `prepared', because the Secretary of the Commission has said in a letter to the shadow Attorney-General that there is much more processing to be done. What about all the matters that have not been prepared or processed? Is it all right for the staff, the Commission or others to release this matter? The amendment is basically saying: `Look here, if something is prepared and moved along to the stage of being a reasonable case to inquire into, shelve it; but every piece of trivia and scuttlebutt is free to be released'. That is an absolutely monstrous situation and the Opposition has moved a much more sensible amendment. It is no good in respect of a matter arising from this Government, with a commission being set up by this Government, for the Government now to try to tear it down simply because it says it was built on trivia. The Commission itself says it is not dealing with trivia. The Commission itself says it has a volume of matters to process and to go ahead with. So let nobody say that.

I have to say that the Australian Democrats' case crumbled completely when the Commission recently put out its statement showing that 14 cases were submitted in writing for answer. There was no longer any suggestion that we were dealing with just some journalistic scuttlebutt. Simply to turn the attack upon the journalists and the media is, of course, an attempt to coerce and to deny freedom. I know nothing that is more ugly than the suggestion that the Government is going to stop journalists from releasing documents by threat of gaol or fine. Nothing will stop that at all because the essential freedoms will come out. In any case, if it cannot come out one way it will come out another. So we have before us a Bill which will create the monster instead of destroying it. I regret very much the Government's amendment; I support the Opposition amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment foreshadowed by Senator Durack and to oppose the amendment introduced by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) and transmitted to us from the House of Representatives. As I understand the import of the amendment which the Government seeks to make to this legislation, its effect will be that class A documents-that is to say, those documents which the original Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry (Repeal) Bill defines as those relating to the conduct of the Hon. Lionel Keith Murphy-are to be given a particular type of protection. In effect, that protection is to be a suppression order. Persons are to be held liable for punishment, in the case of natural persons, by a $5,000 fine or imprisonment for six months and, in the case of corporations, by a $10,000 fine, if they publish or otherwise disclose to any other person the whole or any part of a class A document that has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this will lead to this quite extraordinary situation: A document which purports to be a series of allegations against His Honour Mr Justice Murphy may in fact be published or disclosed without attracting such a draconian penalty if in fact it is published or disclosed in its raw form, having come into the possession of, say, the media or whoever. However, if there were in existence a document prepared by the Commission which said: `We have taken this allegation, investigated it and found it to be entirely without substance', the publication of that document, being a document that has been prepared by the Commission, would constitute an offence punishable by a fairly hefty fine or a term of imprisonment.

It seems quite extraordinary that the publication of a document that might be a document vindicating His Honour in terms of any of the accusations made to the Commission against His Honour would possibly attract very serious penalties. When Senator Gareth Evans was replying to the debate on 21 August he said that one of the basic objects of this legislation was `to prevent the kind of grotesque unfairness to Lionel Murphy and his family that would flow from untested allegations about any aspect of his life-public life, private life, on the Bench, in politics or before all that over the last 60-odd years'. I would have thought that material prepared by the Commission, given the nature of the Commission and of the persons who constitute the Commission, could only be material which would settle matters one way or the other and that indeed it would be not only in the public interest but also in the personal interest of His Honour Mr Justice Murphy that such material should enter the public domain. It may well be that there are questions about time and form but, nevertheless, that should enter the public domain.

The shadow Attorney-General, Mr Spender, communicated with the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry to ask about some of the material it currently held. On behalf of the Commission, Mr J. F. Thomson, the Secretary, replied to Mr Spender in a letter dated 10 September 1986. The letter is on the stationery of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry and it states:
Dear Mr Spender,

I have received your communication dated 8 September and transmitted to me by facsimile. I have had the opportunity of discussing the matter with the Presiding Member of the Commission, the Honourable Sir George Lush and, consistently with that discussion, I make the following observations in relation to your communication.
With respect to the matters set out under the heading `As to section 34' the position is as follows.
Material in the possession of the Commission was not `analysed' for the purpose of possible communication to other persons and agencies specified in section 34 of the Commission's statute.

The Commission is not called upon by its statute to do such analysis. However, the question generally was addressed by Counsel Assisting the Commission and the Instructing Solicitor though naturally not in the same depth as would have been the case had the Commission gone to finality. On an overview of the material available, much of which came from the National Crime Authority, the Director of Public Prosecutions or the Australian Federal Police, analysis was not warranted, in the opinion of Senior Counsel. A good deal of the material is inchoate and, in that form, unsuitable for reference pursuant to section 34 generally. To be suitable for that purpose such material would need to be enhanced by further investigation and/or cross-examination of witnesses. However, when it became apparent that the Commission was to be wound up by the Parliament, it consulted the National Crime Authority over materials in its possession that the Authority might require. Those requested by the Authority were provided to it.

I confirm what you have set out in your communication under the heading `Receipt and Disbursement of Information' except that the material proposed to be sent to the Parliament under the repeal Bill (as presently formulated) will not include:
files received from departments and authorities;
material provided to the Commission in confidence on the basis that it would be returned;
Senate Committee material;
Counsel's personal working notes which, I understand, have been destroyed; and
administrative files.
However, relevant information from the material described immediately above is contained in the Commission's records, which, it is proposed, will be sent to the Parliament.
Yours sincerely,
J. F. Thomson
Secretary

In other words the Commission has established that it is the holder of a great deal of material in a form which is not appropriate-the word used is inchoate-to be transmitted under the terms of reference provided in section 34 of the original legislation establishing the Commission of Inquiry. However, the amendment advanced by the Government does not deal with that sort of material. It deals with material which, in the words of the Government's amendment, has been prepared by the Commission, the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission. I submit that the very fact that the Commission has prepared material means that a great deal of that material would have been relevant to an assessment of the validity or otherwise of matters laid before the Commission. As Senator Sir John Carrick has pointed out, the Commission has made public the fact that it has received a number of allegations which have been put together at least in some form.

With the support of the Australian Democrats the Opposition has sought to provide an alternative form of words which the Committee was minded to accept when we debated this matter on 21 August. Our amendment dealt with the material in a way which material held by Commonwealth authorities is usually protected, that is to say, by making it an offence for a member of the Commission, a member of the staff of the Commission or counsel assisting the Commission directly or indirectly to disclose to any person certain material which should not have been disclosed. Senator Evans has indicated, to use his words, that members of the Commission found it profoundly and uniquely offensive to be dealt with in that fashion. I do not believe that there is anything profoundly or uniquely offensive about specifying all of the persons-the commissioners, the staff and the counsel assisting-who after all are the persons directly concerned with the ownership or control of this material in exactly the way that Senator Durack referred to in his earlier remarks.

I conclude by drawing attention to only one or two of the very lengthy comments made by Senator Macklin. In his speech earlier this day, Senator Macklin indicated that the only documents-those were his words-in the possession of the Commission were `working papers of the Commission'. Of course, we do not know whether that is the case. Indeed, from the terms of Mr Thomson's letter of 10 September, one would suspect that that is not correct.

I do not propose to go over the grounds of the freedom of the Press arguments, although Senator Macklin has made it clear that he does not believe that that is an issue actually arising. Those arguments were canvassed by me in my speech on this legislation on 21 August and were well canvassed by Senator Durack in his remarks earlier today. I therefore conclude simply by saying that I believe that, if the test of fairness is to be applied in the way in which the Minister, Senator Evans, described in his speech on 21 August, fairness is more likely to be achieved by proceeding along the lines suggested in Senator Durack's amendment than by pursuing the Government's amendment. On that basis, I support Senator Durack's amendment and trust that the Committee will reject the Government's alternative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind Senator Evans that, in answer to a question yesterday by Senator Sir John Carrick--
—I was going to deal with that.

—Fine. The only other point I raise is that this morning I said that I would check with the Opposition shadow Attorney-General, Mr Spender, as to whether he had had any communication from any members of the Parliamentary Commission of Inquiry by way of complaint about the amendment. I have done so. Mr Spender has informed me that he has had no communication of any kind from any member of the Commission.
—I wouldn't talk to him either, if I were them.
—There has never been a communication initiated by either Mr Spender or the Commission. It has nothing to do with whether members of the Commission are prepared to talk to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — However much the Opposition's contribution today may be dressed up as high principle, defence of freedom of the Press, or whatever, what it really amounts to is simply a tacky attempt to keep alive, by one means or another, the persecution of Lionel Murphy. It is an enterprise that is being regarded with increasing distaste by the community at large. It will not get the Opposition anywhere but, of course, that does not stop it.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, there is nothing in the Commission documents which is in any way conclusive one way or another in its analysis of the material that has been submitted to the Commission by way of allegation. The material that the Commission has remains allegations-no more than that. They are untested allegations, in some instances made by people utterly without credit-such as `Tropical' Anderson, so beloved of Mr Toohey and Ms Bacon of the National Times. There is nothing in the revelation of the material that would contribute anything to justice or decency in this matter. It continues to remain a matter of shame to the Opposition that it should be so besotted with the continuing saga and desires to keep it alive by one means or another and encourage others to keep it alive by supporting the limited amendment proposed tonight.

I refer to the famous communication of the views of the Commission. For the record, I make it clear-there is no desire to keep any secrets in this respect-that the communications to which I referred, in which the Commission said orally that it found the Opposition's amendment grossly offensive to persons associated with the Commission, was as a result of a request for a reaction to the Opposition's amendment that was made orally to the Secretary of the Commission by a senior member of the Attorney-General's Department. One would think that that was a natural precaution when the Government was deciding whether or not to accept the Opposition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who replied? Was it the Secretary?

—The Secretary replied, having consulted with Sir Richard Blackburn, Mr Justice Lush and Mr JusticeAndrew Wells-former justices in each case. As I understand it, that is an accurate report of their response, based on their distaste for having been singled out. No doubt they are prepared to accept, with judicial equilibrium, being treated in the same way as everyone else, but being singled out for very substantial gaol penalties should they breach faith, secrecy and respect, quite understandably is regarded by them as somewhat less than gentlemanly behaviour on the part of the tories who are allegedly above such things. I make that clear for the record.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I make clear for the record the Government's response to Senator Sir John Carrick's question to me in the Senate yesterday, some of which ground both he and Senator Puplick traversed again today. The Opposition spokesman on legal matters, Mr Spender, in his Press statement of 12 September made the extraordinary claim that there ought to be some continuing activity by the Commission to investigate further the material now before it so that it might be assembled better for the purpose of transmission to law enforcement authorities for the purpose of uncovering evidence relating to the commission of criminal offences. In other words, the Opposition wants the whole thing to keep going because it is unsatisfied with the way in which the material has been transmitted to law enforcement authorities to the extent that it does raise issues of possible criminal behaviour by various people.

My response to Senator Sir John Carrick's question is, in short, that no further action is required or remotely appropriate in relation to the matters that he has raised. I say, for the record, that he was quite selective in his reference in his question yesterday to the parliamentary record. His question made no reference to what I said in the Hansard in my reply at the conclusion of the second reading debate. I summed up the position in the following terms:

So far as the Commission's capacity itself to pass on to law enforcement agencies material not originated from such agencies, but perhaps turning up in the course of documentary submissions made by other people, the Commission has the capacity under section 34 of the present Act to communicate such as it thinks appropriate of that material to law enforcement agencies.
Further, I said:
Material which, in the view of the Commission, satisfies that description is, as I have indicated, being passed-if it has not already been passed now-to the National Crime Authority.

Later in that speech I made the point that there was ample time, on the basis of information received from the Parliamentary Commission, for that process of communicating information to agencies to take place before the anticipated repeal date of the legislation.

The suggestion by Senator Sir John Carrick appears to be that the information that was obtained by Mr Spender from Mr Thomson, the Secretary of the Parliamentary Commission, indicates that the Commission now considers that further investigation and/or cross-examination of witnesses should be undertaken by the Commission before it can perform its function under section 34 of the Act in transmitting further material. To the extent that that is the interpretation that seems to emerge from what both Mr Spender and Senator Sir John Carrick have said, I simply say that that is not what the Commission has said. Any careful reading of Mr Thomson's letter will make that clear. Perhaps I should incorporate in Hansard the terms of Mr Thomson's letter so that the record will be complete in that respect. I seek leave accordingly.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-

Sydney, N.S.W. 2001

I have received your communication dated 8 September and transmitted to me by facsimile. I have had the opportunity of discussing the matter with the Presiding Member of the Commission, the Honourable Sir George Lush and, consistently with that discussion, I make the following observations in relation to your communication.
With respect to the matters set out under the heading `As to section 34' the position is as follows.
Material in the possession of the Commission was not `analysed' for the purpose of possible communication to other persons and agencies specified in section 34 of the Commission's statute.

The Commission is not called upon by its statute to do such analysis. However, the question generally was addressed by Counsel Assisting the Commission and the Instructing Solicitor though naturally not in the same depth as would have been the case had the Commission gone to finality. On an overview of the material available, much of which came from the National Crime Authority, the director of Public Prosecutions or the Australian Federal Police, analysis was not warranted, in the opinion of Senior Counsel. However, when it became apparent that the Commission was to be wound up by the Parliament, it consulted the National Crime Authority over materials in its possession that the Authority might require. Those requested by the Authority were provided to it.

I confirm what you have set out in your communication under the heading `Receipt and Disbursement of Information' except that the material proposed to be sent to the Parliament under the repeal Bill (as presently formulated) will not include:
files received from departments and authorities;
material provided to the Commission in confidence on the basis that it would be returned;
Senate Committee material;
Counsel's personal working notes which, I understand, have been destroyed; and
administrative files.
However, relevant information from the material described immediately above is contained in the Commission's records, which, it is proposed, will be sent to the Parliament.
Yours sincerely,
J. F. Thomson
Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply state, by way of commentary on that letter, the following points: First, the Commission's reply states that the Commission is not called upon by its statute to analyse material for the purpose of possible communication to law enforcement agencies under section 34 of its statute. Secondly, however, the question was generally addressed by counsel assisting the Commission and the instructing solicitor. Thirdly, and perhaps most importantly, is the statement of the Secretary that, on an overview of the material available, an analysis was not warranted, in the opinion of senior counsel. The fourth point needs to be read in the light of that, and that was that a good deal of the material was inchoate-that is, disordered, scattered, messy-and, in that form, unsuitable for reference pursuant to section 34.

SPEECH.PARA: Fifthly-it is only in the light of that previous discussion that the further point is made-to be suitable for that purpose such material would need to be enhanced by further investigation and/or cross-examination of witnesses. The final point is that when it became apparent that the Commission would be wound up by the Parliament, the Commission consulted the National Crime Authority over materials in its possession that the Authority might require. Those requested by the Authority were provided to it. What is said there is very different from the interpretation, the gloss and the notion that the Commission was keen for further examination that is sought to be persuaded. I urge the Committee to reject the Opposition's amendment and vote for the proposition now before us.
Consideration interrupted.
