SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my concern to other senators about the situation in which Queensland nurses find themselves in relation to the attitudes of two crucial Queensland Ministers. Of course, any issue that affects Queensland nurses obviously affects the people of Queensland. The 1985 Grants Commission report found that Queensland nurse staffing levels were 27 per cent below the national standard. It is an absolute scandal that the people of Queensland should have such low levels of nurse staffing. Capital works expenditure in Queensland hospitals is taking preference over work force considerations. New hospitals are opening but there is no guarantee that there will be an adequate number of nursing professionals to care for the patients in them.

SPEECH.PARA: The State Minister for Health and Environment has adopted a head in the sand approach and refuses to meet with Queensland nursing union officials to talk over the problems on a rational basis. Of course, rationality is a characteristic that is not particularly well represented in the Queensland minority Government. High nursing staff turnover with better conditions available in other States has created a situation in which 4,000 more nurses are required to bring Queensland up to the national standard which should be applied. The Queensland Government consistently refuses to co-operate with the Federal Government which has made a number of important overtures in regard to increasing the professionalism of nurses throughout the country.

Queensland is the only State that has failed to agree jointly to introduce tertiary education for nurses. Queensland is the only State that has not matched refresher training grants. Queensland is the only State that has refused to establish a nursing consultative committee to improve communication between the Government and the nursing profession. If better consultation on the future of nurse education and other issues affecting nurses is needed anywhere, it is certainly needed in Queensland. Queensland lags well behind other States in regard to child care provision, which means that, although the Commonwealth is prepared to fund extra child care places, the Queensland Government is not taking up the kind of share to which it is entitled and is not prepared to develop child care facilities where they are needed.

Recently, I met with a principal of a college of technical and further education who announced that he wanted to develop a child care provision for students attending his TAFE college but he was not allowed even to consider a child care provision on State Government premises. I can assume only that a similar ruling applies to hospitals. It is detrimental to nurses if they do not have access to child care facilities. The Queensland Minister for Education, Mr Powell, has a totally negative attitude to nurse education. On 9 September, in a speech in the Queensland Parliament, Mr Powell described the agreements that had already been reached with every other State in the Commonwealth as draconian. He said:
This Government-
the Queensland Government-

makes no apology for refusing to sign an agreement on the funding of higher education that would throw the major burden for both recurrent and capital expenditure for a tertiary education course on the State.

I challenge Mr Powell to explain why Queensland is so different in this regard. If the Commonwealth's agreement is as draconian as Mr Powell would have us believe, why has every other State been prepared to take up the option? I would like to run through some alarming figures relating to the number of persons qualifying as nurses in Queensland. In 1980-81, 923 general nurses qualified but, in 1984-85-the latest year for which figures are available-there were only 835. In midwifery the picture was not as serious but, nevertheless, in 1980-81 342 people graduated whereas in 1984-85 only 331 graduated. Child health is the focus of much attention in Queensland. Yvonne Chapman, the Minister for Welfare Services, Youth and Ethnic Affairs has made all sorts of grand claims about how concerned she is for the family, yet although 80 people qualified as child health nurses in 1980-81, in 1984-85 only 35 qualified. I think that one can see that Queensland nurses are concerned about the neglect that they are suffering. I am concerned that Federal initiatives are not being taken up by the Queensland Government.

A few weeks ago, when Dr Blewett tried to talk with Toowoomba nurses, he was barred from the Toowoomba General Hospital. What kind of consultation process is it in Queensland when a Federal Minister for Health who wants to talk to nurses about the transfer of nurse education, refresher training and other issues of vital concern is barred from entering a State hospital? Only a few months ago, I was fortunate enough to be a guest speaker at the Toowoomba General Hospital. Presumably Mr Austin was not asked whether that was all right with him, and I went without his approval. I suggest that the time for the Queensland Ministers for Health and Education to get their acts together and be prepared to talk to the Federal Government about the transfer of nurse education is long overdue. If that does not happen, I do not see that Queensland nurses have any reason to vote for the National Party Government in Queensland.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this adjournment debate I wish to deal with a question the nature of which I will not be able to deal with at any other stage in the foreseeable future. It is in respect of the development over the last few weeks of a New Right philosophy projected into the public sphere. I consider that there is too much preoccupation on the part of political leaders with the antics of the New Right and that this preoccupation will not cure the ills of this country. It is my view that fair-minded Australians will not subscribe to the philosophy of the New Right, which amounts to a late twentieth century version of the nineteenth century laissez-faire capitalism. The fundamental ground rule of that philosophy is the survival of the fittest, and it results in the most vulnerable and the voiceless suffering most. In economic life the law of the jungle means that small businesses and consumers would become defenceless victims of monopolies. In the industrial arena moderate unions, which have looked to the arbitration system for justice and equity for their members, will be the losers to the advantage of those unions controlled by the extreme Left, whose influence on the industrial and political Labor movements will correspondingly increase. This may, of course, be to the short term political benefit of the New Right, but in my view it will be to the long term detriment of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to observe that when I first came into the trade union movement as an official-it is too long ago to remember now, but it was probably 25 years ago-it was the extreme Left and the communist elements of the trade union movement that were seeking to smash the arbitration system. Now it is the New Right that is seeking to smash the arbitration system. I do not for a moment consider that the extreme Left and the communists have given away their anti-arbitration attitude, but the running is now being taken by the New Right. It is interesting to observe that some of them have gathered together in what is known as the H. R. Nicholls Society. I do not want to reflect individually on the members of that society. Some of what they say is correct and needs to be maturely considered. Indeed, all that they say needs to be maturely considered. But, Mr President, I point out to you that, insofar as a member of the H. R. Nicholls Society has sought to reflect on the Harvester judgment of Mr Justice Higgins, and insofar as they consider that H. R. Nicholls was right in reflecting on that judgment, they are historically inaccurate because the facts are that Nicholls did not win that case. That case was defeated on a technicality after counsel for Nicholls had withdrawn the substantial criticisms by Nicholls of Higgins.

It is important to note also that the Harvester judgment arose not from a wages application but from an application by the Sunshine Harvester Co. for what was virtually tariff protection. In order for the exemption certificate to be granted, the judge was required to determine what was a reasonable and fair wage and what was a reasonable and fair income. In addressing himself to that, he considered the question of what was reasonable to be paid to a worker so that the family of that worker would be maintained in frugal comfort. The important point to remember is that it was the family to which the attention of Judge Higgins was directed. It is clear from an examination of the judgment that he was influenced by the social principles that were developed in, for example, the great encyclical Rerum novarum. Indeed, it is important to reflect that the principle of conciliation and arbitration became ground into the consciousness of the Australian people, such that when it was attempted to be smashed politically by the Bruce Government, it was not arbitration that was smashed but the Bruce Government that was defeated.

I believe that it is well for everyone in this chamber and for people at large to reflect on those matters. I believe that it is important for the Government at present not to be diverted by the antics of the New Right but to concentrate on some of the real problems that are confronting families in today's society in living at a reasonable standard; to understand that those families are feeling the pinch, and that those families, along with every other sector of the community, are prepared to make sacrifices in the interests of the welfare of this country. But it is clear from an examination of what has happened to the incomes of those families that they are carrying an undue burden of the economic crisis at present, and indeed have done so over the last 10 years. In the last 10 years the disposable income of a family with four children on average earnings has dropped by 11 percentage points. Despite the much heralded tax cut of this Government, that family by this time next year will drop a further one percentage point.

It would be disconcerting to say the least, and most electorally damaging for the Government, not to heed the feelings of ordinary families who are feeling the pinch. It will be disgraceful if we in this Parliament allow to continue a situation where parents feel they are being discriminated against because they have children and that young people feel discriminated against in their job opportunities. As I have said on a number of occasions here in this chamber, whereas 20 years ago youth constituted 26.3 per cent of the Commonwealth Public Service, it now constitutes less than 5 per cent. I place these matters before the Senate in a genuine attempt to raise these issues for the Government's consideration, to attempt to address what I believe is a diversion on the part of the New Right, and to recommend that in its quest to crush arbitration, it pause and recognise what the end result will be to justice and equity in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.23 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following paper was tabled:
Health Insurance Act-Statements (2) of particulars of Ministerial Determinations authorised under section 106aa, together with reasons for Determinations, dated 8 September 1986.
The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are difficulties presently being encountered by Telecom in its attempts to establish a digital radio concentrator telephone service to Port Keats (Wadeye) via Peppimenarti and Palumpa.
(2) Has there been a very long delay in the provision of this service, as a result of protracted negotiations between Telecom and the Northern Land Council (NLC), in relation to this development.
(3) Is the present asking price of the NLC for each of the 6 sites which Telecom requires to provide the service $30,000; if not, what is the price being demanded by the NLC.
(4) What price, if any, is Telecom prepared to pay for these sites, in order to provide the telephone service.
(5) How does this compare with payment of `compensation' to owners of non-Aboriginal land acquired for similar purposes.

(6) What action is being taken to facilitate a speedy resolution of this matter which has now dragged on for 3 years, given that the Aboriginal people who live in the area which would be served by the facility, are keen to receive the facility.
(7) Can the Minister for Communications give any indications of when he expects the problem to be resolved, and when he expects the telephone service to be operating.
(8) What other applicants from outback Aboriginal settlements, is the Minister aware of, who may be experiencing problems similar to the one which exists in relation to Wadeye.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) and (4) No. The NLC requested for each of two of the sites a once only payment of $1,000 for a 25 year lease and for the third site a once only payment of $1,500 for a 25 year lease. Telecom has accepted this offer.

(5) The average price for non-Aboriginal land tends to be in the vicinity of $500. The higher offer to traditional owners reflects the dislocation and disruption caused to that land through the presence of Telecom staff and equipment and the strong ties the traditional owners have to the land.

(6) As indicated in the answer to (3) and (4) Telecom and the NLC have reached agreement on the matter. The detailed paperwork is in the process of being finalised. In the meantime permissive occupancy has been granted to allow the project to proceed.
(7) At this stage it is anticipated that the Wadeye system will be cutover for service in November 1986.

(8) Negotiations are continuing in relation to a number of DRCS projects, and are at different stages for the various locations. As in the Wadeye situation, Telecom is satisfied with the procedural arrangements which have been established and there are no problems being encountered which give Telecom any concern with respect to the timing and completion of the Rural and Remote Areas Programme.
